I was really amazed at the amount of different cultures that are all over the world. I feel completely different to everyone I knew, and there's lots of new things to learn and see. level1: Amongst so many notable women in Britain, little is known about the life of Dorothy Hodgkin. We learn only that she is the only British woman scientist ever to win a Nobel Prize, awarded in Physiology or Medicine for her work on skin cancer, a disease that often results in malignant lymph nodes on the face. But despite her remarkable achievement, Hodgkin is little known in her own country, says Georgina Ferry, the author of an upcoming biography of the pioneering surgeon. As she puts it, "the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel prize ought to be a household name in her own country." Her story goes far beyond the Nobel Prize, however. Her work on skin cancer changed medicine. It revealed the mechanisms by which our immune system kills cancer cells. Scientists have long suspected the possibility that the skin is just an extension of our body and that the cancer cells are an extension of our body. But this work, which led to the first clinical trials of the treatment, was conducted in 1950, and she and her colleagues made a discovery that would be the basis of chemotherapy. It is called adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and is used to prevent cancer recurrence. Her success led to the development of new and effective drug treatments for skin cancers. However, Hodgkin and her collaborators were often accused
level2_fkg: The only British woman scientist to win a Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country but she is little known. The only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country but she is little known.
level2_cefr: Dorothy Hodgkin was the first woman to win a Nobel prize in chemistry. Her work proved so brilliant that she was awarded it twice - first for the discovery of DNA in 1951 and again in 1960 - but for the unresolved questions about how DNA works – a subject on which she became known as Dr Dodgkin. In 'Dorothy Hodgkin's Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country', Georgina Ferry writes.
level3_fkg: The only British woman scientist to win a Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country, says Georgina Ferry, but she is little known.
level3_cefr: Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel prize. She is also one of only five living Nobel laureates. Yet little of her story is known. The one thing that is known is that in 1960s Britain was in a time of scientific transformation. A young British scientist, Dorothy Hodgkin, founded the British Institute of Cancer Research (BRIC), and set about developing the first successful therapy for the cancerous tumour of the skin. Her work on developing this was described by The Times as 'the most important piece of medical research done in the twentieth century'. However, Hodgkin was hardly the only one to study the skin in a lab. When the first radiotherapy treatment for cancer was developed in the 1920s, the work was largely carried out in the laboratory of Professor Harry Schild, who was a well-known radiologist at the time. The Nobel Prize, however, changed the course of Hodgkin's career. Instead of receiving it for a paper on cancerous skin cells, Hodgkin was awarded an honourary degree. However, this meant that she could not be awarded a prize in recognition of her work. Since 1967 she has been under an embargo. In 1994, when a number of other British researchers were awarded the same prize, a report argued that the British public had lost interest in this woman scientist,
level4_fkg: Dorothy Hodgkin (1931–2001) was one of the most outstanding scientists of the 20th century. She showed that light is absorbed by water. She is widely considered to be one of the most important scientists in the UK. In 2003 the University of Birmingham published a book called Dorothy Hodgkin, with the help of two colleagues. As the book shows, she was not only one of the most important scientists of the 20th century, she also helped bring the light of science to the rest of the world. The book was a bestseller in Britain.
level4_cefr: Dorothy Hodgkin was the first woman to win the Nobel Prize for Medicine. She died aged 87 in 1967. Georgina Ferry is the author of a biography of the British chemist who won the Nobel Prize in medicine in 1972, whose work led to a better understanding of cancer and led to the discovery of the cancer drug cisplatin.

level1: Sarah Janson (born 1946) is a painter of the trompe-l'oeil technique. Her paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. Here she is interviewed by Joanna Watt. There are a few artists who will not sign their work, unless they are asked to, like Sarah Janson. She is not remotely interested in the concept of the artist as creator, let alone that of the artist as genius. She believes that 'it's not the artist who is important, but the work'. 'It's not the artist who is important, but the work', she states. The title of this interview came from a book about trompe-l'oeil, called Sarah's Spell. In it, Janson writes: 'There can be no artists who are remotely interested in the concept of the artist as creator, let alone that of the artist as genius: It's not the artist who is important, but the work'. This is the very opposite to the attitude to art that most people hold towards it today. The idea that a painting's painter can be identified by its name is dated at the beginning of the 20th century. It isn't a new idea. Trompe-l'oeil, or 'deception of the eye,' was practiced by artists
level2_fkg: Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist whose paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. Here she is interviewed by Joanna Watt There cannot be many artists who do not sign their work unless they are asked to. Sarah Janson, a trompe-l'oeil artist, is one. She is not remotely interested in the concept of the artist as creator, let alone that of the artist as genius: 'It's not the artist who is important, but the work' she states. Janson is so self-deprecating that she would almost like you to believe that her trompe-l'oeil works paint themselves.

level1: The story of the careers of citizens Tristan Smith Set in the fictional republic of Efica is an extraordinary parable of human power, history and humour. In a feat of considerable literary skill, the author has created a world with its own history traditions and customs. The book is notable also for its humour and for the author’s unique vision which is here combined with the author’s penetrating psychological insight in a novel which is difficult but rewarding. Harriet is poised and middle-class with an architect husband and her own business. Ordinarily, she would never have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who looks after her ageing father and has brought up her grandson Leo since he was three. Leo is the oldest of the three. They have been spending time together in the garden but they are still unsure of each other’s relationship. Despite their mutual affection for each other, their differences are apparent and Harriet’s jealousy and her suspicions get the best of her. Leo has an accident during a bath and his grandmother carries him into the bath to comfort him, telling him he can’t have a bath yet because he has broken his leg. Leo has to wear protective leggings throughout the day, which help him to stand his ground and he has to be taught to walk again and be po

She is angry with her and wants to get rid of her. So Harriet takes her to court. As a child she wanted to be an actress. When she tells him that Leo is going to a school where all boys are the same, Leo wants to be a doctor and she refuses to let him go there. level2_cefr: Tristan Smith is a citizen of the fictional republic of Efica. He is a philanthropist who has devoted his life to the improvement of the lives of the people. His exploits reflect the society’s views of human beings, not only in the real world but also in the fictional one. Tristan is an extraordinary parable of human power, history and humour. In a feat of considerable literary skill, the author has created a world with its own history traditions and customs. The book is notable also for its humour and for the author’s unique vision, which is here combined with the author’s penetrating psychological insight in a novel which is difficult and rewarding.
level3_fkg: On his first visit to London Harriet is in love with Tristan Smith the only citizen of Efica who is not actually a citizen. After her friend Leo dies, he takes her eldest son Leo with him to Efica. However, it soon becomes apparent that Leo cannot be seen by others while Harriet and Tristan remain in the Republic. As the Republic turns into a despotism, Leo is taken into the custody of the ruthless Empress Alessandro and Harriet finds herself deeply unsatisfied with the Empress’s decision. As her lover she becomes enamoured with Leo and begins to see him as an innocent child. The situation becomes difficult when Harriet discovers the true identity of Leo. When she realizes that Leo is not her own, she asks Leo to marry her and return to Efica. However, Tristan returns to Efica with Leo’s parents and tells the Empress that Leo is in fact Leo’s sister. The Empress is convinced that this is true and decides to make him the official ambassador to Efica. Leo is not only refused entry by the Empress but also has to undergo an amnesiac experiment.
level3_cefr: Harriet is poised and middle-class with an architect husband and her own business. Ordinarily she would never have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who looks after her ageing father and has brought up her grandson Leo since he was three. But Leo is about to be eight years old when the author makes her visit to a remote village called “Bynina”. Sheila’s husband, Tony, is a poor man who sells bogus tickets to wealthy tourists in a bid to get more money. Sheila’s son, Leo, is a rich young man. The pair spend a few days together and become friends. Leo becomes a fan of Harriet and they arrange to meet each other at Leo’s school. Leo grows up thinking that he can win Harriet’s heart with one bite of her biscuit. But when Sheila refuses to give up her grandson, Leo is left with Harriet and Tony. Leo grows into a spoiled and ungrateful boy and refuses to go to school. He tells his mother that he needs her help and she turns and walks off. Leo’s mother tries to break the news to Harriet but Harriet resists as she thinks Leo might still be with Sheila and Tony.
level4_fkg: Harriet is a middle-class woman, with an architect husband, her own business and her own house. She does not often interact with people from her class. Sheila is a traditional working-class woman who looks after her ageing father and has brought up her grandson Leo since he was three. They are both very pleasant, but they don’t have a lot in common. Harriet says, “You might not understand that my husband is very rich. I can get most things, but I cannot buy anything and I can’t afford to have anything.” Leo looks at Harriet and says, “What do you mean with rich? What have you got?”
level4_cefr: Harriet is poised and middle-class with an architect husband and her own business. Ordinarily she would never have met Sheila a traditional working-class woman who looks after her ageing father and has brought up her grandson Leo since he was three. Sheila is the only person in the family who is honest and trustworthy. When Harriet meets Sheila she finds that she has become an equal with the old woman. Together they argue about life and death and find that there are some good ideas in their differences.

level1: Hakan Hardenberger is the only son of totally unmusical parents in a country district of southern Sweden. He was only six months old when his father rescued him from a bullfight, where the son had been fighting at full sprint. “He’s a little guy,” he said. But at that moment, Hakan saw the world as an enormous playground. His parents had never performed, not even a song, and were still arguing. “Hakan Hardenberger is a very gifted young man with an impressive pedigree, with the kind of talent that will have him toiling in music halls for the rest of his life,” his mother, Hanna Hardenberger, told the BBC. “He is very gifted,” Hakan’s father said. “He’s very clever,” he said. “So he’s definitely got that talent, which comes through.” Hakan grew up playing the trumpet with his dad. He’s also learned to play a piano, which has proved helpful. He’s learned to play guitar and violin. A few years ago, he discovered the trumpet and became a prodigy.
level2_fkg: Hakan Hardenberger had been playing the trumpet for only four years when he decided to study with a coach. He also needed money, so he went to London for a year. He became a member of the Swedish National Orchestra in 1976 and has never looked back since.
level2_cefr: A trumpet isn’t just for Christmas... It is strange how many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Out of the blue Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of totally unmusical parents in a country district of southern Sweden, has at the age of 30 established himself as unique among the world’s trumpet-players today. His records are continually opening up new repertory, not just concertos by long-neglected composers of the baroque and classical periods, but new works too. When you meet him, bright-eyed and good-looking, he seems even younger than his years. As fresh and open in his manner as the sound of the trumpet.

level1: A stay at Henlow Grange, Gloucestershire, is like going on holiday in itself. Set in the picturesque countryside, its vast grounds are a haven for nature lovers and exercise enthusiasts. I was introduced to yoga at the time and went to every class available. I am still very sore but feel totally fit and ready for the world back home. At the spa – which has yoga, Pilates, pilates, hydrotherapy, tennis and swimming pools – I felt pampered and relaxed. The treatments range from the traditional to the more modern and include facials, massages and holistic treatments. Its fitness centre is a must for anyone looking for a well-being break. I got an acupuncture treatment and went to a reflexology class. There are also a range of relaxation treatments, including Pilates. Henlow Grange is not just a health spa, it is a country house hotel too. There are spa facilities and health clubs too for the health conscious. The hotel is a Grade II listed building, so not suitable for young children. The food was excellent and we enjoyed all of it, with a few exceptions. The staff were friendly and helpful. Overall I was very happy with my stay.
level2_fkg: B. BULLES COMFORT BUILT I wowed by the accommodation at The BULLES COMFORT BUILT I thoroughly enjoyed my time at The BULLES COMFORT BUILT. I had a luxury room in a Georgian house which was very comfortable. I also had a balcony which allowed me to sit in the sun for long periods of time. My meals were excellent. I particularly enjoyed the food served at the restaurant, which included excellent fresh seafood. C. HESTERFIELD B&B I was impressed by the amount of detail they put into every facility they put on offer. The large swimming pool, heated indoor pool, outdoor heated pool, steam room, sauna, etc. are well thought out and very well maintained. There are lots of small cosy things to do throughout the week. The food was great (I ate fish for dinner every day and the fish were huge). The staff in general were friendly and helpful. There are also massage therapists, beauticians, personal trainers and sports massage therapists. There were other activities on offer, such as yoga and gastronomic cooking. I enjoyed the evening talks. The gastronomic lunches were a good way to end the day. D. HANDYHOUSE I was happy to be able to go to HANDYHOUSE for two days. I needed a

But from Day Two I started going to body conditioning and doing as many classes as I could (stretch and tone yoga body alignment to name but a few). But from Day Two I started going to body conditioning and doing as many classes as I could (stretch and tone yoga, body alignment to name but a few).

level1: Emma asked Charles for permission to visit Rouen. He thought she was crazy, so he said 'Yes.' and she went to her room. There were many letters. In every one she wanted to explain what she had done and what she meant. When she reached the top floor her room was full of flowers and champagne. She opened the door and greeted her loved one. Then she went to her bedroom and wrote 'Lionel, this evening I will not be home again - I shall be off to Rouen.' Charles smiled and said 'Honest!' Emma replied, 'I hope the iced drink was for you.' He said 'Yes. I would be happy to see you again if you wish.' He looked at her. She said 'Yes, of course!' 'Charles,' he said, 'it is hard for me to stay home, as you know.' Emma had always been a firm believer in the idea of a happy ending and it had been for her and Charles also.
level2_fkg: Charles had said exactly the name Emma wanted him to say. Now she could suggest that it was difficult to explain matters by letter and she offered to go over to Rouen and speak to Monsieur Leon directly. Charles would not hear of troubling her. She insisted. It was a battle of kindness. Finally she cried 'Now not another word please! I am going!' 'How kind you are!' he said kissing her on the forehead. The next morning she was off to Rouen in the coach to consult Monsieur Leon. She stayed for three days. They were three wonderful days. They stayed down near the harbour at the Hotel de Boulogne and there they lived with the curtains closed, the doors locked, the floor covered with flowers and iced drinks brought up every morning.

level1: Leadership is not about breeding or height - taller being better, as the early theorists believed. It’s not simply about intelligence either. Pat Dixon author of the book Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace says that leadership is about ‘making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are’. Enthusiasm is a key element and to convey it and encourage it in others a good leader should be able to speak out articulately and with conviction.
level2_fkg: Career power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. A. What makes a good leader? level1: We are being judged by a new yardstick: not just by how clever we are or by our training and expertise but also by how well we handle ourselves and each other. This yardstick is increasingly used in choosing who will be hired and who will not, who will be passed over and who will not. The new rules can be used to indicate who is likely to become a star performer and who is more prone to mediocrity.
level2_fkg: Emotional intelligence is the key to success. Daniel Goleman examines the 'people skills' that are essential for a place at the top of your profession.
level2_cefr: Daniel Goleman examines the 'people skills' that are essential for a place at the top of your profession. 1. Emotional intelligence is defined as the ability to read emotions and to distinguish between good and bad feelings. 2. It can be assessed by the following: 1. Emotional intelligence 2. Interpersonal skills 3. Self-management 4. Organizational skills 5. Self-control 6. Leadership 7. Service 8. Problem solving 9. Creativity 10. Persuasiveness 11. Social skills 12. Self-motivation 13. Teamwork 14. Listening 15. Compassion 16. Leadership 17. Discipline 18. Teamwork 19. Leadership 20. Decision-making 21. Communication 22. Compassion 23. Self-awareness 24. Responsibility 25. Emotional intelligence (EF) refers to the ability to understand and relate to emotions. EFF was named after Daniel Goleman, a psychologist.
level3_fkg: Emotional intelligence (EQ) is the most important skill you can have, even if you're not very clever. Daniel Goleman describes this skill and suggests that if you possess it, you can get ahead of the game.
level3_cefr: Daniel Goleman examines the 'people skills' that are essential for a place at the top of your profession. The rules for work are changing: we are being judged by a new yardstick - not just by how clever we are or by our training and expertise but also by how well we handle ourselves and each other. This yardstick is increasingly used in choosing who will be hired and who will not who will be passed over and who will not. The new rules can be used to indicate who is likely to become a star performer and who is more prone to mediocrity.
level4_fkg: Emotional intelligence is the key to success in any field, and particularly when it comes to managing others. This book gives some advice to people who want to be successful in this area, and is also entertaining to read.

This yardstick is increasingly used in choosing who will be hired and who will not, who will be passed over and who will not. The new rules can he used to indicate who is likely to become a star performer and who is more prone to mediocrity.

level1: A. Credit Card Executive I get up at 6 am to arrive at the office around 7.30 am. I manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. My responsibilities include the launch and management of the Membership Rewards scheme in the major European markets. I have to keep in touch with existing card users, acquire new ones and build relationships with partner companies. I use the first 45 minutes to organise my day and then I respond to any e-mail messages. I manage all the advertising for the membership programme across Europe, so I meet with our marketing staff and the advertising agencies to establish a strategy and work on future developments. B. level1: A watch with a radio alarm clock can keep you awake and give you a reason to get out of bed (or sleep in). Stuart Harris of The Daily Telegraph looks at five of the most popular, with the most positive comments coming from the inventor Tom Granger (the first ever alarm clock and an inventor whose company also designed the first computerised acoustic alarm clock). The radio wakes you up with a preset station from a local station. We then tried a snooze function, which allows you to use the radio as the alarm. This works very well as the alarm only goes off after a certain time of the day, rather than at the start of the day. But the snooze works very poorly, so unless you want to get up at the same time every morning, this probably won't work for you. It's also very expensive, which explains why it's not a top seller. The radio can also be turned up very loud for very early morning wake-ups, although this isn't very helpful if you're going to be in bed in the morning. The radio has a very simple layout, and the two main channels are clearly labelled. I've got the Radio 1 set with an extra station, but it really doesn't matter much which one I have as long as I can hear it. (And it also plays music
level2_fkg: The 'dual alarm function' that is advertised with this model does not allow you, as I first supposed, to be woken by the buzzer, snooze a while and then finally be driven out of bed.
level2_cefr: Stuart Harris reports Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? Our panel, which consisted of myself plus the inventor Tom Granger and the broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five currently available clock radios. The 'dual alarm function' that is advertised with this model does not allow you as I was first supposed to be woken by the buzzer, snooze a while and then finally be driven out of bed.

level1: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand Jonathon Porritt talks to Danny Dannziger in the studio. In this extract, Porritt talks about 'green' politics, and the politics of environmentalism. Porritt is one of the foremost campaigners in the country for replanting native species. He says it's 'a powerful weapon' against global warming. "It was the first time in my life that I really understood why climate change was so important, why humankind had such little control over it and why we had no right to make any change until we knew what was going to happen."
level2_fkg: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand. Jonallum Porritt's new book sees it as an 'ecological' revolution, and a turning point in the way we think about the environment.
level2_cefr: With the trees, I planted my stake in New Zealand Jonallum Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology, which was published in 2004.
level3_fkg: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand with my parents. Jonallum Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology'.
level3_cefr: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand JONATHON PORRITT TODAY, Danny Danziger talks to Jonallum Porritt the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology.
level4_fkg: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER Jonallum Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics ofEcology'. I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went out to New Zealand every summer here which is the New Zealand winter and so I had nine winters on the trot which was great because I like winter. My parents came up with this idea of buying a small plot of land which ‘the kids’ my brother, sister and I could look after. Mother said ‘If you can take the time and trouble to plant it with trees then you can have it’. The idea was that we would always have a stake in New Zealand, which is a lovely idea as my father was actually brought up there.
level4_cefr: With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand. Jonathon Porritt TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER Jonathon Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology'. I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went out to New Zealand every summer here, which is the New Zealand winter, and so I had nine winters on the trot which was great because I like winter. My parents came up with this idea of buying a small plot of land which 'the kids', my brother, sister and I could look after. Mother said ‘If you can take the time and trouble to plant it with trees, then you can have it'. The idea was that we would always have a stake in New Zealand which is a lovely idea as my father was actually brought up there.

level1: I thoroughly enjoyed Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard. This young adult novel is beautifully drawn. Emma is a confident young girl, who, in addition to her innate curiosity, is a sensitive and intelligent, but also a very good friend. There is a sense that a lot of that friendship comes from her caring, loyal father, who loves her but doesn't understand why Emma is always a bit naughty. Often times, he takes advantage of the lack of trust that Emma has in her father, but it's clear from the outset that Emma is not just naughty but is trying to escape his love. When she finds her life in danger, it's a dark and compelling read. Coppard does a good job revealing the minutiae of family life, the bonds of childhood friendship and warnings that adults aren't always the protectors they ought to be. A fun and interesting read for kids of all ages, and an example of how well Coppard understands what it is like to be a kid.
level2_fkg: Yvonne Coppard is a British author who wrote the book "Hide and Seek". In this book, Emma and her friends are pursuing a holiday game: surveillance of a suspicious bookshop. However, soon they realise that one of its rare customers is their uncle Jim, and he starts to manipulate their affection for him. After trying to make Emma fall in love with Jim, he begins to alienate her from her friends. Emma is confined in a cellar in a derelict house, and the book she buys in the cellar is the only thing Emma takes with her from the house, including her parents and a picture of her parents. The book gives a stunning overview of the minutiae of family life, the bonds of childhood friendship, and warns that adults aren't always the protectors they ought to be.
level2_cefr: Yvonne Coppard is a British author who writes books for children. The book Hide and Seek is about Emma and her friends when they are on holiday at her family's cottage. They have been engaged in a holiday game — surveillance of a suspicious bookshop — when they realise that one of its rare customers is Emma's uncle Jim. He callously draws her into a web of deceit and crime, manipulating her affection for him and attempting to alienate her from her friends. Emma finds herself in danger and things take a dark and compelling turn: her confinement in the cellar of a derelict house is stunningly handled.
level3_fkg: Hide and Seek Yvonne Coppard Emma and her friends are pursuing a holiday game — surveillance of a suspicious bookshop — when she realises that one of its rare customers is her Uncle Jim. He callsously draws her into a web of deceit and crime, manipulating her affection for him and attempting to alienate her from her friends, whose characters are persuasively drawn by Coppard. When Emma finds her life in danger things take a dark and compelling turn — her confinement in the cellar of a derelict house is stunningly handled. This book reveals the minutiae of family life, the bonds of childhood friendship, and warns that adults aren’t always the protectors they ought to be.
level3_cefr: Hide and Seek is a young adult novel set in England. A young girl, Emma, and her friends are pursuing a holiday game — surveillance of a suspicious bookshop — when she realises that one of its rare customers is her Uncle Jim. He callously draws her into a web of deceit and crime, manipulating her affection for him and attempting to alienate her from her friends, whose characters are persuasively drawn by Coppard. When Emma finds her life in danger things take a dark and compelling turn - her confinement in the cellar of a derelict house is stunningly handled. This book reveals the minutiae of family life, the bonds of childhood friendship, and warns that adults aren’t always the protectors they ought to be.

level1: P. D. James may exude an air of quiet authority, but she is a secretly complex and brilliant writer. Barbara Michaels meets the acclaimed crime writer whose innocent exterior hides a complex and brilliant imagination.
level2_fkg: Phyllis Dorothy James is the author of eighteen novels including the best-selling series Dalgliesh & Dalgliesh Mysteries. The initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy.
level2_cefr: Barbara Michaels meets the acclaimed crime writer whose innocent exterior hides a complex and brilliant imagination. Best-selling crime writer P. D. James - the initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy - exudes an air of quiet authority. It is easy to envisage her had she not become a creator of detective stories with more twists and turns than a spiral staircase as the headmistress of a girls' school. But it is soon apparent from what she says that the authoritative mien is in fact a cloak for shyness. She reluctantly admits that Adam Dalgliesh the detective in her novels ‘is I suppose modelled on myself - or rather the way I would have turned out if I had been a man’.
level3_fkg: Phyllis Dorothy James was born in 1875 in Liverpool, England. Her early days were spent in boarding schools, teaching English and Greek at Bishopstone School. As her career grew more demanding, her school closed, but she soon found herself teaching history, and became a prolific and successful author. At 19, she wrote her first novel – A Murder at the Hoggarts in 1919 – before moving to Cambridge in 1933 to teach the history department. She has always been a keen amateur detective, and her later novels feature the same kind of devious killers as the detective novels, notably Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. She is also well-known for her popular Adam Dalgliesh, a man of many talents who has helped solve mysteries that have captivated readers around the world. Barbara Michaels caught up with P. D. James to find out about her career.
level3_cefr: Phyllis Dorothy James (born Phyllis Doris James) was born in England but has lived in various locations worldwide since the age of 12. P.D. James' first book The Last of the Boys came out in 1939. Her second book The Murders of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas was released in 1970. A third book, The Murders of Mr. and Mrs. D. B., was released in 1980. All her books are based on police detective Adam Dalgliesh. Phyllis Dorothy James is an American writer who has written more than 500 books. She is best known for her crime novels set in England. The initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy and the initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy James. Her best-selling novel Adam Dalgliesh is based on herself. Phyllis Dorothy James (born Phyllis Dorothy James) was born in England. She has lived in various locations throughout the world since the age of 12.

level1: This month, we will be looking at some of the great British sportswomen currently breaking records and proving they can do it all. As a skiing instructor, Jill has trained hundreds of students at her ski club, and also has her own ski school. In fact, she has four ski school sites. She also uses her skills to train for the slopestyle season and has helped to train young male skiers. Her other sport is cross-country skiing, where she is the national champion. Jill is also the father of a five-year-old boy. Her career started skiing at the age of nine. She went on to compete at the 2012 Olympics. She won the 5000m and 10,000m sprints, and the superathlon in 2014. She says the sport has taught her to put her body and mind to work – and to be patient when it’s hard. Her main focus now is the Winter Olympics in Sochi, where she will compete in biathlon next week.
level2_fkg: Great sports Women on a winning streak To excel in any sport is hard enough even for men, but women have to be twice as tough. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. But against all the odds, they are beating prejudice and breaking records. Here we talk to just a haw brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals. A. Jill 27 skier "It’s a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don’t feel well or it’s windy and you can’t see, but you just get on with it. I had the feeling when I had my first X-country race: I was going in a strong, confident and confident sort of way and it felt like I was flying." B. Amanda 38 cyclist "The feeling of victory is an amazing thing but it can also be dangerous. I can’t see all the way round and have to jump off the bike. The race is about me and the bike. I have a great idea of what the course is going to be like and I just get on with it." C. Sarah 47 golfer "It’s great when you win because you feel like you’ve won and you feel good. But it can also be really hard when you’re down and have to deal with injury. But I

level1: I saw a lot of things he said. "And I know a lot more. This visit is about money. Mr. Phelan promised that he would take care of me in his will. There were many promises all broken." "Was he crazy?" "He was or he wasn't. Doesn't matter to me. This is the way I see it. Since they're all heavily in debt the kids have to contest the will. No jury's going to feel sorry for them. They're a bunch of greedy losers. It'll be a tough case to win. But you and the other lawyers will attack the will and you'll create this huge lawsuit that gets in the newspapers. "

level1: Bringing up badger cubs. I remember my first thought when Derek took me into the shed to hold a very small cub. He was just two weeks old and the rest were tiny. He explained he had taken the cubs into his shed with the intention of bringing them to the vet for treatment. He had taken them in from the fields where they’d been run over by a car and then let them back out into the fields. They’d been left at that but a few months later they had found their way onto the farm and were being fed as part of a programme. The vet said the badger cubs were around three months old. “Each has their own character,” he said. The badgers were soon growing bigger than their little bodies so we introduced them to other large wildlife species such as a fox and an owl. We’d have to put them in big enclosures as we couldn’t bring them into the house with us. We had to put them in an electric fence. When one of the badgers stepped into the electric fence and ran towards us it immediately jerked the fencing down and so we set up a barrier on the ground. Soon a fox had chased it away and it was the badger’s turn to ruffle the fence. We called the vet to pick the cubs up and
level2_fkg: I was delighted when Derek called me to pick them up. With a sigh, he said he would take them off to the farm vet for examination. The vet told me it was an unusually large badger cub and it had been injured in a car accident but it wouldn’t have been fatal. I knew this was the case because it was the only badger cub on the farm that I’d seen in recent years. The vet, Tom, told me all I needed to know. First, his partner, Colin, was the one to have injured the cubs. Colin said that the tyres he had used on the back of the car — before he took them to hospital — could’ve been very dangerous. But they were all fine and the vet said he was surprised at the size and condition of the badgers. That is when he told me the cubs were born in the shed at their mother’s home, just yards away from his dairy farm. This time the badgers were not in the shed, but in their mum’s garden, on her lawn. Unlike the first three cubs, the others were wriggling from the shock of a car accident and had no tails or ears. In the next few days, it became apparent that these young badgers had been living in the shed all day long and as
level2_cefr: My husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an ‘open farm’ six years ago so we’ve established a reputation for looking after orphaned animals. But the noise coming from die box — a cross between a cackle and a bark - was not one I recognised so it was with great interest that I peered in to see three small grey badger cubs each no more than eight inches long. Their coats (later to reveal fleas) were like velvet and milky-coloured eyes looked up at me from three tiny black-and-white striped heads.
level3_fkg: It had been a busy day for us at the farm and my head was spinning with the thought that it was going to be long before I could get them up, fed and watered, and away from the big cats. But as I climbed onto the farmhouse steps, a feeling of joy and relief filled me. They were badger cubs and we wouldn’t have them for long. We put them out to be fed and watered and then – as quickly as we could get them on to the hayloft — sheltered them from the bad weather. I could see how quickly they’d adjust to the heat and the heat lamp, which had been set in the sunroom. Within an hour they’d joined their mothers in the hayloft. The noise they were making had been coming from the small enclosure and they had to be moved. Soon they had settled, and in two hours they’d been named “Ozzy”, “Peter” and “Nick”. Clearly they had been used to humans, but it was a bit odd when they started doing their own thing. When they first got out, Pete was quieter, but soon started to give us lots of cuddles. Peggy had not been able to get up to them by herself and had only a few minutes to nurse them. After a while she had climbed in and was holding them up
level3_cefr: We’d just rescued three cubs from the back of a van in the far reaches of Somerset — a rarity in this part of the country which gets heavy rainfall, heat and snow at an unusually rapid rate. We had brought them up from their mother’s den, and although they threw up a few times they were not going to be eaten by predators for a while, so they’d presumably died in the journey. We knew their mother was safe as it was spring and we hadn’t heard a sound for seven days. When I got back from church I rushed over to the badgers’ den to see how they were doing and noticed the mothers were clearly struggling. I was relieved that they weren’t horsing around with a huge herd and decided to let them stay in the farmyard for a few days. They settled in easily as well, but the older two wanted to stay with their mother. When they grew up, we will hopefully be able to separate them from their mother.
level4_fkg: I immediately thought about whether I should try to care for them as I'm not experienced with badgers. In my experience, as long as they are cared for in their enclosure, they will stay with us. But bringing up badgers? Who do you trust with them? What do you want to do with them? This involves deciding whether to put them in a new enclosure or keep them with us. For some animals it may be better to be with them in the new enclosure, with their mother, and for others it may be better to keep them outside with their dad. Derek and I have a rule that no badger will ever leave the area where we culled them. It’s too dangerous. When I put the cubs back into their new enclosure, they would stay with us for three days as a precaution against attacks. Now that they’ve done so much to survive, I’d also like to think that the two of them will eventually bond with one another, to become a whole badger family.
level4_cefr: ‘So you have three cubs?’ Derek said as I took hold of his arms and pulled the sack out of the box. ‘That is great. Let’s move them to a safer place.’ I held the cubs up in my arms to feel their thin bodies. When I looked at them closer, they each had small dark circles under their eyes – probably fleas. I rushed to give them one more cuddle. ‘You will stay with us until they are strong enough to go out to be alone. It might take a few days for you to get over that,’ I said as I held the cubs in my arms.

level1: Publisher A: Reviews can or should sell a book. For a broad range of books and on most levels, yes. However, authors may be more oblivious about this. They are more likely to respond to reviews that are good than negative. Book marketing is therefore really much about selling a book in the right way. In that sense it is much less about the reviewer's opinion about a book as such and more about having people buy a book. We haven't yet published a study, so we'll wait to see what happens but you do get the sense of the size of the potential audience of reviewers at the start of every review - with those that are good tending to focus more on a book in their opinion. The impact of negative reviews is less strong. Some readers may have decided they liked a book based on one negative review while others may have remained undecided. Some reviews may be really good and some simply bad. We are happy to see reviewers' experiences as they can be interesting to see. There's something about a really bad review that catches people's attention.
level2_fkg: Publisher B I think that reviewers play a very important role in determining the success of a book. The book review in the Daily Mail and the Guardian is often the first part of a newspaper that people turn to. The authors' responses to review are slightly different from publishers. Both are devastated by no reviews but publishers are usually more equable about the had reviews judging that column inches are what matter and that a combination of denunciation and ecstatic praise can actually create sales as readers decide to judge for themselves.
level2_cefr: Publisher B A book is often purchased by the buyer because of a review. As an author, I do not find reviews to be helpful in getting a book published. I have no idea if publishers think reviews make a big difference to a book's sales, but I'm generally satisfied if a book is recommended on a blog by a friend or colleague, and is reviewed by another reviewer. A good review will help to sell a book when it is difficult to attract a review from a book critic, or when I have not marketed a book well enough. The best reviews are those written by people whom I have not published with, who have a good knowledge of the book and its characters, and are genuinely enthusiastic about it. These are rare but the authors who write books whose characters are not well known also tend to receive positive reviews.
level3_fkg: Publisher B The quality of a book's reviews is one of the most important factors when it comes to the decision to buy a book, but it is difficult to tell whether a review is helpful or destructive. However, I have come across books that have been influenced positively by negative reviews. Certainly a good deal of the public's knowledge of a book comes from online reviews. Some people read reviews before they read the book and can then make their own mind up about whether it is something they would read. In some books, this leads to a decision being made, but it is more difficult to know whether the book is worth re-reading. Other books have been influenced negatively by reviews and have been re-read. Publisher C A review is crucial to our commercial success. It's something we do to maximise our sales and to make sure the books we publish are as good as possible for our readers. Some book-lovers might be put off a book if the reviews are critical, but others might just think the book is good. Publisher D The author, like the publisher, is affected by reviews more than anyone else. The more positive or critical the review is, the more the sales will increase. The reviews we are most worried about are those that say that the book is not good or not up to standard. However, most book-lovers are a little bit wary of those kind of reviews,
level3_cefr: IMHO, reviews don't sell books. You can't get people to buy a book from one review. You need to sell the book yourself.
level4_fkg: Do reviews sell books? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of the reviews of a book on its commercial success. Here is what they said: Publisher A Reviews are absolutely key for publishers - the first part of the newspaper we turn to. The Book Marketing Council found some years ago that when questioned on why they had bought a particular book, more people cited reviews than any other prompting influence (advertisements, word of mouth bookshop display etc.). Authors' responses to reviews are slightly different from publishers. Both are devastated by no reviews, but publishers are usually more equable about the had reviews, judging that column inches are what matter and that a combination of denunciation and ecstatic praise can actually create sales as readers decide to judge for themselves.
level4_cefr: Author B I think reviews are extremely important. Books are reviewed almost daily in the newspapers - for example, in the Guardian, Daily Mail, Telegraph, etc. This is where people see the book's cover (often the first one they see) which can have a dramatic influence on purchase decision making, especially for children's books. I think reviews don't always mean as much for children's books as they do for adult books (for example, 'A boy's life in the wartime trenches' and so on), but it is an important part of my job to get a fair, professional, unbiased review published and, ultimately, the book sold. I think that the reviews are very important for children's books too, however. I think they are equally important for adults and a good review can get sales for both. We have a review for every book that we publish, we have a review for every author we publish. For all books we do review a copy of all our books for bookshops so that they are seen by many readers in a wide range of bookshops and so increase our sales.

level1: Graham Smith, a craftsman with over 25 years experience, is one of the few people in the country who still hand cut weathervanes.
level2_fkg: WeaTHERVANE MAKER THE MAKING of weathervanes is an ancient skill going back to early Egyptian times. Today, the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham’s designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers. ‘That way I can produce a unique personalised item’ he explains. A lot of his customers are women buying presents for their husbands. They want a distinctive gift that represents the man’s business or leisure interests. It’s all a far cry from the traditional cockerel, the most common design for weathervanes.

level1: "They're getting hung for this?" Mrs. Rohr asked. "Yes, and I'm guilty of this." "It is because of the 'denials.'" Rohr said. "Yes," said Mrs. Rohr. "I made a mistake."
level2_fkg: "How did you know that the tobacco companies aimed their advertising at teenagers?" he asked. "We spent millions studying kids. We knew that they could name the three most advertised brands of cigarettes. We knew that almost 90 percent of the kids under eighteen who smoked preferred the top three advertised brands. So what did the companies do? They increased the advertising." "Did you know how much money the tobacco companies were making from cigarette sales to children?" Rohr asked. "About two hundred million dollars a year." "I didn't, either." Rohr said. "But I also didn't say that the tobacco companies knew that 3000 kids start smoking every day and that nearly all adult smokers start as teenagers. "Now I know, though."

level1: A great interview with a great athlete. Great article about the importance of altitude training. Thanks Richard for sharing your experience of your training camp in Kenya.
level2_fkg: The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar, one of Britain's top 10000-metre runners, visits the Kenyans' high-altitude training camp. Ten miles south of the equator a sony mountain track leads off the quiet metalled road from Nairobi. The track marks the start of the trek up Kenya's highest peak, the glacier-capped Mount Kenya. This gorgeous if lonely and isolated spot is Nanyuk: for the past three years it has been my base for mid-winter altitude training in Kenya's Central Highlands. But not once on those trips had I trained with Kenyan runners on their home soil. On my fourth and most recent winter training trip to Kenya however, I broke a personal tradition.
level2_cefr: "I had never trained with Kenyans before." It was a dream come true. "After training with us for the last three years, if I wanted to run at altitude I'd have to come back to Kenya." I was determined to achieve this goal. "As I arrived there were only two other Brits at training, and I knew I had to be in it to win it."
level3_fkg: The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar one of Britain’s top 10,000-metre runners visits the Kenyans’ high-altitude training camp. Ten miles south of the equator a sony mountain track leads off the quiet metalled road from Nairobi. The track marks the start of the trek up Kenya's highest peak, the glacier-capped Mount Kenya. This gorgeous if lonely and isolated spot is Nanyuk: for the past three years it has been my base for mid-winter altitude training in Kenya’s Central Highlands. But not once on those trips had I trained with Kenyan runners on their home soil. On my fourth and most recent winter training trip to Kenya however, I broke a personal tradition. I ran a marathon in Nanyuk: my fastest time was 2 hours and 3 minutes. I ran with the Kenyans for the first time ever, for which I was humbled. They were extremely proud of me. They had to train hard to be able to compete in Nanyuk. But I must admit they were also very proud of Nanyuk, not least because they had to go far to get there – just ten miles from my base. The route took us through dense forest and across rocky fields, but with the guidance of the Kenyan staff we climbed the mountain. When we reached the top it was as though we had reached
level3_cefr: Two weeks later I arrived in Nairobi for my last training session before I headed for Kenya. I stayed at Nanyuk, a mountain base for mid-winter altitude training in the Kenyan Central Highlands. For the past three years it has been my base for mid-winter altitude training in Kenya’s Central Highlands. But not once on those trips had I trained with Kenyan runners on their home soil. And on my fourth and most recent winter training trip to Kenya, I broke a personal tradition. I joined a few Kenyan runners on their home soil.
level4_fkg: The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar one of Britain's top 1,0000-metre runners visits the Kenyans’ high-altitude training camp. level1: The hull of Tom Cunliffe's yacht, "The Westerman", looks like it has aged - but she's not. The hull, launched last June, is a modern evolution of an old design of motoryacht - a small, powerful boat built to explore the Channel. "I had a couple of prototypes of boats that had been built for the last few years and had proved well," says Cunliffe, the co-founder of London-based Boatbuilding Company, Tom Cunliffe. "For me, design is about being able to meld the old and new of boatbuilding, and that is what is best for a boat. "I knew the design of a modern, highly-powered powerboat, such as a Volvo Penta, would work well in fresh water and I would think that would work for a big boat that had been built in shallow water." The idea that the hull of The Westerman would look old but not look "out of place" proved difficult, says Cunliffe. "I had to have a broader view, think about the whole picture of the vessel and what it would look like in the water." "That meant I needed to use every available form of technology - from hydrodynamics to navigation systems, from radar to navigation lights - to make this boat as functional as
level2_fkg: A designer has created a boat that is a mixture of old and new. Tom Cunliffe was a British yacht designer who was born in Kent and lived in Scotland, where he studied at the Royal College of Art in London. He now owns a boat on the south coast and sails it regularly.
level2_cefr: Tom Cunliffe is a British yacht designer who is in the process of creating the boat of his dreams. He says it should combine old and new.
level3_fkg: Tom Cunliffe's 'The Westerman' is a traditional-looking boat, which was designed in 1997. He says the vessel can be easily taken off the road, making it easy to take home for maintenance.
level3_cefr: The boat of my dreams is about combining old with new, Tom Cunliffe argues in his article for the Sunday Times. "It's the boat of my dreams because it looks like a traditional boat, but there are loads of modern tech '', says Tom, who designed The Westerman. Tom has been a yacht builder since he was about 12 and built his first boat in 1984. He then went on to build his own boat, The Westerman in 1992. He says he is ''a bit of an old guy.'' He lives on a tidal creek off the south coast, with his wife and six-month-old son.
level4_fkg: THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS The best boat design should combine old and new says Tom Cunliffe. And he put it into practice in his own craft, 'The Westerman.' This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is resplendent with fine yachts bristling with new technology. Nearly all are descendants of the hull-shape revolution that took place 25 years ago. By contrast, my own lies quietly on a tidal creek off the south coast. She was designed last year, but seeing her you might imagine her to be 100 years old and think that her owner must be some kind of lost-soul romantic.

level1: Hedgehogs Hedgehogs are small mammals characterised by the sharp spines which cover their body. The hedgehog is found in many different parts of the world. None of the hedgehogs are native to either America or Australia. All species of hedgehog share the ability to roll into a tight ball when attacked so that their spines point outwards. The effectiveness of this as a defence mechanism depends of course on the number of spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to carry extra weight, and consequently they have fewer spines and are thus more likely to attempt to run into their attacker using their ball rolling ability as a last resort.

level1: An old English village has a blacksmith shop and a smith who makes wrought-iron stair treads. The old man has been resurrected by a group of youngsters who want him back into business. They have to find a smith to rebuild an old-fashioned smithy to repair it. The boys have to find a smith to make a wrought-iron staircase. Then they have to learn how to drive a forklift truck to get it to the village. The old man and a group of youngsters from a nearby village are all based at the town’s old public house.
level2_fkg: Blacksmiths have played an important role in British history, for all time iron has exerted a powerful pull on the human imagination and the men who work it have often been regarded as much more than skilled craftsmen. Before the Industrial Revolution blacksmiths enjoyed the same status as doctors and astrologers because they were the sole providers of weapons, armour and farming tools. They also been féted as artis. Eighteenth-century smiths produced the wonderfully baroque ironwork for St Paul’s Cathedral. The sinuous metalwork of French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture was always the work of a talented blacksmith. But practitioners of these ancient skills had become almost extinct in Britain by the late 1960s, for heavy industry had ceased to have any use for them and towerblock architects rarely used anything as graceful and pleasing as a wrought-iron handrail. Blacksmiths, the makers of intricate ironwork, had disappeared but there was a revival of interest in wrought iron as the defining feature of modern architecture.

level3_cefr: THEN, in the 1990s, a blacksmith in Bradford came up with a solution: he took old cars and other vehicles that had heavy rust and he began to polish them in his workshop. Hundreds of people now buy his handcrafted wrought-iron works at his shop and he has gained a new clientele.

level1: "We got in there in January and they were still trying to find a name for the building," one person told me of the museum, which opened today. And a number of people were less complimentary in their reviews. I went to a preview party for the new Tartan Museum last month and saw the museum from the outside and then went inside. It is not the most attractive building and the layout of the collection is a lot less intuitive than it might seem. It is located opposite a centuries-old building and there is no obvious way that an unfamiliar visitor is going to know where it is. There is an enormous stack of artefacts to see, but the best of them is a small, circular wooden structure. It is a hulking, dark and very different piece of architecture. The only one that I would call impressive. I like the idea of a modern art museum but this was much different. It was very dark, very dark, very dark. It felt like a hospital. It felt like a hospital with a big, cloistered, dark and gloomy room, like you were on the second floor, not the ground floor, as I had feared. The smell in the room was overpowering. In comparison the new museum is pretty tame. "When I walked into it there was a lot of confusion," says one person, "I don
level2_fkg: The new Museum of Scotland is open, and it is beautiful. Despite the stark contrast in design, the Tartan Museum in Edinburgh - designed to coincide with Scotland's national day - is packed with history. Sally Varlow went to see it just before it opened to find out what it was like.
level2_cefr: Tartan is Scotland's national symbol and one of the most popular things to see in Scotland. The national museum is set on a corner of Edinburgh's Chambers Street with its huge yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings topped by a hulk of a hanging garden. This unassuming new museum contrasts sharply with its historic location. But would its contents be as striking? Sally Varlow went to visit the Museum of Scotland just before it opened. She was there early in the day, so the exhibits were under wraps, so that it was impossible to appreciate how much the interior had changed. "It was quite a surprise when I walked in," she says.
level3_fkg: The new Museum of Scotland has a surprising amount of space, yet it still looks like a giant spaceship. It has been compared to the likes of Burj Khalifa and Buckingham Palace. The building, which was designed by architect Zaha Hadid, was controversial from the start. It was built on the site of an old courthouse, right on the corner of Chambers Street, a street full of historic buildings and an area known as the 'Irish Quarter' which is home to the Royal Scottish Academy. It is a big building, but the most striking thing about it are the whitewashed walls, which contrast sharply with the yellow sandstone tower on which it sits. At first, it was only the outside of the new Museum of Scotland that was unmissable, stuck on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh with its huge yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings topped by a hulk of a hanging garden. Last winter, the building was greeted with a mix of modernist architectural applause ('masterpiece''stunning') cautious approval ('striking') and outright hostility. A sculptor and historian, David Hume, took umbrage, telling The Evening Standard: 'This has to be the best building you have ever seen.' That
level3_cefr: The new National Museum of Scotland in Scotland's capital is destined to elicit a variety of opinions. And some, such as David Adler of the National Trust for Scotland, are unconvinced. Adler, who has criticised the building's design in numerous publications, has argued that the building's appearance makes it hard to get into, but he says it is a fitting home for the nation's history. Others find it obnoxious and jarring. A few say the museum's buildings can feel a little unnaturally out of place, adding that it lacked a home on its historic site. But a number of critics see its contents as compelling and suggest it may outperform other similar museums in other places, as well as the rest of the country. "The design is outstanding and the building is stunning," said architect Philip Jones. "There's also an element of surprise and delight here. The museum tells the story of the nation through objects, film, art, archival material, and new technologies." Some critics, however, find the museum's interior design "as striking as the building's exterior." The museum's temporary exhibitions include an installation called the Tartan Garden. The installation was designed by artist John Bell, who is also a senior adviser to Glasgow-based Yarrow McLean Architect
level4_fkg: Modernism in Scotland The Modernism in Scotland The Scottish Government has just opened the Museum of Scotland, its new state-of-the-art headquarters in Edinburgh, a modern cheese-wedge building that is in stark contrast to its historic and picturesque setting.
level4_cefr: The Scottish government's new national museum faces criticism of its strange appearance and its controversial use of modern materials. The museum, which opened this week, has been described as a masterpiece of modern architecture. The tower, topped by a giant hanging garden, is described as a "striking landmark in a city that is generally regarded as snobbish, reserved and insecure. The cheese-wedge buildings, which are supported on thick slabs and stand in stark contrast to their traditional surroundings, are described as "a major step forward in reclaiming the cultural heritage of Scotland's capital". But its contents are more down-to-earth.

level1: The British Geological Survey has embarked on a journey to trace the steps astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1706-1742) took to determine magnetic north, while charting his voyages on the warship Paramore. The journey is titled 'Retracing Halley's Voyage' and has been funded by the Royal Society. The project will include a survey of the British Isles, the Netherlands, and the Netherlands East Indies. The British Geological Survey's researcher, Toby Clark, says it was Halley's attempt in his lifetime to use calculations made by an astronomer to chart the 'variations of the compass'. This is now known as 'declination'. Halley claimed to have realised it was caused by the earth's magnetic field, and therefore magnetic north would not always be the same north. It is possible to calculate the declination using a few mathematical techniques. Calculations are relatively straightforward: a number is written on the side of the compass rod and the angle is dependant on the strength of the magnetic field in a particular region. For instance, in the Netherlands, declination is calculated based on the speed of the magnetic pole, so that a speed of 10 nautical miles per hour can produce a declination of 2.5 degrees. By measuring the force of an earth magnetic field, Clark and his team
level2_fkg: When the seagoing astrologer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) came on his first schooner in 1607, the ship became known as Paramore. But it was Halley's 1711 voyage of the Paramore that made it one of the most important navigational landmarks in history. Halley mapped the declination of the earth's compass. The degree between magnetic north and true geographical north was known as declination. Halley used his sea voyages to establish the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. For every compass bearing of the seagoing vessel, Halley measured the declination. His records are now kept in a museum in Great Britain and, more recently, at the National Archives in Washington DC. For the project, Toby Clark has been working with colleagues at the British Geological Survey. "In the early days, ships like Paramore had little guidance," Clark said. "So we use what we have, and use a technique called "declination drift". This translates into a drift of magnetic north around the globe. The drift is caused by a change in the magnetic field of the Earth, or, in scientific terms, magnetic dipole. While the exact distance between the pole and declination drift is hard to say, Clark said, there are three main factors to take into account: the distance from the centre of the Earth'
level2_cefr: Dr Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is retracing the steps of a 17th century mariner who charted the compass variations.
level3_fkg: Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742), astronomer and mathematician, was not the first to discover the difference between true north and magnetic north. His father, Sir Edwin Halley, was an astronomer and the first British king to be astounded by Halley's findings. But in the era before GPS and satellites, he was left completely alone. To find out what he had observed, researchers at the British Geological Survey are working on a project to help solve the mystery. The British government are supporting Clark's quest to find what he has discovered, which is "suggesting" that Halley himself might have been on to something if his calculations were correct. For his work, Clark is using data that's 2,000 years old. The British Geological Survey has collected data on compass variations since 1707, when Halley was an officer on the warship Paramore, named after Halley's astrological wife. Clark will find out whether Halley's calculations had any impact on our understanding of true north, and what effects a change in the earth's magnetic field might have on it. "It turns out that the only thing that makes it different is that the earth's magnetosphere has grown. The Earth's magnetosphere grew more massive when it was struck by the comet, so when it had run away
level3_cefr: Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is best known for the comet that bears his name. Yet one of his greatest accomplishments in the eyes of his contemporaries was to chart using calculations made on his sea voyages on the warship Paramore the 'variations of the compass'. These variations are now known as 'declination' that is the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north.
level4_fkg: Dr Toby Clark is the senior scientist at the British Geological Survey who will go through the sands of the British Isles to find how astronomer Sir Edmund Halley knew.
level4_cefr: The British Geological Survey has been following a track supposedly tracing the voyages of Sir Edmund Halley on his warship Paramore. This is in what researchers are claiming is the first real attempt to trace the trajectory of one of the world's greatest navigators. Sir Edmund Halley, a 16th century astronomer, is best known for his comet, which now flies past Earth every five years. But what makes him a truly remarkable astronomer was that in 1678 he made his first attempt to chart declination, the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north, using calculations made on his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. The angle between magnetic north and true geographical north has been measured from the coast of the Continent, and the angle in this way between magnetic north and true geographical north is known as declination. Dr Toby Clark, of the British Geological Survey, is carrying out research at a number of places around the world to try and make the measurements he made on the warship and find out the exact locations that Halley visited, and also the degree of declination that they had. "Toby has a fantastic amount of experience and his interest in Halley is not limited to the scientific aspects," explains Ahuja. He says that to get a better understanding of what Sir Edmund Halley actually did, he has to take

level1: A. THAILAND PHILIPPINES PHILIPPINES Philippini is a country where the word ‘hotel’ has to be substituted with ’camp’, referring to the gypsy inn or caravan park where you can experience a spartan life with all the comforts of a modern five-star hotel, but in an inexplicably tranquil setting. This remote hotel sits at the edge of a small village in the hills and is a combination of English country-house tranquillity with Thai symbolism. The Ghanerao family have lived there for 400 years and today Sajjan Singh and his wife have opened their home to paying guests. The facilities are basic with hot water arriving by bucket but the spartan aspects of life at Ghanerao just add to its appeal. B. NEW ZEALAND HERMITAGE HOTEL MOUNT COOK One of my favourite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand’s South Island which I came across by chance when I was climbing. The name is apt as the building is perched on the ridge, 900 feet above sea level, surrounded by mountains and surrounded by luscious farmland. Rooms are modestly furnished and feature an opulent fireplace but there are no luxuries on offer here.

level1: My journey to achieve the Seven Summits began late in life. I was 32 when I did them. I knew it was a big goal, but I knew at the time that it took more determination than I thought possible. I made it to Mt. Everest Asia (8848m) in 1998 on a solo climbing expedition with Dougal Haston. The trek began in Lukla, the capital of Kazakhstan. It took us about four weeks to reach the mountain’s summit. The journey was long and not too hard on the body. I remember being totally surrounded by ice and snow, but I got plenty of exercise by ice climbing on my knees. The descent through the frozen mountains was very cold and snowy. The following day, the route to the summit was a much easier one, but the ice was still thick in places and I did not really feel that I was going to make it. At the summit, we all agreed that that was a big achievement, as we’d reached the world’s highest point on each continent. A. Everest Asia (8848m) On the final summit summit day, I found myself standing in the summit meadow. It was magical to me. My head was filled with ideas, and it seemed like a dream came true. I had been dreaming about getting to the top since I was 16, a dream I still enjoy today. B. Mount Everest
level2_fkg: Foreword To Seven Up is an interview with Doug Scott, who climbs the Seven Summits. He tells the reader about his journeys to the top of each of the seven peaks, his relationships with the other climbers, his experiences at the summit and the spiritual mystical feelings that he has experienced in doing this.
level2_cefr: As we reached the top of Mt. Everest we began a meditative ritual. Dave Clark had been with us since base camp and had told us that he was going to give Dave the bag that we slept in in order to save it being filled with oxygen. When we saw Dave with Daves bag we all fell silent as we felt that something was not right with the way he was sleeping. In the end we agreed that Dave should give the bag to Dave with the idea that it may save it being filled with oxygen. The meditative ritual was carried out in a number of ways. The first was that Dave and I were sitting on the rock and then a large boulder on top of us was pushed over. This rock has a crack and Dave had slipped when the rock broke. After this we decided that we would sit on the boulder. We walked up on the rock and waited for an ice axe to strike us over the ice. The axe made a crack on the rock, and since the ice axe was in contact with the rock we moved the ice axe so that it was pointing in the right direction. We moved the ice axe over the crack and we stood in front of Dave and he leaned into it. After this he took the ice axe, and after a little bit he pulled the ice axe
level3_fkg: This is a summary of Doug Scott's story of climbing the seven highest peaks on each continent. He begins with his first attempt on Mt. Everest, his second attempt on Lhotse, and finally his seventh summit, Mt. Kilimanjaro. He was 69 years old at the time.
level3_cefr: A. Mt. Everest Asia (8848m) We were in a snow cave 91m below the summit when my climbing partner Dougal Haston began a conversation with Dave Clark our Equipment Officer about the relative merits of various sleeping bags. I thought this was strange as only Dougal and I were present. Putting this down to oxygen deprivation, I then found myself talking to my feet. B. Denali Australasia (9178m) Dougal and I were on the edge of the ice wall in Nepal for two weeks in June. I was climbing the North Ridge and when I saw Dougal climbing, I just shook my head. I looked at him in the eye and said something like a “I think this is nonsense”. He looked up at me and said “Oh! a sleight of hand? Don’t touch my face?” I thought this was bizarre, and we started heading down. On the return trip, we were rescued by Sherpas at about 9,000m. As we began to descend, I asked Dougal how he could feel his feet at such a high altitude. He replied that he was “shivering and shaking so badly” that his feet were numb. He said he felt his feet in his pocket, but when we had recovered he said that they were just resting. C. Denali Austral
level4_fkg: One day I am climbing to the summit of Mount Everest. Then I see this enigmatic, white figure and my mind gets fuzzy and my feet say "Hey! :)" ; I ask if I should climb any of these peaks because :) ; I find out that these peaks are named after the continents that are found in the Himalaya. They are: America (8963m), Asia (8848m), Europe (9346m), Africa (8944m), South America (8942m) and South America (8943m). ; On the way to Mount Everest I felt like I wanted to climb all the peaks, but my mind got hazy and my body did too. ; I wonder if I could do it as an adventure or maybe as a way to meet the best man in my life. ; I was amazed and speechless when I reached the top of Mount Everest and felt the air rush through my nose, and my body was screaming with so much oxygen. I heard that the mountain was giving out a radio signal and that the next message from the summit would be from a Russian climber who had climbed Mt. Everest. In a way it felt like the message had been delivered, but somehow, I was not expecting it, as I had no idea where I was going. ; ; I decided that

level1: When photographing people it is important to understand their perspective and get something interesting out of the shot. This may sound obvious, but people may not be aware that you are watching them. Be aware of their eyes, mouth, and body language. People's expressions can change quickly and for different reasons, depending on the situation and the people involved. Getting an eye-level shot with the right camera can be easier said than done. A good vantage point may be to try to look into the frame and then photograph from behind. The closer your subject is to the camera, the more likely your eye level shot will be. If people are not looking at the camera, the face may be in focus, but not in the right angle. If the subject is very distracting, try to hide them with a distracting object. For example, if you are taking a portrait of someone close up, try to make sure the background is in the foreground. A camera that sits behind the subject may not be able to see the subject's face, and may look even worse than the one in the foreground. 1. Know that they are not posed. 2. Do not pose people who are not engaged in a conversation or activities. 3. Look for small actions. 4. Remind them to smile, laugh, or be pleasant. 5. Be prepared to shoot in low light (around f/8 or less) 6. Avoid pointing the camera
level2_fkg: Photographing People People are the most interesting of all subjects. A photograph with someone in it is almost always more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. Apart from the technical and artistic considerations, the photographer has to be conscious of actions, gestures and expressions. And often the presence of the camera itself can have a disastrous effect on these. A. GROUPING PEOPLE Avoid straight lines in group shots. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances and if possible on different levels. Otherwise have some of the group sitting or kneeling at the front so that you can see all the faces or raise your own viewpoint.
level2_cefr: A. GROUPING PEOPLE Avoid straight lines in group shots. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances and if possible on different levels. Otherwise have some of the group sitting or kneeling at the front so that you can see all the faces or raise your own viewpoint. B. POSING PEOPLE Be aware of stances in group shots. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances and if possible on different levels. Otherwise, have some of the group sitting or kneeling at the front so that you can see all the faces or raise your own viewpoint. C. TAKEN AS AN INDIVIDUAL If possible, ask people to stand at different angles and distances so that you can see all the faces or raise your own viewpoint. D. EVENING PEOPLE If possible ask people to stand at different angles and distances so that you can see all the faces or raise your own viewpoint. A person in a sunset or sunset light will appear out of focus in a photograph. You can reduce this effect by having people stand at different angles and distances and if possible on different levels. You can even take photos of people standing with their backs to you instead of facing away from you. E. ACTING IN ACTION People tend to be more expressive when they are in movement. If you photograph people standing still you are likely to make them seem still or pose them
level3_fkg: People are the most interesting of all subjects. A photograph with someone in it is almost always more compelling than the same shot without the human interest.
