And often, the presence of the camera itself can have a disastrous effect on these. A. GROUPING PEOPLE Avoid straight lines in group shots. level3_cefr: A. LOCKING PEOPLE In portrait shots try to position the subject in the frame so that his or her eyes are level with your own camera so that the face is at the centre of the photograph. To do this position the subject so that the top or bottom of his or her face is not visible and the eye, cheek, forehead and mouth are at eye level with yours, either as a face-on, portrait, or in portraiture. Try to shoot from low-angles or have the subject look at the camera so that the eye is above or below the subject. If this seems difficult, try using a smaller aperture in combination with another lens such as the 28mm or 35mm. The lens should allow for a much wider view of the subject. 2. PERSONALITY IN PEOPLE The facial expressions of people are largely determined by their personality. For example, if a person is a joker you want the viewer to see a sense of humour in the photograph and a sense of enjoyment in the situation being captured. For this reason facial expressions are the subject of most photographs. To create the best portrait of a subject try to show his or her real character. If possible try to photograph people while they are interacting and talking with each other. By observing these interactions you can get a feel of the person and how they are feeling and reacting to you and your

level1: As she leaves the hotel, Sue Brown comments on the receptionist’s lack of customer service: ‘Turns out this is a common fault. I’ve seen it at other hotels where receptionists have not recognised guests if there’s only one of them present. The problem is that when you get it wrong, you end up telling the hotel something it didn’t realise it needed to do. That’s why I’m here today,’ she says.
level2_fkg: The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel, not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring.
level2_cefr: The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judged hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel. Not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring. ‘Hasn’t even acknowledged us’ Sue Brown says out of the corner of her mouth. ‘Very poor’ It is a classic arrival-phase error and one that Sue has encountered scores of times in her 11 years as an inspector. It takes a while to recollect that she has already spoken to us three times already. Suddenly, she realises that she is speaking to somebody else. She then stops and remembers the details of the booking made by Christopher Middleton and Sue Brown. The Globe Hotel manager is delighted and applauds Sue Brown. The hotel’s owner and a manager who hasn’t been to inspect it for five years asks Sue to leave. But Sue goes back. She leaves in the silence of the reception area. Her report and a summary of the evening’s events will be shared in January.
level3_fkg: The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel. Not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring. ‘Hasn’t even acknowledged us' Sue Brown says out of the corner of her mouth. ‘Very poor.’ It is a classic arrival-phase error and one that Sue has encountered scores of times in her 11 years as an inspector.
level3_cefr: “The first thing that I do as a hotel inspector is look at how well your receptionist greets customers – especially if you are not aware of your guests’ identities,” says Sue. ‘And when you do know a guest’s identity, you should acknowledge them’. If you are unable to do so, it could cost your hotel a top score. Sue’s comments suggest they will not only encourage the Globe to take responsibility, but will also help make it easier for her to do her job.
level4_fkg: The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judged hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel, not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring. ‘Hasn’t even acknowledged us.’ Sue Brown says out of the corner of her mouth. ‘Very poor.’ It is a classic arrival-phase error and one that Sue has encountered scores of times in her 11 years as an inspector. This is the only one she had not noticed, since she had arrived an hour earlier. Sue and Christopher were waiting at the hotel, and the receptionist was still reciting room rates over the phone. Sue saw the receptionist’s face when Christopher drew close, but couldn’t say a word. ‘Very poor,’ Sue said. ‘I had to walk up to my car.’

level1: As we approach another round of job interviews and personal vetting, handwriting has come a long way. Graphology is a legitimate science, a sliver of the ancient art of finger painting. But it doesn’t seem to be picking up much steam in the United States, where its use seems to be growing. Researching handwriting patterns has been around for centuries and can be used to help doctors with heart problems, diagnose cancer, and predict behavior. The technique can also help predict a person’s personality. In the past couple of years it has become more common for employers to ask for a sample of someone’s handwriting in addition to their resume. It’s not yet clear whether Americans are ready to embrace the era of pen-and-paper assessments, but when it is, it can be a valuable tool. Researchers are looking into how handwriting, or Graphology, can be used for personal guidance, occupational guidance, and even in the context of job interviews. The Journal of Handwriting Analysis, for example, is using handwriting samples to look at job candidates with a range of personality issues and to see what they think of them. Even the National Institute of Health has joined in. In May, a US federal court allowed the use of Graphology in personal counseling and job assessment. However, the US Supreme Court quashed the practice.
level2_fkg: The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. The study of handwriting to reveal a person’s character is gaining support. If you applied for a job in some countries, you would almost certainly be asked for a sample of your handwriting. And it would be the handwriting as much as anything else that would determine your suitability for the job. Handwriting analysis or graphology is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. Researchers say it can be a useful tool in indicating certain illnesses such as heart disease and cancer and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. Handwriting analysis is increasingly being used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews.

level1: Volunteer tourism is a form of 'gap year' tourism. Some say that it is a great way to experience a new culture, but most people believe that it is not worth the cost. Some say that it is a time in their life, but there may be better ways. Others say it is a waste of money.
level2_fkg: Four academic writers discuss the topic of international voluntary work. A. It is hard to argue that the actual contribution to development amounts to a great deal directly. Whilst volunteer tourists can get involved in building homes or schools, they have usually paid a significant fee for the opportunity to be involved in this work: money that if donated to a local community directly could potentially pay for a greater amount of labour than the individual volunteer could ever hope to provide. This is especially so in the case of gap years in which the level of technical skill or professional experience required of volunteers is negligible.
level2_cefr: Volunteer tourism is an idea that seems to have caught on in recent years. Four academic writers discuss the topic. The first writer, David Laidlaw, says that voluntary tourism is a "good idea, which should be encouraged". The second, Jill Gossett, says that "voluntary tourism is bad, which should be discouraged".

level1: It is the University Museum of Classical Archaeology. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is housed in a purpose-built gallery with excellent natural light. The advantages of plaster casts are many: groups of sculptures originally set up together but now split between various museums all over Europe can be viewed together as originally intended.
level2_fkg: The University Museum of Classical Archaeology. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world, comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is housed in a purpose-built gallery with excellent natural light. The advantages of plaster casts are many: groups of sculptures originally set up together but now split between various museums all over Europe can be viewed together as originally intended.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology The University Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is housed in a purpose-built gallery with excellent natural light. The advantages of plaster casts are many: groups of sculptures originally set up together but now split between various museums all over Europe can be viewed together as originally intended.

level1: It comes naturally. Smiling was a necessary part of the job dealing with customers - but when I look back on the experience now I can see that I was actually doing the opposite - desperately covering up for my own inadequacies my incompetence. So next time you feel unsure about the value of your kindness and its role in your life, ask yourself the following question. Do you often say things to cover up your lack of self-confidence?
level2_fkg: Are you too nice for your own good? When I first worked as a waitress in a restaurant, I soon learnt that the best way to get myself out of trouble was to smile sweetly at every possible opportunity. 'I'm so sorry' I beamed when I dropped the plate on the floor and it smashed into smithereens. 'There must have been a misunderstanding. I'll sort it out straight away' I smiled after I served chicken Kiev to a strict vegetarian. It came naturally. Smiling was a necessary part of the job dealing with customers - but when I look back at the experience now, I can see that what I was actually doing was desperately covering up for my own inadequacies, my incompetence.

level1: The plane's crew made sure they were at the right altitude as the 13 students prepared to enter into a state of weightlessness. Each took a spot at the back of the white tunnel and looked at the ceiling. Then they put their hands in their pockets and rubbed their necks and hands. Each thought briefly about their next move. After about a minute the group split into two groups, some for weightlessness and some to carry out experiments under normal gravity. One group arranged a balloon with a length of thread through it that was tied to a support beam while the other had its end wrapped around its feet. Then the balloon bobbed up and down on a spring and dropped to the floor. The scientists watched them, their eyes getting more and more crinkled as they struggled to keep their balance. They realised that if they tried to lift off from their standing positions, they would immediately fall to the ground. This is something the team had known for years, and was sure they had discovered long before the experiment. They had been trained to tether themselves to each other. The rest of the students were held in a capsule where they would feel nothing. The first group carried out experiments on how a mass can become heavier in the absence of gravity and how gravity could affect the brain when it moves. A colleague helped one of the groups to build a balloon and they were able
level2_fkg: The young scientists took a deep breath, held it for a moment, then sat with the tense, limbs stiffened. The pilot said he was sorry for the delay. He had just finished a flight from a nearby airfield. The aircraft had been converted into a weightless experiment where they would use lasers to study the waves of energy the universe is made up of. “We ain’t gonna die,” said the young physicist who was testing the effects of the new technology, using a hammer to knock against the walls of the tunnel. “And you get smacked in the face,” said the chubby American who had been holding the glass of cold water. The scientists were aiming to find out what happens to a body after it has been in the air for a couple of seconds and to what degree the body absorbs the energy. The first wave of energy — known as Newtonian — strikes at just the right moment, and by the end of the experiment they would have collected a wealth of data. “It’s an excellent exercise for teaching people that the force of gravity causes things, but that it doesn’t cause them,” said one scientist. “It’s just one more way of doing things.” “It’s just great to have all that data out there,” said one. “
level2_cefr: The 13 students were in the capsule, in their own space, and when the ship reached an altitude of 15,000 feet – the lowest point in the world – they were thrown into a room with no gravity. They had three hours to prove that their theory about the law of gravity was correct or explain why the universe was full of holes. Their experiments had turned out brilliantly. The students had become light years ahead of their fellow researchers. By the end, their scientists would know whether the laws of gravity had been proven correct or wrong, proving that the universe is full of holes.
level3_fkg: The scientists had been given a few hours to experiment. They had hoped to use the atmosphere of weightlessness to test their theories. They had been taught that their bodies remained in the gravity of Earth but in weightlessness their bodies became a vacuum. Despite this, a few managed to talk. He said he had learned that weightlessness increases the speed of thought and increases IQ. He said the most surprising thing about the flight was the fact that they had to stay still for up to two hours. Tom Mumford had been travelling with science journalism students for three years to the American University of Pennsylvania in Pennsylvania, USA, in an effort to help young people take an interest in science. The students would be in weightlessness for up to eight hours, with a half-hour break before returning to Earth. The students are studying how gravity affects our brains. They were in weightlessness for eight hours and will have to stay in the vacuum for eight hours. A computer explains what will happen if they stay in a vacuum for longer than that. As a normal human would, they will fall back into Earth’s gravity and when they rise again, they will feel like they are flying. During this time, gravity acts like a constant refuelling tank. It keeps us from losing energy. It keeps us from wasting calories. The computer explains how gravity affects our nervous system and muscles. It explains
level3_cefr: The students’ experiments sounded like a blast from the past. They were testing the theory that scientists have for centuries that gravity exists in this world, but that it has nothing to do with space. It was just another flight.
level4_fkg: It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964 a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. But appearances were deceptive and the 13 students from Europe and America who boarded were in for the flight of their lives. Inside it had become a long white tunnel. There were almost no windows but it was eerily illuminated by lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats had been ripped out apart from a few at the back where the pale-faced budding scientists took their places with the air of condemned men.

level1: The day I drew Picasso Richard Cork recalls how, as an 8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van, he came face-to-face with one of the most revered artists of the century. Even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbour, Picasso was instantly recognisable. I was an I8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van. Having run out of money I found a boat-painting job on the waterfront. But I spent much of the time drawing and was lucky enough to be carrying an ample sketchbook when my encounter with the octogenarian artist took place. "I was an I8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van. Having run out of money, I found a boat-painting job on the waterfront. But I spent much of the time drawing and was lucky enough to be carrying an ample sketchbook when my encounter with the octogenarian artist took place."
level2_fkg: After working as a boat-painting job on the Cannes waterfront Richard Cork met the famed artist Picasso on his last day in France when he was an 8-year-old student.
level2_cefr: Richard Cork, 78, has long been fascinated by Picasso. One of his favourite paintings is a young woman in a pink bikini — and he remembers watching him as a teenager eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes. Cork recalls that, even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbour, Picasso was instantly recognisable. i he took his seat at his table, he began to paint. I had been sketching most of my day before, when I had started my boat-painting job. A little while later, he stopped eating, and he stared across the water at me, smiling and laughing, for a moment or two. He remained gazing at me as long as I could draw. I have been drawing Picasso ever since. I have never forgotten him.

He told the BBC: "Seeing him was an unexpected revelation. At first, I was quite daunted but he was instantly recognisable."

level1: The plight of advertising in the doldrums can be traced to the way media and marketing has resisted the whirlwind of accelerated economic change. The fact is that advertisers have failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. Advertising’s problems are more fundamental. Instead of seeing consumers as indivisible chunks of the human population, marketers have interpreted them as homogeneous audiences to be targeted and marketed to. The result has been an increase in the number of targeted audiences and, at the same time, a fall in the share of total revenues going to advertising and related media spend. The decline is worldwide and is reflected in the percentage of media-sales dollars in print ads, which are now up 13 percent from 1989 when a recession began to bite. According to a recent report by The Association of National Advertisers, the number of advertising dollars being spent by media in 1990 was 92 percent of total media-sales dollars. At the same time, the percentage of media ads spent on TV ads declined 20 percent. It is no accident that TV ads tend to be more expensive than print ads, but in the interest of conservatism, advertisers seem to have taken the view that mass markets and mass media are the key to success. Yet if you look at the numbers, mass markets are more efficient than individual markets, and individual markets are more focused. As a result, advertising
level2_fkg: This story was originally published in "The New Yorker," February 7, 1990. In 1988, the "global recession" hit advertising hard and nearly killed it, said Robert Connelly, a managing director of the advertising agency A&E Networks. Yet even though "advertising was in the doldrums," Mr. Connelly believed that "the problem had less to do with the recession and more to do with advertising's inability to match the pace of economic change." "Mass marketing, at least as we understand it, is a way to reach the vast majority of the market," he said. But by the 1990s, it was hardly universal. For example, most Americans buy homes with a lot less mortgage money. They don't go on vacations very often. They don't spend any time out in nature. They're not very engaged in sports; they aren't as interested in politics; they don't spend a lot of money on entertainment and other recreational pursuits. They are more likely to shop with credit cards than debit cards." Eventually, the advertising industry became overwhelmed by the variety of media. It's no longer easy for firms to evaluate the relative effectiveness of all the media that serve their target markets. And then, as the recession hit, it was the media that were hardest hit. The cyclical nature of advertising meant that advertisers used the same budget for
level2_cefr: With all the talk of mass marketing, it remains a very popular idea. But in the new world of personalisation, mass marketing hasn't worked so well.
level3_fkg: On the other hand, as a result of the explosion of television, radio, and cellular phones, people are more dispersed and people don't buy products from companies they don't know well. In the course of their tumultuous interactions, people prefer to receive advertising from people they feel know their business. People are more selective in their choice of companies, and those companies tend to market in more specific ways, to particular niches. "It has been a hit and miss for mass marketing," says Tom Greenfield, director of the Global Media Institute at the Harvard Business School. "Because, as the business world has gotten more complicated, it has become difficult for mass markets to satisfy consumers' wants and needs." And it's true for advertising. If the goal of advertising is to create mass appeal, it's an expensive proposition. Some firms have spent upwards of $200 million on TV ads per year, per market. That's $1.25 per consumer. But when a consumer watches only a few seconds of commercials, the ad probably makes him or her want to buy a product that only a select few will actually buy, says Greenfield. "There has to be something special about the commercial that would persuade them to buy."
level3_cefr: An advertising campaign featuring a song from the Beatles featuring the words "If you want to be successful...you've got to be in the pop world" could hardly fail to appeal to the young, hip, urban youth culture of the 1980s, according to David E. Keen, an advertising critic and author of the book, The New Mass Market: The New Face of the Masses (Penguin, 1991). But the campaign failed to hit an audience who, for many reasons, didn't respond to it. And the age-old problem is being highlighted: the lack of diversity in the mass audience, which includes both young consumers and older, more mature, tech-savvy audiences. "There is no excuse for not making any effort to reach out to these audiences and [the recession] has only made this worse," writes Keen. The failure of advertisers to reach out to these audiences has resulted in their feigned interest in the "culture" and thus in losing some market share to non-consumers. The mass market has grown too big, too complex, and the advertising industry is overcomplicated. Its ad agencies, publishers, media buyers, and marketing specialists are constantly searching for new targets. But the mass audience has been so broad that it's difficult to identify even a small number of target markets. The key is the hegemony of the mass market and the lack of
level4_fkg: Hit and miss of mass marketing The advertising industry has been struggling to keep up with economic changes for a long time now. That means that it has often marketed to a large number of people, but these campaigns have rarely targeted minority audiences.
level4_cefr: The Hit and miss of mass marketing AS ALMOST everyone knows advertising is in the doldrums. It isn't just the recession. Advertising started to plummet early in 1989 before the recession really began to bite. Advertising's problems are more fundamental and the decline is worldwide. The unhappy truth is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. As brands and media have proliferated, target markets have fragmented. Even campaigns for major brands ought to be targeted at minority audiences but they rarely are.

level1: The Christmas before last I turned 37 and realised that time was running out if I wanted to resurrect a career in journalism - which I believed had been washed down the plug-hole... the technological plug-hole. A quick glance at my curriculum vitae showed that I was shamefully stuck in the 1980s when a piece of carbon wedged in between several sheets of paper in a typewriter was the state of the art. I started on Google Chrome, installed a virtual desktop and set to work. There was no sign of the traditional laptop – I was in the middle of a two-person interview with a colleague, and it didn’t help that we lived in a rural area. On the first day, I put together a basic blog on the topics I’d found myself writing about. I’d also set up a new WordPress blog, which had just won a Blogger Award, and it’s already in full swing. Google docs isn’t all that complicated, but at first it seemed daunting to create it. But once I got the hang of it, I found it much easier than I thought. Since I’d been working full-time, the most important thing about getting started was having a home office. My husband stayed at home as a web designer, and the kids have a part-time school run, so I could
level2_fkg: The Christmas before last I turned 37 and realised that time was running out if I wanted to resurrect a career in journalism - which I believed had been washed down the plug-hole... the technological plug-hole. A quick glance at my curriculum vitae showed that I was shamefully stuck in the 1980s when a piece of carbon wedged in between several sheets of paper in a typewriter was the state of the art. I rushed out to buy a pair of new-fangled, state-of-the-art computers, thinking that I would be able to use them for what I had been doing for 20 years: the writing of books and magazine articles for newspapers, magazines and journals. As soon as I got them home, I took them apart and began to look for a place for them, and decided I needed a small office and a desk and a chair – all the stuff that a journalist uses in a professional office. A coffee table was the obvious choice, as it would be convenient, with room to type and write. A coffee table that would double as a desk wasn't important, as I have a large desk in my bedroom, and I wasn't planning on concentrating on just one part of the job. There would have to be enough room to do a lot of things. So I looked for a flat that would be
level2_cefr: The Christmas before last I turned 37 and realised that time was running out if I wanted to resurrect a career in journalism - which I believed had been washed down the plug-hole. A quick glance at my curriculum vitae showed that I was shamefully stuck in the 1980s when a piece of carbon wedged in between several sheets of paper in a typewriter was the state of the art.
level3_fkg: Georgina McGuiness had taken a long career break from journalism and she felt out of touch with the changes brought about by technology. She recounts here how she transformed the family home into an efficient workplace.
level3_cefr: We used to plug in the phone and type up our articles by hand, but technology has radically changed and it is now possible to write and edit articles by the click of a mouse, with a plethora of electronic gadgets at our fingertips. I'd had a long career break since 2000 and after returning from South America I was feeling that I was out of touch with technological developments. I found myself in a bit of a quandary. Having had to leave journalism for a while, I was concerned that I was going to get stranded by the fast pace of technology. I also felt out of touch with how changes in the workplace had affected my working life. My husband works in a construction business and I was able to work from home and the only distraction was my children. I decided to transform our living room into an office, which will now be transformed into a freelance writing room. To do this I had to sell everything I didn't need or use any more and replace it with lots of modern gadgets, as well as cutting down on my electricity bill. In addition to that, I had to install a broadband connection, which will enable me to access the Internet whenever and wherever I need to from anywhere in the world. The kitchen table which was originally used as a dining table is now used as a desk. We now use it to listen to music and write. It's even
level4_fkg: Georgina McGuiness (born 1972) is a British journalist. She is one of the earliest adopters of the Internet, which has given her an opportunity to do what she likes in her home. She enjoys taking part in various projects for various people in her community, including a re-opening of a heritage school to help older people learn to read.
level4_cefr: I had taken a long career break from journalism and I felt out of touch with the changes brought about by technology. But I had to find a way to plug in the home. I had a desk at home, which I made into a desk with computer facilities. I set about organising my space in the best way possible. I bought some comfortable chair to sit in, gave the kitchen an air of sophistication, then built an office desk in the lounge. I also fitted shelves on either side of the room for office equipment and a shelf over the kitchen sink for supplies. I took my books and desk furniture to the carpentry workshops to get them up to scratch. The building works took about five days. We fitted the cupboards with drawers and filing cabinets. It is still a work in progress, but I have been able to turn the desk into a home office. As a result, I can get all my writing done on my laptop in the same time as I can write my email. As the years pass, I think it has become quite a useful part of the family home.

level1: POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER, the peacocks that roam free within Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire expose their magnificent trains to the critical and often disdainful gaze of the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day: how in this competitive world where nature, as Tennyson said - is red in tooth and claw could birds have evolved such an obvious extravagance? How do they get away with it?
level2_fkg: When there are peacocks walking their way through the park’s woods, they are not tempted by the food laying eggs from the hens. But there are male peacocks that strut their stuff in a different, more imposing fashion: the strutting peacocks aspire to become kings, and the male peacocks at Whipsnade have, for centuries, sought to become more than a few pecks from a few hens. It was then that Charles Darwin wondered whether there might be something in nature’s evolutionary strategy to help the female peacock become a queen, if she needed a little extra help to achieve this.
level2_cefr: Peacocks in the wild are not usually so large. They have a thin, wiry frame and are fairly large birds by the standards of the domestic peacock.
level3_fkg: Marion Petrie and her colleagues of the Open University are now exploiting the quasi-wild conditions of Whipsnade to try a century after Darwin’s death to settle the matter.
level3_cefr: One would be hard pressed to find a bird in the animal kingdom that would dress as magnificently as the peacock. The story begins, however, with a peacock squawking his displeasure at the hens. A peacock’s squawking is often thought to be related to his sexual aggression - his urge to show off to attract a mate. The bird’s tail feathers are so long that some peacocks have even shown off their sexual dimorphism - which allows both male and female to display their plumage in different colors. Marion Petrie is studying how birds behave in this situation to try to answer Darwin’s famous question, but is unable to find evidence. “We don’t know why it happens or how it varies between individuals. The hens are probably more important to the peacock than he is. They have the ability to judge who is a male and who is a female and if the female peacock shows signs of aggression, she could be forced to choose another male or lose out on breeding opportunity,” Marion Petrie, a zoologist at the Open University, told BBC News. The peacocks were kept in captivity for 15 years while Marion Petrie bred and studied them. Her findings are not conclusive. “The hens
level4_fkg: In Darwin’s world a peacock was the ultimate jerk. He thought his little friends might just be being playful when he turned around in his grave. But while peacocks are social butterflies in the pecking order and are found in some of the oldest nature reserves in the world – like Whipsnade – their social organization has long remained a mystery, with some arguing that peacocks spend too much time mowing their grass, others arguing that they should be left to their own devices. What he found to be the best way to test this was to observe peacocks in the semi-wild conditions of Whipsnade. There, the peacocks can’t run up and down trees. The hens just peck away the grass under the peacocks’ noses and head. Peacocks don’t have to hide their plumage. They can walk around the peacock park at their leisure, and the birds there get plenty of sunlight and water. Peacocks, Petrie and her colleagues have found, have adapted to the conditions. They can fly at low speeds, even with wings full of feathers, without losing any height. The hens can keep their tails feathered, and peacocks keep their heads down. The peacocks’ elong
level4_cefr: Peacocks do not usually carry long and furious tails, but there are certain conditions when peacocks are in flight that favour the presence of a crest. In the late Spring and early Summer peacocks take up residence at Whipsnade, where they are given food such as chicks and insects in boxes or buckets of water. Then they spread their wings in the mid-summer, and display their magnificent and often disdainful crests as they strut their stuff. It is not only the peacocks’ crests that attract attention in the skies: all birds have a single distinctive feather on the top of their head. The peacock crest has now been voted as one of the 100 Most Beautiful Birds in the World.

level1: There’s an eerie thing about art—as it is so much a part of our DNA—that it’s just as strange that so few scientists have devoted time to explaining what makes our brains work the way they do. At one time, brain researchers said their work would only answer questions about how the brain works. But today, a group of researchers led by Mark Levitan of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says they might have found a clue. Levitan, who studied the brains of five groups of scientists studying different parts of the brain, says he found two key clues. One was the fact that the brains of those subjects differed in the same way each person’s brain works. That’s because their brains are built differently: each person’s is built for its job. Scientists were working on the idea of a “brain hierarchy” in which the brains of a person at the top, and a person at the bottom, are organized according to the importance of specific tasks. The researchers then sequenced their brains and found a “brain hierarchy” in which both brains made similar decisions about what tasks needed to be done, depending on the priorities of the situation. They found a similar hierarchy with a brain hierarchy for reasoning about which tasks were important and which weren’t, but they couldn’t determine why. In most cases, they
level2_fkg: An excellent story with very interesting ideas! In just seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't had time to develop any differences: genetically, we're still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale, whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. Our biological history implies that our physical capacity for making art (whatever changes were needed in the human physique, brain and sense organs) and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to just a tiny fraction of our genes. That's a large burden to place on a relative handful of genes. Thanks for this informative article.

level1: Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston were on a quest to climb in Greenland and record their story in their new book. Earlier this year, the pair teamed up for the first time. Chris Bonnington was best known for climbing the summit of Everest in 1985. He now runs Everest Rescue Expeditions and Mountain Rescue in the UK and has written many books including Quest for Adventure and Everest the Hard Way. Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, began his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first to circumnavigate the world singlehanded in his yacht Sunhaili. He broke the transatlantic record, taking 10 days to reach the Lizard from New York. The two teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, recording the trip in their new book Sea Ice and Rock. Bonnington and Knox-Johnston were on a quest to climb, sail and cycle in Greenland. Then the pair teamed up to climb and sail in Greenland.

The pair teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, recording the trip in their new book: Sea Ice and Rock.

level1: 'I wish we could have brought the plane' said Lenina looking up with dislike at the blank rock face. 'I hate walking. And you feel so small when you're on the ground at the bottom of a hill.' They walked along for a time in the shadow of the rock turned a corner and there, in a dry channel worn away by the water in former times was the way up. They climbed. It was a very steep path that went from side to side of the channel. Sometimes the drums were almost silent at others they seemed to be beating only just round the corner. They reached the top where the path turned round to the other side of the channel and led to the valley floor. They climbed. It was a very steep path that went from side to side of the valley. Sometimes the drums were almost silent at others they seemed to be beating only just round the corner. It took them a long time. 'I wish we could have brought the plane' said Lenina looking up with dislike at the blank rock face. 'I hate walking. And you feel so small when you're on the ground at the bottom of a hill.' They walked along for a time in the shadow of the rock turned a corner and there in a dry channel worn away by the water in former times was the way down. They climbed.

level1: CHEWING GUM IS A LAST-CALL GIFT IN THE CENTURY OF AIDS – and in countries across the world, people who can’t fight the disease chewing gum might be left to fend for themselves. Among the ancients it was a means to alleviate toothache.
level2_fkg: Chewing gum culture It’s fashionable, classless and Americans chew 12 million sticks of it a day. Discover how an ancient custom became big business. Chewing gum contains fewer than ten calories per stick but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. Today’s gum is largely synthetic with added pine resins and softeners which help to hold the flavour and improve the texture. This was not always the case though. The ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like resin obtained from the bark of the mastic tree a shrub found mainly in Greece and Turkey.

level1: Nicholas Evans wrote The Horse Whisperer in 2004 to escape the financial ruin of his late-2009 blockbuster, Life and Limb, in which he had worked as a screenwriter and as an aspiring director and director. It was not an easy sell--there were over a hundred thousand copies sold and the final price was $90,000--but it was a bestseller that changed Evans's life. Its sales grew by threefold over the summer, and The Horse Whisperer is one of the biggest-selling books of all time, selling 1.2 million copies in the US alone, and has been translated into over 30 languages. Despite its fame and popularity, The Horse Whisperer does not really follow a traditional story, which is how most films follow the adolescent Jonah Hill, the son of an Italian who wants to join the US Army. In fact, Hill's story doesn't even involve horses at all. The Horse Whisperer isn't so much a film as an homage to the book, and it borrows several things from its storyline: The author is a veteran screenwriter who has produced and directed a number of major Hollywood films, including The Departed and The Good Girl, and it draws on his life experience as a screenwriter and producer. In particular, it's the story of a man who goes about
level2_fkg: Nicholas Evans was looking for a reason to write The Horse Whisperer after the film project he had been working on, Life and Limb, collapsed. He felt an urgent sense of emptiness. Nicholas Evans had been unemployed for years, and this was the only way he could earn a living. And then it happened — the opportunity came to write the book. After the first months of the year were not kind to Nicholas Evans screenwriter producer and aspiring director, the year began badly when Life and Limb, a film project he had been working on for months, fell through 'almost overnight'. Nicholas Evans' disappointment mixed with stomach-churning worry: it had been two years since he had earned any money and the promise of that film had been the only buffer between him and an increasingly irate bank manager. And now suddenly, out of nowhere, the film project he was working on was a success. The Horse Whisperer became his first book, and the first of many to come, breaking records for books about horses: it sold more than one million copies and racked up £80 million, including the profits from the film. As a first novel it became the hottest book of the year, and before it was published The Horse Whisperer was the hottest book of the year. A first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, the book became the
level2_cefr: Nicholas Evans was not the first young screenwriter to break into Hollywood with his bestselling novel The Horse Whisperer. However, it was only after years of searching for a job that he began to understand how to use his own strengths as a writer and produce his own films.
level3_fkg: This is an excerpt from The Horse Whisperer by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans. A successful first novel that has since been adapted into a motion picture the book has won seven Oscars and has now been sold over 20 million copies in 35 countries. Nicholas is the screenwriter, producer and aspiring director of Life and Limb, the 2003 British biopic about the exploits of John Wayne.
level3_cefr: Nicholas Evans has created an extraordinary story in his first book, The Horse Whisperer. In the pages of this first novel Nicholas Evans has recreated a friendship between a wretched saddleman, his nemesis, and an enigmatic oxer, a horse. He has entrusted a new pupil to his care, a young, brightly coloured, and very handsome horse that, along with some remarkable human traits, allows him to befriend this horse, which is more difficult than it sounds. At a distance, this book captures all the machinations and drama of a horse-show, showing the many ways that man can be misunderstood. The Book Description: Beginner Takes All is a novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans. It was first published by Faber and Faber in the United Kingdom in May 2012, and it has been turned into an Academy Award-winning film, with Academy Award-winning director George Clooney as its star. The Horse Whisperer became the best-selling book of the year and is now being sold for over £50m worldwide. What are the reasons behind your success? It was a very difficult book to write, because this was my first book and, as a first time novelist, I had never written a book before. There were so many people who thought that there were so
level4_fkg: There have been some tough times in Nicholas Evans life. After a long, hard struggle to make a living as a screenwriter, he now finds himself in need of a new source of income. In May, he receives a job as a writing coach at a state school in Texas. When he first arrived, he was not sure what he wanted to do with his life, but he became instantly enamored with the idea of helping children to become proficient at writing.
level4_cefr: Nicholas Evans, screenwriter, producer and aspiring director, had to fight back tears when a film project that he had been working on for months fell through 'almost overnight.' His disappointment, mingled with stomach-churning worry, had been the only buffer between him and an increasingly irate bank manager. So when he read an article in The Horse Whisperer by a British book store employee, Nicholas decided to give it a go. In doing so he found himself in a similar position. The writer was having a hard time coming to terms with the loss of a film project he had been working on for months and, more importantly, he didn't know the name of the film. It had been called Life and Limb, which he had been working on for months. He had not been able to get any financing for it, and there were no guarantees that it would ever happen. At the same time, though, he was still feeling resentful towards the film industry: it had left him with a feeling that there was something wrong with Hollywood. He couldn't give it up. But in his desperate efforts to find the money to pay back the bank, Nicholas learned a surprising bit of truth about the industry. level1: SANTA BARBARA • JANUARY 18-19, 2017 (Getty Images): The ten-act epic about the all-conquering warrior can seem never-ending but it emerges as one of the most thrilling nights of the year in Terry Hands’ staging. He has hacked great chunks from the text and offers a production that combines the glories of Marlowe’s play with an exhilarating speed and physicality. Antony Sher is in terrific form in the title role, somersaulting from the balcony, sliding down a rope head-first as he delivers a speech demanding and getting the audience’s complete attention as his eyes glint with a mad lust for power and glory. He dances in a samurai helmet as he battles his way through the forest. Tamburlaine the Great, as written by William Marlowe, is a ten-act epic with many lengthy speeches and many moments of swordplay.

level2_cefr: I was delighted when Tamburlaine the Great, Marlowe’s ten-act epic about the all-conquering warrior, emerged as one of the most thrilling nights of the year in Terry Hands’ staging. He has hacked great chunks from the text and offers a production that combines the glories of Marlowe’s play with an exhilarating speed and physicality. Antony Sher is in terrific form in the title role, somersaulting from the balcony, sliding down a rope head-first as he delivers a speech demanding and getting the audience’s complete attention as his eyes glint with a mad lust for power and glory. Unlike Shakespeare’s plays, Tamburlaine the Great doesn’t follow a conventional narrative. Instead, its ten-act length reveals more about the history of the era in which it was written. The King of Spain, the Duke of Milan, and the Duke of Lorraine all return from the Holy Land, where they were defeated, but Tamburlaine is captured and taken to France. There, his enemies plot to capture him, seduce his daughter and sell him into slavery and burn the city. The production is brilliant in its physicality. level1: The ominously named The Thin Red Line is perhaps the most overlooked war film of the last 70 years, but one that still deserves a place in the annals of cinematic history, not least because of the cult following it enjoys on DVD. As a result, much of the critical focus has been on the way the film has been remade on video by a number of directors, including this version of James Jones novel by Andrew Marton. The result is a gripping story of a unit waging a relentless but futile struggle for control of a Japanese-occupied island where nearly 2 000 American and Japanese men were killed. The original, which stars Tom Hanks, John Malkovich and Tom Wilkinson, is at times harrowingly accurate, but also painfully superficial. Thankfully, it contains two stunning sequences showing the bravery of an American soldier and of a Japanese woman on the run from the Japanese. As it turns out, these scenes are the real reason to watch the film - as the two moments in which soldiers are confronted by the Japanese narrator are all that matter. Although The Thin Red Line suffers from a slightly slow pace, the powerful visuals and excellent performances make up for it. A fascinating and well-made war movie, A Abyss is the sort of film you can watch over and
level2_fkg: The story is so-so. The actors are so-so. It is a tragic slog. It could have been better. There are moments of tender warmth and slapstick wit. But that's pretty minor compared to the brutality of what follows. It makes for an excellent introduction to film-making.
level2_cefr: On video, Nick James sees five titles. A Abyss Long before Titanic director James Cameron made this sweaty, claustrophobic Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water, this sweaty, claustrophobic Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water The banter and self-deprecating bravery of foreman Bud and his men rekindle memories of similarly laconic heroes In movies directed by Howard Hawks. Production design and special effects are hugely impressive. It's only the dialogue and characterisation that creak For all the craftsmanship which goes Into the film-making, the story itself IS strictly B-movie material. B The Thin Red Line The video release of this version of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal directed by Andrew Marton makes a fascinating counterpart to Terrence Malick's new film, which isn't available on video.
level3_fkg: It's a good-quality release, but it's not as gripping as Terrence Malick's new epic. The soundtrack and special features are excellent, but the film itself isn't very good. C Against All Odds: A thriller set in the 1950s, this is a classic war film. The action is superb and the cast is great, but the direction could be better. It was originally produced as a stage play but never got the theatrical release. Now it's on video in a good-quality transfer that captures the epic battle and the intensity of the era, and the actors are all top notch. The video release is excellent if you want to see a gripping drama in HD. D In Cold Blood: Two former Hollywood stuntmen are recruited to save a young woman from a Nazi concentration camp after a terrorist attack. The action is gripping. The actors also make excellent choices for their roles, particularly actor Richard Jenkins, who has never looked better. E The Killer Inside Me: An excellent adaptation of the novel by the same name, starring Brad Pitt, is one of the few good films of the decade. It's about a family of three women in England during the Second World War who spend a summer visiting the body of their mother. It's the sort of film that should be recommended by any serious film fan. F The Greatest
level3_cefr: It's difficult for many readers to grasp the depth of feeling and power of this film about the American invasion of France in 1944. But as this evocative reviewer writes, in this gritty yet uplifting drama replete with poignancy, you'll almost find it hard to believe what happened.
level4_fkg: It isn't a good movie, but it is very good compared to The Thin Red Line. It is also better than The Thin Red Line in terms of how it tells the story. It is a retelling of the true events, with the added interest that the story is told as a series of conversations between two men, each in turn telling the other what he thinks.
level4_cefr: Films on video Film critic Nick James reviews some recent releases A Abyss Long before Titanic director James Cameron made this sweaty claustrophobic Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water The banter and self-deprecating bravery of foreman Bud and his men rekindle memories of similarly laconic heroes in movies directed by Howard Hawks. Production design and special effects are hugely impressive. It's only the dialogue and characterisation that creak For all the craftsmanship which goes into the film-making, the story itself IS strictly B-movie material. B The Thin Red Line The video release of this version of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal directed by Andrew Marton makes a fascinating counterpart to Terrence Malick's new film.

level1: The era of the newspaper in print may not be over in the next five years, writes Peter Preston. At the moment, all of this is happening in the UK, although the trend towards the demise of the British press seems to be moving in the opposite direction from the rest of the world. According to statistics from the British Newspaper Association, the UK now has the smallest circulation of any other country in the world. The proportion of adult readers aged 18-49 who still read newspapers had not increased since 2007, while that for all of Asia-Pacific dropped from a high of 31% to 22% in the same period. This is a striking contrast with previous figures. In the UK, over half (54%) of those aged under 18 read a newspaper every month, compared with nearly half (41%) among those aged 50 and over.
level2_fkg: This is a short story about a journalist who is making the case that the end of print may take some time. Clearly, the digital age is here. But what does this mean for newspapers? Is it a good thing?
level2_cefr: The end of print may take some time, according to Peter Preston, the deputy editor at The Observer, a national English language newspaper in London. “It’s one of those things which if you wait long enough the right thing gets done,” he explains, referring to newspaper circulation figures. “It’s probably going to take at least another four years before digital media will be the dominant force in the newspaper industry. And it’s probably going to take another four years before the internet is widely available to all. “The truth is that when you’re talking about media and technology these days, nobody is making a big deal about it,” Preston says, adding that ‘all newspapers are already planning for the end of print’. There is a fear, however, that the end may come too soon. He explains that newspapers’ decision to move to online media was not driven by the advent of digital technology, but by other factors, such as a general distaste for newspaper adverts. “I think that is part of a fear of technology,” he says. “There’s a certain level of reluctance to embrace the online world in certain quarters of the world, but there is a real acceptance among the public that they need the newspaper in print. But it’s not just the press and media that are moving to online platforms – people are switching because they want
level3_fkg: The end of print may take some time Peter Preston (Economic Times) Print circulations have dipped, and it looks as though the industry may indeed be heading for the bottom. As a nation, we still buy the newspaper, and it has a special place in our hearts. But print is fading away. It’s not only in the UK, where newspapers are showing signs of becoming obsolete. Around the world, the industry is facing difficulties. On Wednesday the UK’s two largest publishers of newspapers – the Guardian and the New York Times – announced that their print circulations dropped by around a quarter in the past year. This is a shock. A recent survey by ICM Research found that 57 per cent of UK adults believe that print is dying. But according to the research, 58 per cent of them believe that it is unlikely to reach a tipping point in the next decade or so. Newspaper readers have moved online in droves in recent years – and it appears that the trend has been continuing. The Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mail have seen visits to their websites double in the past three years. So it seems that print is losing its grip. But is it all just a matter of time? The Guardian reports that the Telegraph newspaper’s sales were up by 15 per cent last year. At the same time, the Guardian’s online subscribers were up 58 per cent. This is, of course
level3_cefr: The end of print may take some time. But surely (you say) it is bound to happen eventually. Everyone knows that print newspaper sales are plummeting while visits to the same papers’ websites keep on soaring. Just look at the latest print circulation figures.
level4_fkg: The end of print may take some time Peter Preston As print newspapers become increasingly inactive or relegated to the digital age, they will be the first to disappear. But publishers will have to restructure to cope with the potential loss of readership.
level4_cefr: The end of print may take some time Peter Preston The end of print may take some time Peter Preston The end of print may take some time It seems to many that print newspapers can't afford to lose subscribers, as a growing proportion of print customers prefer the convenience of electronic readers, but newspaper publisher News International says that's an unwise strategy. It points to a slow, but inevitable decline, as print advertisers gradually move to other media, including the internet. News International said its print circulation figures rose by 0.1% in the three months to May (from 1.9% in the previous three months), but its digital circulation grew by 8.4% to 31.16 million, with its website gaining 15.2 million visits in the last three months. It has more than doubled its print subscriber base since last year (to 65.5 million). It is also increasing its online share (from just 1.1% in March 2014 to 12% in March 2016). As the decline in print advertising continues to accelerate, so has the number of newspaper publishers laying off journalists. There is now some fear that the shift will cause job losses across the industry. Newspaper staff are also being forced out or transferred to other media, including TV, radio and the internet. What is worrying is that the shift is not uniformly being made. So even with newspapers losing their majority share of print, there is little sign that readers’ appetite for print will change. Print subscriptions for the latest quarter fell

level1: We got up at 6.30am, went to the gym at 7am, got to work by 8am and started operating at 8.30am. I operate all Monday and Wednesday as well as some Friday afternoons. Most standard head operations take three hours but some operations take all day. I’ve worked ten hours straight through on occasion without eating or going to the loo. Deciding when to operate and what to do can be stressful. The work can be physically demanding and sometimes it’s hard to keep going. It’s good to have time to yourself. The downside is some people do not get their operations back on track. It’s important to remember to rest – to eat properly, to sleep well and do your exercises. I feel like I lose my motivation. It takes a lot of stamina. I’m at work by 8am, get to the gym by 9am and get to work by 10am. My regular colleagues at work are all men. Usually it’s a small team of doctors, nurses and technicians, but sometimes it’s as many as fifteen of us. It’s hard to feel productive if you don’t get to interact with the people you come into contact with. I think there are too many women in my profession for it to be an equally balanced environment. You should make sure you have a good support network. It’s also important to not be afraid to voice

level1: Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture. If you want something to be built well, then you need good craftsmanship. The cabinets he has made for friends and family for the past five years are absolutely superb. But as his reputation grows, so does his workload. In fact, one recent order came so well-received, that he had to extend his workshop: 'I've added an office to house my workshop, with access to a phone, computer, laptop and a sewing machine.' Despite his busy lifestyle, he said he feels his income is rising at least as fast as the rate of housebuilding in the capital. 'I get about £22,000 for my cabinets a year, and then I have to build them again.' It's a slow, meticulous process and his biggest challenge is being able to be creative and make something out of every bit of wood he gets. Even the smallest thing he makes is a masterpiece, no matter how small. This week I meet Hurst again and see how he's making a sofa for a man with a disability to use with his cane. He says he's having difficulty finding customers for the work, as most people are used to seeing something else in their living room. But he does say he is keen to improve his business model, which is currently based
level2_fkg: The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst gives the impression of being a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop tucked under a railway arch in East London and am greeted with a quick handshake and the words: 'Well fire away then!' Whether this brusqueness is real or a front hiding a shy streak is not immediately apparent. But a glance around the workshop reveals that Hurst is obviously busy with good reason not to waste a minute of his time. The arched space is full of half-made pieces of furniture and planks of wood in an amazing array of natural colours.

level1: The Vales’ house is an oasis in the country's rural south, a place where human waste can be turned into green energy and where an eccentric pair live a ‘free’ life. Robert Vale, founder of the Autonomous House, uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles his sewage into garden compost, heats his house with their own body heat, and gets much of his electricity from their car. Robert also says that the most unusual feature of his eco-friendly home is that it's an actual cathedral, not a man-made building. In the chapter house, which sits astride the road that leads to the village shop, a monk kneels in prayer, as the chapter book of the fifteenth-century bible reads. During his two-year project with the Vales, Robert designed and built what they call the ‘autonomous house’. It consists of a two-storey building surrounded by fields and an ash-and-spruce wood-shed, and, with the aid of a series of pumps which make their sewage ‘green’, the Vales produce enough electricity to power their fridge, washing machine, television and internet. They do not use fossil fuels and they also compost all their waste in a garden which is covered with compost. Their only waste, he says, is from electric lights. The
level2_fkg: The Solar Survivor Charles Clover was invited by Robert Vale to investigate his ‘autonomous’ home – designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale – in Southwell Nottinghamshire. Before our visit we spoke to Robert and Brenda, who explain that they have used rainwater for washing and drinking, recycled their sewage into garden compost and heated their house with their own body heat and that of their three teenage children and their two cats, Edison and Faraday. We also visited the Minster which was built in the thirteenth-century by Sir Roger Bannister and built at a cost of around £35,000.
level2_cefr: Charles Clover ventures into Britain’s most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire is full of surprises. The first is Britain’s least-known ancient cathedral Southwell Minster, celebrated by writers of an environmental disposition for the pagan figures of ‘green’ men which medieval craftsmen carved into the decoration in its thirteenth-century chapter house. The second appropriately enough is Britain’s greenest dwelling, the ‘autonomous house’ designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat together with that of their three teenage children and their two cats Edison and Faraday. What do you think? Did you know that solar power consists of concentrating the sun’s rays? Yes or no?
level3_fkg: Charles Clover, Solar Survivor’s host, goes inside Britain’s most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire is full of surprises. The first is Britain’s least-known ancient cathedral Southwell Minster celebrated by writers of an environmental disposition for the pagan figures of ‘green’ men which medieval craftsmen carved into the decoration in its thirteenth-century chapter house. The second, appropriately enough, is Britain’s greenest dwelling, the ‘autonomous house’ designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat together with that of their three teenage children and their two cats Edison and Faraday. Having heard about the Vales, Charles meets Brenda, Robert’s mother, Brenda’s sister and the younger child, a boy named John. The Vales spend a lot of time in their garden, mainly planting new trees and tending their five greenhouses. They grow a range of vegetables, most of which they grow themselves, and they cook with all the food. Their vegetables are sold at farmers’ markets throughout the year, and they make a living growing vegetables with the leftover waste heat from electrical appliances. The family has a well in their garden to take rainwater from the house, so when they get it back
level3_cefr: Charles Clover tours Britain’s most environmentally-friendly home. Visiting the autonomous house designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale, a professor at Leicester University, Charles meets up with a young architect who lives in the house. Charles goes on a tour around the house, taking in the gardens, the recycling system and the sewage treatment plant.
level4_fkg: In this adventure for Solar Survivor, Solar Survivor Charles Clover explores two homes which he believes could provide the blueprint for a sustainable, eco-friendly future.

The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat together with that of their three teenage children and their two cats Edison and Faraday.

level1: What is acupuncture? Acupuncture is a Japanese medicine system which originated in China over 2500 years ago. It has been used for many different conditions but its role in treating pain has received most attention in Western medicine. Some GPs, midwives and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.
level2_fkg: Two thousand years ago acupuncture was used in Chinese medicine. It comes from a traditional Chinese system of medicine. It includes herbalism massage diet manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions but acupuncture's role in treating pain has received most attention by doctors in the West. Some GPs midwives and physios use it regularly for pain relief.

It comes from the traditional Chinese system of medicine that includes herbalism massage diet manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture’s role in treating pain has received most attention by doctors in the West. Some GPs, midwives and physios use it regularly for pain relief. A. What's it all about? Traditional Chinese medicine sees health as a state in which the energy of the mind, body and spirit are in harmony. According to the theory, energy or Qi (pronounced chee) flows around the body along lines called meridians. Some injuries such as a broken leg could be due to blockages of the meridian. Medicinal acupuncture can be used to treat these blockages.

level1: The December cover of Capitol Magazine featured Clay Carter looking rich and handsome in his expensive Armani suit. Inside there were pictures of him playing with a dog (borrowed from Rodney), standing proudly in empty courtrooms, washing his new Porsche and standing on board his new boat in the Bahamas. Near the back of the same magazine were pictures of brides followed by announcements of future weddings. There was a picture of Rebecca Van Horn looking beautiful sitting on a bench next to her future husband, an insignificant but rich-looking man called Jason Schubert Myers. Clay smiled to himself at the misery the magazine must have been causing in the Van Horn home.
level2_fkg: Clay Carter’s boss in Manhattan is the December cover of Capitol Magazine, with a picture of himself looking rich and handsome in his expensive Armani suit. He realised he didn’t really have a chance to sell it because the Van Horn family would be too upset to buy it. But at least Rebecca Van Horn was not able to see it, so she did not know who the man was. Jason Schubert Myers, the insignificant but rich-looking man, had a picture of a beautiful, blond woman with a man-eating cat sitting next to him. Clay smiled at his own miserable situation and realized that he had to make things right with Rebecca. He bought the magazine and gave it to Rebecca’s family. He told them that Rebecca had a new boyfriend and she should be happy. He explained that he could do that because his friend Rodney has a job and he was paying for it.
level2_cefr: The Van Horns were very upset that Clay Carter had given their Christmas present to Rodney Van Horn. But because of what they said on Christmas Day, Clay had had his wish granted and the gift was now being adored by Rebecca and Jason.

level1: A. The image of cleanliness Supermarkets know from market research that shoppers place a premium on the cleanliness of the store. They may place their fruit and veg at the entrance of a store or even a display of house plants for sale to enhance this. They may also provide an in-store bakery that wafts irresistible fresh bread smells around a large area of the store. The colour of the store's fixtures may heighten the image too - for example, green may be used because of its association with fresh produce. B. The image of convenience Supermarkets know from market research that shoppers place a premium on convenience stores. They may place their fruit and veg at the entrance of a store or even a display of house plants for sale to enhance this. level2_cefr: B. The appeal of nostalgia and sentimentality Shopping centres use all kinds of techniques that make shopping more enjoyable. Some may place old items on display, or may advertise particular items with nostalgic words or phrases. In these situations, there may be a slight change in the price of the item being sold, and this, coupled with nostalgia, can help make it more appealing. For example, if you visit a department store, for example, some aisles may be devoted to old favourites, such as DVDs and CDs. They will also often have old photographs of deceased people on display. They also may have a range of products based on these photos, such as cosmetics and handbags.

level1: Isabel is an art student of 31, a devotee of historical romances and a devotee of comic books. Her wacky and witty personality belies her seriousness of purpose. She is an avid lover of historical fiction and a devotee of Tom Hooper. She is also a little too keen on the late 18th-century romances in particular. Her concern for her knees, which are rather rudimentary by her standards, might ruin her chances. Isabel’s parents, on the other hand, are proud of her and don’t mind her prickly knees; but for some reason, they haven’t been encouraged by her mother’s choice of men. Her desire for a suitor is not met but rather rebuffed by her parents. She then runs into a series of other people and starts to see them as “The Enemy”. However, she quickly realises that the Enemy are also in love with someone else. In particular, one of Isabel’s new friends, a younger man who has just become a teacher at her school and is convinced that Isabel has inherited his son’s love of art and who can make her a more convincing female character. Her prickly knees prove to be her salvation — and that of other people in the story — which proves to be the author’s trademark
level2_fkg: Isabel is an art student of 31. She devotes herself to historical romances. Isabel's knobbly knees ruin her chances. She is attracted to a man who is a former dancer. Isabel makes friends with the man, but eventually they break up.
level2_cefr: Isabel is a young art student who devotes her life to the study of art. She has an obsession for period fashions and adores historical romances. She is in a hurry and doesn't take time to reflect. At one point she is found wandering on the streets in a pair of skirts which she thinks she has worn before.
level3_fkg: I actually look rather good in jeans. So I rarely wear them. I don't want to get mixed up with the wrong sort of person. So runs the logic of Isabel 'our heroine’ in this refreshingly zany novel. An art student of 31, a devotee of historical romances, she seeks Mr Right but is concerned lest her knobbly knees ruin her chances. Hope however springs eternal - which proves to be her salvation and that of other people in the story. Employing the staccato drama-laden pace of an early silent film, with chapter headings like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired', the author writes with terrific witty.
level3_cefr: A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student, devotee of historical romances, and a devotee of the BBC's Eastenders. She wants a Mr Right, but is concerned that her knobbly knees will ruin her chances. Hope, however, springs eternal. Employing the staccato drama-laden pace of an early silent film with chapter headings like "Our Hero Feels Inspired", the author writes with terrific energy.
level4_fkg: Isabel is an art student of 31, a devotee of historical romances, and a devotee of the French countryside. She finds Mr Right, and her knobbly knees ruin her chances. So she wears jeans sparingly. However, this means she makes mistakes, and is set up by a strange and unpleasant man. She also finds herself in a smuggling accident, and is reunited with her grandmother, who reveals herself as her long-lost family. Isabel realizes that if she marries Mr Right she will be living with a very different man, and learns that he is a real man.
level4_cefr: I actually look rather good in jeans. So I rarely wear them. I don't want to get mixed up with the wrong sort of person.’ So runs the logic of Isabel, our heroine. An art student of 31, devotee of historical romances, she seeks Mr Right but is concerned lest her knobbly knees ruin her chances. Hope however springs eternal. Which proves to be her salvation and that of other people in the story. Employing the staccato drama-laden pace of an early silent film with chapter headings like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired' the author writes with terrific verve.

level1: Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However, what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. There seem to be three main theories. The most popular states that the functions and purposes of sleep are primarily physiological. It claims that we sleep in order to maintain the health of our body. In other words, biological processes work hard as we sleep to repair any damage done during the day and to restore ourselves to full efficiency.
