level1: Is your office working ok? Fresh air and the right chairs are the key to a happy healthy workforce according to a new survey. We went to four contrasting offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. Our expert panel was a building health consultant; an ergonomist who studies people’s working conditions; and an occupational psychologist.
level2_fkg: Office B. The Financial Times Building Health Consultant: This office is clean crisp and extremely quiet. The occupants are part of a small dynamic team and have no complaints. There is no central heating but the space is well ventilated with great views. The chairs are firm and comfortable and the windows are letting in lots of fresh air. There is no central heating so the occupants can comfortably sleep. There is a healthy dose of daylight. Office C. Insurance Company Ergonomist: This is a well ventilated and well heated office with a lot of natural light. It is well ventilated with a natural atmosphere. There are plenty of window seats which allow the occupants to enjoy fresh air. This space has central heating and air conditioning so the occupants can easily regulate their temperature. The occupants say they enjoy this space but would prefer to have central heating. It has a natural feel and a good dose of light. The chairs are firm and comfortable but not overly firm or too deep. This space feels very clean and open. The occupants appear to like this workspace. Office D. Hospitality Provider Ergonomist: This is a relatively new office. It has a great view of the street and is well ventilated. The space is spacious, light and comfortable. There are comfortable chairs and good natural light. The occupants are engaged and happy in the
level2_cefr: Office B. Financial Services Firm Ergonomist: This office has a good level of ventilation and natural light and is a good place for employees to work, although it has a relatively small number of staff and lacks windows opening straight onto the street. Although there is no central heating or mechanical ventilation it is a healthy environment for people to work in. Office C. Engineering Company Ergonomist: The ergonomically designed space is comfortable and allows for movement throughout the space. There is a large kitchen and the employees spend time here during the day and return to it at night. The air is also very healthy because there is no central heating or mechanical ventilation. The staff appear to be happy because of the amount of natural light that comes into the space.
level3_fkg: Office B. Hospitality Firm Ergonomist: A good ergonomic workspace should include adjustable height chairs and good access to fresh air, but this particular office may lack this basic requirement. A little comfort and good lighting should encourage occupants to make the most of the space. Office C. Retail Shop Occupational Therapist: This office had to be commended on the fresh air front. A lot of natural light, lots of natural ventilation and a lot of natural light led to the workspace being a happy place to work.
level3_cefr: Office B. Pharmaceutical Company Ergonomist: This large office has a full range of ergonomic features but lacks a comfortable office seat. The staff have been told it is “very comfortable” but many complain that the seating does not “give them sufficient leg and hip support”. They also reported having difficulty typing comfortably at a keyboard because of their desks being so low. Office C. Retailing company Building Health Consultant: This office is one of the most sophisticated in the group and is well appointed; there are plenty of high-backed chairs that have lots of leg and hip support and plenty of head and shoulder room. This space is very quiet and therefore very good for concentration, while the staff seem happy and not to experience pressured or uncomfortable working conditions. They are also allowed to use the coffee machine and the company benefits from the use of free wifi. Office D. Restaurant and Coffee Shop Building Health Consultant: The staff were very happy to have their feet on the floor. They also commented that the windows are very large, enabling air to circulate. There is sufficient space for everyone to be able to talk at their desk and have light-filled conversations. The staff have their own meeting rooms and are able to arrange their own meeting space depending on what they need at any particular time. However, many staff say that there is a lack of fresh air coming into the building. Office E. Insurance Agency Ergonomist: Despite the office having
level4_fkg: Office B. Legal firm Ergonomist: A well designed office can help people to feel happy and healthy. There is a lot of natural light with windows opening out onto a greenery covered patio, the furniture is very comfortable and the staff feel a sense of well being. Office C. Social enterprise This space has a wide range of natural light. The staff are very comfortable here. The environment is very stimulating. Office D. Finance company Ergonomist: The space has a lot of natural light. The offices are open plan but there is some natural ventilation and the office is very clean. It does have some mechanical ventilation but otherwise it is very well designed. This office is designed for a relatively small group of people with a lot of interaction. They work in comfortable modern furniture but the occupants feel that it needs improvement. Office E. Engineering firm Ergonomist: The space is a real mix of old industrial buildings and modern offices. There is little natural light but the design is quite pleasing and the staff feel comfortable in the space. The desks are firm but not uncomfortable. The space is well ventilated but no natural ventilation. A few people are having health problems. The space is well designed with lots of natural light, lots of natural ventilation and plenty of natural light. The layout is good. The staff seem to love the place. Office F. Insurance company Ergonomist: The space is very spacious and
level4_cefr: Office B. Software Development Office Ergonomist: This office is designed for maximum comfort and efficiency. There is plenty of free standing work space which is great for the office team that works on projects remotely. This office is bright and open-plan with good natural daylight. It also has good ventilation and access to fresh air, which would benefit everyone in this office. Office C. Banking Office Ergonomist: This office is quite modern and has large windows which open directly onto the street. A high ceiling means that the air circulates freely. It is a great space for team work. However, there are too many people to make a high level of air quality sufficient for occupants. Office D. Construction Company Ergonomist: This office is more like a university than an office space; it is not particularly airy, it is not well ventilated and it has mechanical ventilation, which is not necessary. The occupants complain that this space is hot and claustrophobic. There is an informal atmosphere within the office but the employees do have access to a meeting room. This is very important for workers working in the construction industry. The building has excellent natural light and is well ventilated. It is an open plan office with plenty of natural light. The team who work in this office have the chance to be in the fresh air from their offices.

level1: When I was a young man, I had a bad childhood, filled with petty problems and my mother putting me through hell every day. My older brother on the other hand, was the one that had the time of his life. He was a musician and a brilliant businessman. He was a little bit of a scamp, and would make a great husband. During my teenage years, he married me. I am very grateful to my father for that. He introduced me to a lot of interesting things. I could not imagine my life without music, even though I was an artist at that time. It has always been my passion. In fact, I could not imagine not being able to sing in front of thousands of people. I have always thought that I might be a musician and not a theatre director. I am immensely proud of my children and I cannot imagine life without them. I could never imagine my life without my work. As a journalist, I used to do everything and I am very proud of that. I feel that I am the most successful person in my family. I would never make a living as a journalist. But I am also very proud that my children have always been brilliant and that I have taught them a lot of things. I am very pleased with myself for this. I will always be thankful to my parents for giving me such a good upbringing.
level2_fkg: From here to paternity A. The theatre director Because of my bizarre personal life, which I cannot be proud of, I have been blessed with 35 years of small children and I can honestly say I have loved every minute. I had the pleasure of feeding the baby this morning and that for me is what being a father is all about. I’m terribly lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera theatre, books, music. It creates a great bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I have become a friend rather than a father.

level1: I LOOK AWAY from the cigarettes now and wonder: did I have one to give up and if so, why? Was it so easy? I know it’s hard to be objective about everything, but I suppose I didn’t have to because I’ve never been a smoker. I will try to answer some of your questions in future columns but for now I am happy to take you on an imaginary journey in which you will learn all the things you have to know in order to quit. And you’ll be surprised what you will discover. There are six steps, each with a step-by-step explanation and suggestions for how to implement each one. They are not all presented here to ensure you understand the steps in the right order. But I have tried to provide an overview so you can follow along. 1. You will remember smoking once.: You won’t smoke again when you stop the session. This is how you identify cigarettes as a physical object that you will have to stop smoking. 2. You will want to quit.: You will want to stop. When you stop the session you will feel a bit strange and your mind will go blank. This is the first part where you will imagine that you are not going to smoke again. You will think of what you want to eat and drink and you will remember how cigarettes make you feel. Then you will picture yourself as a non-smoker. You
level2_fkg: THINGS CAN CHANGE IN A WEEK There are two basic problems that lead to someone giving up smoking: habit and will power. In an addictive habit such as smoking, the relapse rate is very high. The ability to stop smoking is a very short-term ability to change an undesirable habit and so it is difficult to build habits that last longer than three or four weeks. The relapse rate, by contrast, is very small. So the first thing that smokers do when they want to stop smoking is to cut back on the amount of cigarettes they smoke. As soon as a smoker stops smoking, the urge to smoke may start to reappear, which is why it is so easy for people to start again.
level2_cefr: THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING I thought everyone would be pleased but one of my colleagues was absolutely furious. ‘What do you mean?’ she raged. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day lifelong smoker and four hours later I was not was faintly irritating. I find it curious myself. The stop-smoking session was an interesting mixture of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I had not intended to stop and I did not even particularly want to. I started to feel ill but the other smokers tried to talk me into staying and that just did not work. My lungs felt a little more relaxed and I felt better in general. I thought everyone would be pleased, and I hoped they would share my excitement. One of my colleagues remarked afterwards that she did not seem to realise how great it felt to stop, so I think my inability to explain it to her might have offended her. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ she queried. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day lifelong smoker and

I took part in a few sessions of that type and now I never smoke again. My colleagues were absolutely furious at first. ‘What do you mean?’ she raged. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day life-long smoker and four hours later I was not was faintly irritating. I find it curious myself. The stop-smoking session was an interesting mixture of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I had not intended to stop and I did not even particularly want to.

level1: The article’s thesis is that what is written without effort is in general read without pleasure — and this has been the prevailing tenet since the advent of the telegraph and the typing machine, as well as for some of the most successful and influential literary and artistic ventures that come from the humanities. It appears that the writers of great texts are those who work hard at their craft and persevere until the end. The argument that this work is ‘good writing’, i.e. comes hard, is not a new one. Some of the most iconic works of fiction have been created by a handful of writers, notably Emily Dickinson (1844–1914), William Faulkner (1885–1971), and H.G. Wells (1918–2001), many of whose contributions have been included in an anthology, The Letters of Emily Dickinson. Dickinson wrote a short story a week (in the style of the short stories by Hermann Hesse) in which every word was written by hand. He used to read Dickinson and to edit it in his office, where he wrote for hours. When Dickinson’s death in 1849 was announced, he was forced to take to the streets of London. At one point he wrote a poem titled, ‘And I came to New York in the hope and expectation of getting married
level2_fkg: Dr Johnson maintained that ‘what is written without effort is in general read without pleasure’. The converse is that good writing comes hard. Looking back through my handwritten school essays, I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. I am sure the reason was that they were physically hard to write. The slowness of the hand disciplined the brain. What would be difficult to alter or erase was written with care. The casual facility of the computer leads to sloppiness. Most writers using word processors find the time spent correcting early drafts more or less equates with the time originally spent on handwritten text.

level1: I headed down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. The dusk had deepened, the humidity thickened into a palpable prickly drizzle that lent my walk a heightened feeling of sheltered stealth. I knew this side of the street from the dawn of consciousness; our neighbours the Matzes and the Pritchards and Han Kieffer’s grocery store and the Kring’s and the Pottses’ houses where my first playmates all girls lived. These houses down the street, though not every inhabitant was known by name to me, had each been as distinct in my childish awareness as the little troughs in the cement which led rain from their roof gutters out through the sidewalk to the street and which punctuated my progress on roller skates or on my scooter. These houses down the street, though not every inhabitant was known by name to me, had each been as distinct in my childish awareness as the little troughs in the cement which led rain from their roof gutters out through the sidewalk to the street and which punctuated my progress on roller skates or on my scooter.
level2_fkg: Suddenly I heard a voice. It said to me, “Are you the one? Are you the one who attacked Jim?” I looked around for my friend the droopy eyed man. He seemed to be nowhere in sight. I crept closer. I saw the back of Jim’s head leaning against the door. I realized that Jim was wearing a long red coat. My brother had only left for school an hour or so earlier so he could not have gone after me. And yet it was hard to think of anything but Jim being the one that came towards me and confronted me. As I drew closer, I realized how long Jim had been lingering behind. As I stepped into the house, the droopy eyed man began to question me. “But you saw his coat hang on the door. Isn’t that why you came out from the house and not over to the mailbox?” “Yes but I wasn’t here.” “So why are you here?” “So you saw me?” He started to point at me. The droopy eyed man looked down at me. I took a step to the side. “What are you doing?” “I’m here, you snuck up behind me!” I looked back at the house. The droopy eyed man said, “You know, you
level2_cefr: I saw the little streetlight in front of me and looked up at it with my small finger. I saw in the darkness a shadow with three horns. I smiled as I remembered that evening when I was five years old and was about to give a speech to the neighbourhood children, I told them that I had just bought my first book on children’s writing which would lead me to a new field of study. I paused a moment and looked around. No, I remembered from the beginning. I wanted to know what they were interested in because I’d never seen this side of the street with those houses and this streetlight and I wanted to find out. What is that? I was thinking, I thought to myself, as I peered up at the night sky, the stars were far away from me, but I knew there was a light tumbling through the clouds of rain. As soon as I realized it it fell on the streetlight and it turned to shadow as if someone had flinched. I paused. It was the same dark sky which I had seen all day, but it was a black sky now. I looked back and looked into the darkness. It was a dark, clear night, except for the distant light of a nearby lamppost which had cast a beam which was blazing against the sky. I knew it was that light now, but I didn

level1: Albert Einstein, the great nineteenth-century German physicist and mathematician, was among the first to show that the laws of physics, developed by Albert Newton and Isaac Newton, could be applied to the physical world. After studying the speed of light, he proved Newton and Newton were wrong and made a revolutionary leap forward. After Newton’s work, Einstein had to rework his work so that his theory of gravity could be tested by Newton’s formula for the speed of light, known as the Riemann hypothesis. While Newton’s law was a very successful prediction and led to other successful predictions, Einstein’s theory still has many problems today. One of the problems is that Newton’s laws of motion could only be tested by the experiment of colliding atoms. Since colliding atoms were only made of a solid substance called atoms, they are easily disproven. While Newton’s theory is still being tested, Einstein had a new idea of how collisions would occur. In his work on the Riemann hypothesis, he suggested that if some atoms were not in motion, there would be no collisions or collisions resulting from gravity. Einstein’s new idea could not be tested until he tested a series of objects including two very small, exploding pieces of dynamite, which became known
level2_fkg: Einstein Stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist and the chances are they’ll think of Albert Einstein. His face is used to advertise products with intellectual connotations from computers to encyclopedias. Most people know little about what Einstein did except that he developed some mysterious theories under the heading of ‘relativity’ which are famous for being incomprehensible and for coming up with bizarre predictions that run counter to everyday experience. Einstein was part of a gigantic leap forward in scientific thinking, an intellectual revolution that heralded the birth of twentieth century science. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to create a new, more rational description of the universe by studying relationships between matter and the forces of nature.

level1: An astronomer, on his first visit to the Southern Hemisphere, was astonished by what he saw. He shivered at the expanse of the night sky, which included the moon and all the planets, in all their majesty. He took the time to talk to all the strangers about the craters, and in the evenings sipped ale and sipped wine. He sat on the grass at his picnic table and took some notes.
level2_fkg: Amateur Astronomy Many things have changed in astronomy over the past half-century. Until about 30 years ago, there was a great shortage of charts and catalogues. Telescopic equipment was limited and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today, the range of off-the-shelf telescopes and equipment covers almost everything one could need. Electronic calculators and computers have revolutionised almanacs and chart production and facilitated the analysis of observations and the publication of results. All this must surely make this the golden age of amateur astronomy. Well, perhaps, but a great deal has been lost as well. Now one may have to travel 80 km to find a sky comparable to that found in urban areas 50 years ago.

level1: Art has evolved in modern times - more and more over the course of the last two hundred years - as though every artist had to rebel against the art of his contemporaries. Art is praised in terms of being unique revolutionary shocking even. We feel good about admiring the artist whose work no one appreciated a hundred years ago. But when we get to the art of our own day we get cold feet and say that an artist has gone too far, that what he does can no longer be called art. Or rather the media say it for us.
level2_fkg: Art In modern times, more and more over the course of the last two hundred years - we have come to speak as though every artist had to rebel against the art of his contemporaries. But when we get to the art of our own day, we get cold feet and say that an artist has gone too far that what he does can no longer be called art. Or rather the media say it for us.

level1: Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon entirely dependent upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century capitalism for its development. Most historians of fashion are at pains to point out though that fashion, at least in the sense of style and design, has a very long history. They often take the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as their starting point. As societies have developed in complexity, populations have expanded and multiple technologies for producing an increasing variety of clothing and physical adornment have been discovered so the meanings attached to dress have also increased in their complexity and significance.

level1: It is difficult to say what sparked the first interest in metals. One possibility is that stone-age people made tools primarily to use stone, perhaps in order to carve stones to make tools or grind stone into grains for the purpose of making other things. Another possibility is that the discovery of metals brought new opportunities for those who were able to work it. Some of the first stone-age toolmakers, especially those who worked axes, hammers, and axe-points, were of mixed ethnicity and migrated across the entire Middle East. Some early toolmakers in the Near East were of the nomadic ethnicity. They were also skilled in hunting and fishing and knew how to work and preserve the meat they killed.
level2_fkg: Metals It may have been a wish for self-adornment that aroused the interest of Stone Age people in metals. Sitting by the side of a river waiting for a fish to come within a spears throw or just idling away a moment one of our early ancestors might have happened upon a shiny yellow pebble and plucked it off the river bed. It did not have the feel of stone but it was attractive. In such a way one could conjecture that gold entered the lives of primitive people. Given the malleability of the metal it very soon became a much sought-after material.

level1: In the meantime, the light on the river was dazzling and I thought that if the light of the setting sun had caught the lilac leaves of the trees to one side in the early morning sunshine, I would have captured the autumnal feeling. But in the early afternoon it was a different story. The light was still strong on the river, but the shadows cast from the trees had been reduced by the shadows of the city above and below. I realised the light was too strong on the river, too much for my liking. I wanted to capture the quiet beauty of the river and the reflection of the city behind it, but I could not. Instead, the shadows of the old buildings, a glimmer in the wind, had shifted around them, and it wasn’t looking promising. The river is a lily pond after all, not a fountain. No one was going to come down to swim here after all, after all.
level2_fkg: The Vienna Assignment I was in Vienna to take photographs. That was generally the reason I was anywhere then. Photographs were more than my livelihood. They were part of my life. The way light fell on a surface never failed to tug at my imagination. The way one picture a single snapshot could capture the essence of a time and place a city a human being was embedded in my consciousness. One day one second I might close the shutter on the perfect photograph. There was always the chance, so long as there was film in my camera. Finish one load another and keep looking with eyes wide open.

level1: Enough Sleep? As the richer and busier countries have grown, so sleeplessness and anxiety have also grown in the popular psyche. Research in the USA has found 40 million Americans to be chronically affected. Some recent best-selling novels in Britain have featured insomniacs as protagonists or sleep-research laboratories as their settings. Part of this interest is in sleep in general: in its rhythms its uses and in problems with sleeping. But a central preoccupation remains. ‘People need more sleep’ says one leading sleep researcher. ‘People cut back on sleep when they're busy.’
level2_fkg: Enough sleep? Tiredness, it is often claimed has become the modern condition. As richer, busier countries have grown so sleeplessness and anxiety have also grown in the popular psyche. Part of this interest is in sleep in general, in its rhythms its uses and in problems with sleeping. But a central preoccupation remains. ‘People need more sleep’, says one leading sleep researcher. ‘People cut back on sleep when they're busy.’

level1: Irrespective of whether you are a City worker or a City resident, chances are you are in need of air-conditioning at some point during the day. If you live in a City, you are probably more aware of the health hazards of lingering in the hot sand of the beach than you are of the harmful effects of air-conditioning. This is just one example of how the modern world casually misuses air-conditioning. It has become a central feature of work and play, a potent symbol of the ability of humanity to control the climate, or at least modify it. Many air-conditioned buildings, however, could employ other methods of cooling.
level2_fkg: Air-conditioning There is a chill in the air at Cannons Gym a favourite lunch-time haunt for City of London workers. To deal with this summer’s unusually high temperatures the fitness centre has gone overboard with the air-conditioning. So much so in fact that at quiet times the gym feels like somewhere in the Arctic. This is just one example of how the modern world casually misuses air-conditioning. It has become a central feature of work and play, a potent symbol of the ability of humanity to control the climate or at least modify it. Many air-conditioned buildings, however, could employ other methods of cooling.

level1: I said, ‘Sir, I don’t think we will find the stars’. You looked at me in horror and said, ‘I have no idea’. I laughed, and said, ‘This is what I was telling you about.’ And then I stared at you and said, ‘How is it’. You stared at me with your large blue eyes. I said, ‘I believe it’. But what would you do if you thought I had lied? Why would you lie to me?’ You said, ‘Well it would be very strange if we tried to find the stars if we had done so.’ And so I stayed down there for some time letting my thoughts drift, trying to decipher what the stars were saying. You wondered aloud why I waited for so long to climb out. But I did not know what to say; you sat watching as I told you I had climbed out of the well. In the days of cavemen when all that was required to find a cave man was to climb up and down a series of precarious ladders laden with rocks and mud and sand, it was the only way to discover a cave. So I remained there looking through the clear blue sky. But that’s not really what the stars told us. They told us that they had a telescope just as we had
level2_fkg: You were too scared to look at the stars. 'I am a little scared to get in.' I said. 'But you are only going to look up at the stars when you get out.'
level2_cefr: I saw the stars. I could see the moon and all the planets, from this height. We sat on the cliff chatting, you still holding the handle of the bucket. Then the water entered the well and we plunged in. I told you to stand still. You knew that I had been snatching the bucket because you looked too frightened to fall down. But I could not bear the thought of letting you fall. I was still holding the handle. The water flowed down into the bucket. The water was so still that there was no abyss, no sand or mud on the bottom.
level3_fkg: THE WELL I had read somewhere that from a sufficiently deep hole one could see the stars if the day was clear. I had persuaded you to help me with my scheme; you watched eyes wide fist to mouth as I winched up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I had not thought to allow for the bucket’s much increased weight, your lack of strength or inclination to just stand back and let what would happen happen. You held the handle, taking some of the strain as I pushed the bucket off the side of the well’s stone surround.

level1: The policeman took three steps back towards the police station. The policeman's face was a bit clouded by tears but then he stood up, still smiling, and walked back to the crime scene.
level2_fkg: Ralph turned into the dark street towards the hospital and wondered if the ambulance would be able to find him because his ringing mobile had been loudly beeping. He followed the sound, knocking on the door of the hospital, and heard the emergency alarm activate. He followed the ambulance up to the top of the hill before noticing that the telegraph pole which had rung so loudly as he entered had been pushed up against the wall. The telegraph tower was standing just below the tower and as he walked to the ambulance the telegraph pole had moved up. The hospital had been moved onto a small hill above the road where he was standing.
level2_cefr: Ralph unlocked the door to his let and as he entered the dark motionless hall experienced that momentary qualm of ownership which even after three years still lightly besieged him sometimes when he returned alone at the end of the day. When he had first bought the flat he used to come home in an eager questioning mood - often as early as he could — wondering what it had been doing during the hours he had been away. It had represented a form of welcome to him, a region in which his focus was undisputed and reliable. He supposed that he should have worried about intruders or burst drains in that moment of reunion, but his flat had always been sitting waiting for him with an expression of independence or of neglect depending on whether he’d left it tidy or not.

level1: Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously, we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived. But beyond that there is a wider basic need to learn about our past in order to help us understand and interpret our individual and national futures. Heritage represents a fundamental desire for continuity - assurance about the past goes a long way to assuring our future. It is through this continuity that we achieve our own place in history, our own immortality.

level1: Othello The London Transfer of an exceptional production of Shakespeare's play Othello allows me to make amends for an unfair review that I wrote when the show opened last spring. Back then, I complained that Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role and I was guilty of running down his acting. I still think its a distortion of the tragedy to remove the age difference between Othello and Desdemona but I eat my words about the rest of Mr Fearon's magnificent performance. Indeed, the whole cast is magnificent. Memorable scenes include the one where Cassio’s competitive games with the other young officers get dangerously out of hand and the moment when Iago begins to lose control and has to struggle to get a grip on himself.

level1: With a certain humour Keith described it as being like being stranded in a blizzard in a cold wet room at the foot of a snow-capped mountain. Dawne was less amused. 'I'm not sure about you', she said, "It doesn't feel cold at all, it's warm as a fricking furnace." Keith was quite irritated by the mention of a blizzard but then again she was not the only one. 'Does that make sense? It doesn't seem likely,' she said. 'The only reason I came up with this is because my Dad had a secret wish to take a skiing holiday.' She also had an idea about what they would be doing during the ski season. Keith had brought her the maps but she never had time to look at them. They were a bit sketchy but she did realise that they were in Switzerland and remembered that the Swiss have a fondness for putting themselves in danger. Keith and Dawne were glad to go up the mountain to look for a snowfield, but as they headed in that direction they were very surprised to find a tunnel - it turned out to be a tunnel for the hotel guests who were a long way off! Keith said that they would have to find someone from the hotel staff to come and
level2_fkg: When Keith and Dawne woke up in the morning they found themselves in a snow storm. They looked out the window and saw snow covered trees and mountains swaying gently in the wind. Dawne, who had just come back from school, couldn’t wait to show Keith her passport which he had misplaced. They took it to the hotel receptionist and he said: We had an accident. In Room 212, Keith and I are in a room called the Edelweiss. There are eight people in Room 212 and three of them were our relatives. We have booked this room for 12 nights. We want to spend 12 nights here. We will go to the station and get there by bus and return to England by bus. The other room is on the third floor, it is called the Sky room. There are four beds in the room. The person upstairs, who was sleeping next to us, said that they had not heard anything. They are not Italians. Dawne and Keith explained that when they got up this morning they saw that there is snow on the ground. When they tried to show Dawne and Keith their passports it said that they could not find any. Keith tried with no success to explain but couldn’t. He asked Dawne if there were any police cars in the road. Dawne said no. Keith was confused. Keith said that no-one had been at the hotel since we got there
level2_cefr: Dawne's uncle, the Wrong Country Uncle, had arranged for Keith and Dawne to go on holiday with their aunt and uncle, Keith and Dawne. He took them to Venice and booked them into the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went together to the travel agency to make the booking, the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast. But something went wrong. Either in the travel agency or at the check-in desk, or in some anonymous computer, a small calamity was conceived. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
level3_fkg: The Wrong Country Uncle chose for them a package holiday at a very reasonable price: a flight from Gatwick Airport twelve nights in Venice the fairyland city in the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went together to the travel agency to make the booking the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast all of them learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either in the travel agency or at the check-in desk, or in some anonymous computer a small calamity was conceived. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Room 212 somewhere in Switzerland.
level3_cefr: Two British teens are stranded in the middle of a Swiss countryside and entrusted to two Swiss friends to help them out. But when they arrive in Switzerland they find that they are locked in the room, only to awake in the middle of the night to find they are in the wrong room.
level4_fkg: Dawne and Keith were surprised. Dawne was a little bit disappointed that they hadn't been to Venice, but they still had a wonderful holiday together.
level4_cefr: The Wrong Country Uncle chose for them a package holiday at a very reasonable price: a flight from Gatwick Airport twelve nights in Venice the fairyland city in the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went together to the travel agency to make the booking, the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast all of them learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either in the travel agency or at the check-in desk or in some anonymous computer, a small calamity was conceived. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Room 212 somewhere in Switzerland.

level1: Lions are incredibly efficient hunters, thanks to their insatiable appetite, but they also have an insatiable desire to make new friends. Now, the latest research from Harvard, Cornell and University of Toronto shows that lions are no more social than dogs, or even humans. The results are striking. In an experiment involving a large group of captive lions, the team of researchers examined the vocal displays of each individual, trying to identify how vocal group members communicated. It was a close call: A male lion roared three times, as one cat would do when he wanted to scare away potential rivals, yet another lion would roar twice, as one would when you want to scare off a rival. All three lions gave different versions of this behavior, with males, not individuals, demonstrating the more vocal communication and sociality. This suggests that not all cats roar at the same time and that members do not always express their desires as they do when they want to. Lion vocalization is not a monosyllabic sound: lions can roar multiple times. If they are interested in the same item, they do it all at once, while if they are not, the leader can stop the group from doing so. "This discovery suggests that in social animals, the lions are much less social than previously thought," explained the researchers. "
level2_fkg: Two lions are seen working together. They have been spotted together in a circle. They look into each others eyes, then look in the direction of their respective circles. They roar, then they stand still, then they move on. The roaring is heard from behind the lions.
level2_cefr: Lions roar to scare off rivals, and in lion packs they hunt like a group. Now we know that most of these roars are not roars from rival lions. These are roars from rival males. In addition, the lions rarely communicate with each other by roars. Their roars are actually squeaks. Rather than being roars from rival males, they are squeaks from lions who have found food together and are protecting their territories. Thus it is clear that males can not communicate with the cubs and even with each other. Whenever they are in danger they will stay put, scavenging food for themselves. But because they are in constant danger, they do not act in a coordinated way. The result is that lion packs seldom hunt for food in groups.
level3_fkg: In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals, rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal. But after spending many years observing these creatures in the wild we have acquired a less exalted view. When we started our research in 1978, we hoped to discover why lions teamed up to hunt rear cubs and amongst other things scare off rivals with chorused roars. We have now learned that all the chorused roars seem to be mere ploys for predators to get away with something that is more important to them - a tasty meal.
level3_cefr: As far as we could tell, lions roar because they have a vocal system which uses a different approach to communication than other animals. When lions roar they use their own voices and if a lion has a rival who shouts a roar at the same time as another lion then that rival will be forced to give up its territory. But the other lions do not use their own voice at all. They use their own vocal system to scare off rivals or to communicate in certain situations with their own vocalizations. By making the other lions' vocalizations inaudible, the lions are able to attract the attention of an unwary prey.
level4_fkg: Observing Lions In the popular imagination, lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset, a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal, in this case their next meal. But after spending many years observing these creatures in the wild, we have acquired a less exalted view. When we started our research in 1978, we hoped to discover why lions teamed up to hunt rear cubs and among other things scare off rivals with chorused roars. We found that the only way lions managed to scare off rivals was to use a "team roar" composed of individual roars: Lions never use chorusing as a means of warning off each other; even the best choruses are merely a temporary defense in a fight. Instead, lions seem to depend more on their instincts: they prefer to attack when they have to and even when the prey is too weak to attack without assistance.
level4_cefr: Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals, rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal. But after spending many years observing these creatures in the wild we have acquired a less exalted view. When we started our research in 1978 we hoped to discover why lions teamed up to hunt rear cubs and amongst other things scare off rivals with chorused roars. It turns out the reason why lions work together for mating and other sexual behaviours is because they are not afraid of cubs. Instead they don't roar at cubs but the male lions can see them and have the cubs disqualified.

level1: Dennis Tito is hoping to launch the capsule to Mars by 5 January 2018, but he has a problem – it’s not yet fully ready to use and will need to be refined. It will then fly back to Earth via the same ‘Martian gravity’ to return to Earth. The capsule, named Lunar Express, was designed as a four-person capsule to travel to Mars from Earth and then return home using “Mars gravity”. It will be powered by a battery-powered electric motor. It will be up there about 100km above Mars, making for a very long round trip. It will take two people, two crew members and a pilot. There will be a two-person crew for the first round trip to Mars, but it’s understood a crew of two will be necessary for the second round trip, so it’s not clear who will pilot the capsule. As well as being able to read the Martian landscape, the crew members will also be able to listen to the Martian chants in their cabin. “Mars is a big place. I’m sure there’s going to be some stuff we’ll have to learn, but it’s not going to be like what we have on Earth. Those are not so big questions. I think we can do that. We have a very good crew size. We have a good crew size,” said Tito
level2_fkg: Mars will soon become home to the first human mission, if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito’s plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 actually lead to fruition. Space traveler Dennis Tito has launched a private mission to launch a capsule to Mars on January 5, 2018, which the Los Angeles Times describes as a “remarkable endeavor”. A report on the mission says: “At the onset of its maiden voyage, our craft would have reached the Martian atmosphere and be at its greatest speed, approaching Mars at the speed of light”. Afterwards, the capsule would take the astronauts “almost 160 km above Mars” where, using the gravity of Mars, it would return to Earth without burning up any more fuel.
level2_cefr: A multi-millionaire has launched his private mission to Mars, with the pair – known as the Mars One couple – undergoing extensive screening and selection procedures.
level3_fkg: Mars needs humans to begin a new era of civilisation and space exploration if billionaire Dennis Tito’s plan to launch a capsule in 2018 actually leads to fruition. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use the gravity of Mars to allow it to return to Earth without burning any more fuel for fuel efficiency is a priority – the 2018 deadline has been fixed since the next launch window when Mars and Earth align again isn’t until 2031.
level3_cefr: Tito’s plan is the only one so far with any hope of landing on Mars since he is waiting for Mars and Earth to align themselves again. He has already funded the construction of a new rocket to carry the capsule to Mars as well as the cost of the crew. The first mission is expected to cost around $100 million, a large sum even by space technology standards. The next Mars mission isn’t expected to cost more than $150 million, as it will be a privately owned spaceship in which a group of Europeans and Japanese are expected. The capsule is backed by a group of billionaires and will include a capsule and a crew of eight. The capsule will take the crew to 160 km above Mars and will use the gravity of Mars to allow it to return to Earth without burning any more fuel. Fuel efficiency is a priority because the next launch window when Mars and Earth align again isn’t until 2031. Tito said the plans are “adventurous” as well as “soon to be mainstream” news.
level4_fkg: Dennis Tito is planning a mission to Mars with his partner Roberto Cavanagh and their 3 year old daughter, Luna. They will travel to Mars from Earth with the help of an unmanned capsule that will be launched on the 5 January 2018, with the aim of returning to Earth without any more fuel.
level4_cefr: A multi-millionaire, Dennis Tito, is working hard to launch his capsule on 5 January 2018 from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The spacecraft will use the gravity of Mars to allow it to return to Earth without burning any more fuel. He said: “The next launch window when Mars and Earth align again isn’t until 2031. ” That means his spacecraft will have to be launched and returned to Earth by 2031. That means the two astronauts will need to be physically and emotionally robust. If the mission goes ahead, Dennis Tito plans to go from Cape Canaveral to Mars by 2030 and then back to Earth by 2031. There are currently 73 human spaceflight programmes and over 1,400 unmanned missions to Mars. Tito says there are around 1,500 people who would be ready to go on the first mission to Mars. He is hoping that the number of people willing to go will rise to 1,000 in the next ten years. Dennis Tito says he has had dozens of people call him to ask him about going on the mission, saying: “I haven’t had any negative responses so far. I’m still deciding.” He says it takes him about a month to choose the ten best people he will choose from. He says that if an astronaut wants to sign up he must tell him he’s willing to go. The maximum number of people

level1: “All households pay for the service out of local taxes,” says economist Mark Robinson. That's a fair description, but not all households are equal. Here's why. The average American family produces almost 12 pounds (4.6 kg) of rubbish each week, about 42% of the average family's entire yearly trash output. But with an average family of four generating 20 pounds (4.9 kg) of rubbish each week, only two households will be paying anything. “The other half of households generate only five pounds (0.16 kg) of rubbish,” says Robinson. The reason is that dumping too much rubbish into landfills (which isn't a big deal by itself) creates environmental problems and costs money. As Robinson notes in his new book, "When to Do It: An In-depth Analysis of the Benefits, Burdens, and Implications of Commercial Refuse Collection," putting a levy on each bag of garbage would reduce the amount of trash being dumped. In this way, residents would reduce their garbage production, which means fewer bags are tossed into landfills, which results in fewer problems, for both society and the environment. For the average family, he calculates, that means at least $6.45 of extra money paid for recycling, and at least $29.20 spent on landfill costs. And on the positive side, the average American family will spend $8,250 less
level2_fkg: What if we charged people for each bag of rubbish they produced? It would be environmentally sound and economically sensible. But it would also make it more likely that people would just throw more rubbish into the bins, creating more pollution. What if there was a way to sort waste by materials before it entered the refuse stream? We've got a solution that would solve these problems.
level2_cefr: Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems environmentally sound and economically sensible. But it may not be. Some rituals of modern domestic living vary little throughout the developed world. One such is the municipal refuse collection: at regular intervals rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into the bowels of a special lorry and are carried away to the local tip. To economists this ceremony is peculiar because, in most places, it is free. Yes, households pay for the service out of local taxes but the family that fills four bins with rubbish each week pays no more than the elderly couple that fills one. The problem is that there are many households that would not be able to afford the service. They may only use it at certain times of the year when it is convenient for them. They could not afford it and had to find a way for a second or third income. It may be possible to charge each family for each bag of rubbish they produce, but it would be more expensive for a single family to dump just one sack of rubbish rather than more. There is no obvious incentive to throw rubbish out because it is free. The free service can be turned into a paid service if people wanted to pay more for it. This can be done either by charging a fee for bags or by raising the tax on the sale of waste goods.
level3_fkg: This is a very interesting idea for recycling and reducing environmental pollution. However, it can be very unpopular with many householders. So could this not be done differently? The solution is to charge families for each bag of rubbish they produce, or at least each family that produces four bags per week. This would help with recycling and reduce pollution because the rubbish would be split into smaller pieces and put back together again. Another way this could be done is to limit the number of rubbish bags that can be placed into the recycling bin, if it can be recycled.

level1: The event was held by the Buccoo School committee and was a success for the local community. I was impressed with the effort that the committee had made to bring this to fruition and was pleased to see the local community in full support of the sport.
level2_fkg: I was about to witness goat racing. Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was fighting my way through ice-cream vans hordes of people food stalls and hot music singeing my eardrums. Even though the general movement was towards the racecourse, I elbowed my way through the crowds in an effort to get a good pitch. An area had been cordoned off to make a course for competitors. Not quite on a par with established racecourses but on the similar assumption that spectators were to line either side of a stretch of ground along which the participants would travel.

level4_cefr: My friend walked towards me, and said, 'You come to the goat races, don't you?' "You've come to the goat races, don't you?" "Yes, you are," I replied, and he walked away. "But you're the spectator! You are the most important spectator here."

level1: The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone’s testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience. In an interview, each party is affected by the other. It is the historian who selects the informant and indicates the area of interest; and even if he or she asks no questions and merely listens, the presence of an outsider affects the atmosphere in which the informant recalls the past and talks about it. The end product is conditioned both by the historian’s social position vis-à-vis the informant and by the terms in which he or she has learnt to analyse the past and which may well be communicated to the informant.

level1: Lancelot couldn’t imagine what could have happened to make his secretary forget such things. It could have been something as simple as a break in her duties as a secretary. He wondered if the secretary needed some help to remember to take the sugar or if it was down to a simple case of forgetfulness on her part, which it surely was.
level2_fkg: Lancelot's secretary had an ulterior motive and he knew it. She asked him if he would like a sugary drink. 'Yes,' said Lancelot, grinning. "I'll be back later," she said. "I'm not a witch," Lancelot replied. "I don't have one." "So, what's it for?" Lancelot asked. "Well if you want something sugary you would better have it after I've made you some tea." She looked away but a sudden flash of inspiration gave her a new idea. "I may well have forgotten the sugar, but I'll take the beans."
level2_cefr: Lancelot was an author and playwright. He was sometimes there for a long time. He was not expected to be there. Lancelot was not a hapless dogsbody.
level3_fkg: Lancelot thought about it, for a moment he was able to stand on two legs but he realised that in the process he had turned into a dope in the eyes of his people. 'You don’t take sugar do you?' asked Lancelot.
level3_cefr: Lancelot shook his head. Awkwardly he turned and headed for the door. It was all very confusing. The security guard said he was standing near the entrance but he could not make it through the metal detector and the staff had turned round with warning signs. There was a police officer near the door, he said, pointing at the key, but he could not open the door because there was a barricade in the way. The only way he could get through it was to get up and leave. Lancelot was the last person he would expect to see, although this did not deter them as other staff members followed.
level4_fkg: You don’t take sugar do you? shouted his secretary. Not so much asking a question as stating a fact, as well she might because she had been making Lancelot cups of coffee for many months. Her excuse for forgetting such things was that he wasn’t normally supposed to be there. Actually nowadays he was usually there all the time having discovered that to take up his proprietorial privilege of staying away was tantamount to opening the floodgates. Not for the first time he pondered the easy, imperceptibly divided stages by which he had progressed from valued counsellor meeting authors and playwrights over lunch at carefully planned planning meetings complete with agenda to hapless dogsbody moving one step ahead of catastrophe with nowhere to park when he arrived at work in the mornings.

level1: Susan saw that the removal van had been named ‘Removers of Distinction’ and in fact, every distinguishing feature of the house had been removed. Everything which made the house particular was being wrapped in newspaper and packed in boxes by Fred the removal man his enormous fingers like sausages tenderly handling all the breakables and his team of helpers not so gentle. It was a lovely house that she was leaving. An elegant four-storeyed building overlooking a tiny harbour. The years she had spent there the years of the children growing up and leaving hung around in the air faintly present like agitated dust.
level2_fkg: Susan took a deep breath and leaned forward to look at the incoming van. The van was bright red and the lettering read ‘Removal of Distinction’.
level2_cefr: Susan was getting very emotional as she walked towards the main door. Fred the removal man was approaching. He showed her his stubby fingers like sausages which he wrapped in newspaper carefully and then started to put things in boxes. She looked at Fred with a smile. ”I must have taken something with me to give to you?” he asked. She looked up and smiled back. “Yes, Fred, I am sorry that I caused any damage to your furniture or anything else but I am only sorry that I did not know about the house’s history when I put the furniture into the boxes, and I did not know that the paint on the walls was a colour called ‘Sensitive’. I know that a lot of people think that, but I was just a little shocked by what I saw in your house. I had a dream that I would return in a few years and I saw you sitting on the doorstep. Did you know that I am the one who brought the furniture from the house to the van?” Fred said sarcastically. I paused for a moment before continuing. “Well, your new home isn’t as nice as it could be. It’s a bit more ‘shabby chic’ than the other houses in our area. That was always my aim, to give it that ‘old world’ feel. That was exactly why I wanted

level1: It is easy for us to focus on our children and the technology we use every day when they are young, when they are absorbing information about the world around them. But what are they really learning? Well, this has become a familiar narrative. A lot of children’s and young people’s early learning will be skewed by their screen time. Whether we like it or not, our children are still developing their brains before we are ready to start thinking about what they are learning on a more permanent level. For this reason, we need to stop the endless, mind-numbing repetition of screens for learning. It’s good practice to put learning down into practice. Let’s stop thinking about screens as if they’re the answer to every learning problem. Instead, let’s talk about how to get children interested in learning and teach them on a meaningful and lasting basis. It’s a subject that has been the subject of much controversy. But it isn’t just about learning about dinosaurs and other prehistoric animals. It’s also about how to teach kids to become aware of other kinds of information, such as weather conditions, plants, animals and so on. We need to be talking about how to find out about things – to ask, “Is there snow in Australia?”, “What are the differences between sand in the desert?” “How do ants look?”, “
level2_fkg: Screen learning can be very useful for learning. But there are some risks. It may reduce the depth of understanding in the young child, he may learn less in one session than in a few. There may be a danger of being distracted. Several children have been harmed when they have learned online. Another parent has been accused of inappropriately educating their children.
level2_cefr: This article is about screen learning. There is no evidence to suggest that it is a good method, and the writer’s argument that this was the case is largely wrong. Screen learning requires little concentration, a lot of eye-tracking and often little interaction with other people. It also fails to involve the development of new skills, such as concentration.
level3_fkg: I am surprised to find that your son didn’t remember much about dinosaurs. So it is best to put them to bed and to return to the familiar. For most children, it is better to talk and re-tell the stories that you read to them. For me it is better to go to the movies with them rather than reading them to them.
level3_cefr: Screen learning is a modern phenomenon. The Internet and computer programmes now account for more of children’s learning than all other educational materials combined. The problem is that children learn in different ways. Some prefer to hear or read; others are more interested in seeing pictures. When they do read, they need to comprehend the text because it’s in a language that they can understand. That means that when they are watching TV, they have to learn the language of the programme, with all its visuals. This type of learning is often a bit immature, and children’s minds are not yet fully formed. However, there is still a place for screen learning. It’s part of a wide-ranging attempt to teach children about the world, so it’s better than nothing. In this case, what happened was that the child learned the words to a song, but didn’t understand how to use them. There was no need to be able to read the words. The child was able to make up a story by talking about things he’d seen online. This type of learning is often referred to as rote learning, which has the effect that children often need to re-learn their knowledge. One thing I did like about screen learning with my son was that he was interested in learning as I spoke. By saying the words he’d just learned as he went along,
level4_fkg: Screen Learning A few days ago I noticed my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth while trying to look fierce. ‘I’m a little dinosaur’ he said. He was play-acting a scene from a recent TV programme so I quizzed him about what he remembered about dinosaurs. The answer was not much. There is a modish rush to embrace internet and computer learning but is learning via a screen a good method? One writer tells how he tried out an interactive programme with his son. The father diligently read the words while the son fiddled with the pictures.
level4_cefr: Screen Learning A few days ago I noticed my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth while trying to look fierce. ‘I’m a little dinosaur’ he said. He was play-acting a scene from a recent TV programme so I quizzed him about what he remembered about dinosaurs. The answer was not a lot. There is a modish rush to embrace the internet and computer learning but is learning via a screen a good method? One writer tells me about how he tried out an interactive programme with his son. The father diligently read the words while the son fiddled with the pictures.

level1: The Bambu Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, buys you a computer-designed custom frame plus a fun weekend of bike-building. “What made you want to run this course was that the design process consists of a computer modelling of how the bike will sit and ride and then a CNC-cut prototype frame that is built up in the workshop. The CNC machine builds the frame out of solid bamboo and is operated by one of the engineers,” Marr says. That process is done in a small room set up in a former paint shop in Hackney Wick, east London. The two engineers – James Marr and Ian McMillan – had done extensive research in the sustainable manufacturing of bamboo frames and decided the best way to ensure they were cost effective was to enlist the help of others in the bicycle industry. So, they contacted a number of industry-leading computer designers and made their designs available for free to anyone interested in making their own frame. This is how the Bambu bikes were born. Marr and McMillan designed the frame with their partners, and took advantage of the opportunities offered by the raw bamboo. Each member of the frame is also able to choose a colour from a range of ten. They can also mix their own colours using the Bambu colours, and add a variety of other options.
level2_fkg: The Bamboo Bike Club runs an experimental, computer-designed bike-building course in Hackney Wick, east London. Students start with a pre-designed bike frame using a computer software, then turn it into a hand-made bike after being guided by two engineers who teach the class about bamboo and the engineering that goes into making it. A bike's frame is one of the first things to be made; the bike's parts include a frame fork, handlebars and seatpost. A computer designed frame can be made using any material, a bamboo bicycle frame, for example, would not be the same as a titanium bike frame. James Marr, who started the workshop, runs it together with Ian McMillan, an engineer from the University of Bristol, who makes and sells bespoke bicycle frames. The pair say that there is a growing trend for cyclists who ride bikes to get to work and commute to work or for leisure, for instance, because it is good for the environment, good for health and better for the health of others. As a bike is made from a piece of material based on a template, the final part must be made by hand, which is where it gets its name. The workshop is a mix of workshops and classrooms, with some people working on their own bikes and others being guided. Some students build their own bikes, while others choose to take a course
level2_cefr: The ride isn’t pretty, but it’s the only way of seeing Hackney Wick – a sprawling industrial estate in east London that’s home to the most innovative bicycle workshop in the country. The bike-building school is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. The nascent bike-building school was born out of a dream forged by the pair over two decades ago to build high-end bicycle frames made from bamboo, an eco-friendly and largely renewable material. It was conceived after seeing a similar workshop run at Bicycleworks, an engineering firm based in north-west London. “There’s a lot of opportunity for us in Britain,” Mr Marr told a BBC team in December. But the club has had its share of drawbacks. The company struggled to find the right location, and the bikes built by the group aren’t very good. They’re not very good, either. A bicycle should be more like a car, with the frame sitting between the wheels and the road. But even after one year, the bikes are still wobbly. “The bikes squeak and they’re noisy, too,” says the owner of one workshop. This is no ordinary bike building course, however. It takes place over two weekends, and the only thing you get for your money is the frame and a weekend of
level3_fkg: A bike with an engine powered by solar cells is just one of the items on the bike-building course at Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan in Hackney Wick.
level3_cefr: The bamboo bike is a renewable resource that requires little maintenance. There are more than 40 million bamboo stalks in Asia and the Americas combined, making it one of nature’s most sustainable materials. But there has been little in the way of bamboo bicycles in the UK, where it has previously been unavailable. Engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan have set up the Bamboo Bike Club in Hackney Wick to help bike-enthusiasts – both novices and pros – turn their hands to building a bike from scratch. They spend two weekends in Hackney, creating a computer-designed frame and teaching how to ride. They sell the frames, which are made of carbon-reinforced bamboo, and teach a two-part bike-building course that culminates with a ride to the coast. The final price is £750 for the frame, with the workshop open to members only, and the cost of materials. To pay the fees, members get the frame, as well as a two-day workshop and a two-course dinner.
level4_fkg: A computer design of a bike with integrated lights, baskets, saddle, handlebars and mudguards is created using three dimensional CAD software. For £400 you get a computer-designed custom frame, plus a fun weekend of bike-building.
level4_cefr: Two engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan say they want to turn their workshop in Hackney Wick into the UK’s first bicycle factory and a fun weekend of bike-building. There’s excitement too because the bikes will be made by hand. James takes me round the workshops, showing me various machines, and you can try out some of their bikes. You’ll be building a custom frame from scratch by hand, and will get to choose the bamboo that goes into it. It’s a nice contrast to the computer models used by a lot of bike-builders, who are mostly made from steel or aluminium. As I watch James he has an idea for a bike I might like. “We’d all like to build a really fast bike,” he says. The bikes are computer-designed, so your bike will be different. The frames are made from a high-quality bamboo that’s cut in to a thin strips by hand. James says it’s as if you’re making your own violin. Each frame costs 900 pounds ($1,600), but the bikes are so much fun to build that the cost of the bike would be low and you can have a blast with the bike. The builders tell me that the frames are lightweight and easy to fold, and the course lasts two and a half days. I’ve been able to watch most of the workshop

level1: The strange male realised he had been duped and fled, and as a result the group had to get used to not having a rival.
level2_fkg: The vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth describe how one day the dominant male in the group of vervet monkeys they were studying noticed a strange male hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger’s intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it. If he succeeded, it was more than likely that the incumbent male would be ousted from his position of privilege. With the vervet equivalent of a stroke of genius, the male hit on the ideal ploy to keep the stranger away from his group. As soon as the strange male descended from the grove of trees to try to cross the open ground that separated his grove from the one in which the group was feeding he gave an alarm call that vervet monkeys use to signal the sighting of a leopard nearby.
level2_cefr: Cheney and Seyfarth tell of a vervet monkey group that they were studying. One day, one of the males noticed that a stranger was hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger’s intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it. If he succeeded, it was more than likely that the incumbent male would be ousted from his position of privilege. With the vervet equivalent of a stroke of genius, the male hit on the ideal ploy to keep the stranger away from his group. As soon as the strange male descended from the grove of trees to try to cross the open ground that separated his grove from the one in which the group was feeding, he gave an alarm call that vervets use to signal the sighting of a leopard nearby. As he descended, he sounded this alarm. As he fell, he made a small ‘tuck-tuck’ motion in his body as he dropped into the water. When he swam away, it was with a scream that many other monkeys heard. The rest of the group knew just who the alarm caller was, as they recognized the sound of his alarm call as coming from their male.
level3_fkg: Vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth describe how one day the dominant male in the group of vervet monkeys they were studying noticed a strange male hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger’s intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it. If he succeeded, it was more than likely that the incumbent male would be ousted from his position of privilege. With the vervet equivalent of a stroke of genius, the male hit on the ideal ploy to keep the stranger away from his group. As soon as the strange male descended from the grove of trees to try to cross the open ground that separated his grove from the one in which the group was feeding he gave an alarm call that vervets use to signal the sighting of a leopard nearby.

level1: AESTHETICS By one of the ironic perversities that often attend the course of affairs the existence of the works of art upon which formation of aesthetic theory depends has become an obstruction to theory about them. For one reason: these works are products that exist externally and physically. In common conception the work of art is often identified with the building book painting or statue in its existence apart from human experience. Since the actual work of art is what the product does with and in experience the result is not favourable to understanding. In addition the very perfection of some of these products, the prestige they possess because of a long history of unquestioned admiration creates conventions that get in the way of fresh insight.

level1: Sand Much as I admire sands miraculous ability to be transformed into useful objects like glass and concrete, I am not a great fan of it in its natural state. To me, sand is primarily a hostile barrier that stands between a seaside car park and the water itself. It blows in your face, gets in your sandwiches and swallows vital objects like car keys and coins. When you are wet, it adheres to you like ‘stucco' and cannot be shifted even with a fireman’s hose. But and here’s the strange thing — the moment you step onto a beach towel, climb into a car or walk across a recently vacuumed carpet, it pours off you. Sand tends to stick to our bodies when wet, but there is a different type of sand that is soluble in water and does not adhere when wet. It is water-soluble, and is found naturally in the ocean. When the water evaporates from the sand, the dissolved water is drawn to the surface and evaporated. Unlike sand, this water-soluble sand is less likely to stick to you.

level1: American Visions is a very disappointing series, but it is not the only one. The other series to make a bad impression is ITV’s British Art. At the moment ITV has taken on the challenge of making art available to those who can only view it through a DVD. The British Art website has an enticing programme called In Search of an Artist. This series is set up to take you through a variety of artists, some well known and some little known. You can watch a selection of episodes in the archive on the ITV website. This programme, commissioned by BBC, also makes an excellent introduction to the idea of viewing art in a virtual way. For me this is a very good idea, it should give people an opportunity to see work in a way that is accessible and not just restricted to the physical world. However, there is also a danger of simply looking at artworks and having a look at them. After watching all eight episodes it is a real treat to see a sculpture, or a painting or an installation in its natural environment. In other words we get a lot of the effect, but what is so great about the real world is that it is a very different world and much to admire. The programme also highlights how the art business has changed from art centres with walls of paintings and sculptures to business centres with large amounts of money invested and people who come along
level2_fkg: Why is it that television so consistently fails when it comes to programmes about the visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be natural subjects for the camera which has the ability to show a whole work of art then move in close to examine the details. Yet I can think of few series on television that have managed to convey both the pleasure and complexity of looking at them. A good example of what goes wrong can be seen in Robert Hughes’s eight part survey of American art American Visions. Hughes is a critic you can trust he has a personality that commands attention and he has been given nearly eight hours in which to introduce British audiences to a school of art that British galleries have totally ignored.

level1: To all you fans of the actor, the craft is simply a set of rules you play by: When an actor is on stage, he or she has to know how to play by those rules and not the other way around. The rules are like arrows in a bow. They pierce the soul of the character and drive it into the wall of the audience, which in turn drives them into the wall of their head and out of the audience, which is an exercise in futility. The actor who is always trying to break the rules is always trying to get at the soul of the character and not the soul of the character. It is hard to break the rules on the stage, but only the actor with a brain can break them. That’s why we see “Hallelujah!” when an actor smashes the “Bridge of Spies” in The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe. When people talk about acting and talk about the craft, many of them just want to prove their mettle, so they don’t have to do anything and can focus all of their energy on the craft and the characters. This is exactly what they do. The first part is the hardest: a good actor tries to go beyond what is expected of him or her. If it’s not a good enough performance, the performance isn’t good enough. The second part is the easiest. The first
level2_fkg: The Actor’s Craft Derision and contempt are sprayed at actors from time to time. Much of this disdain is fuelled by the actors themselves when they’re compelled by their film/theatre companies to talk about their craft (and themselves) in interviews. They should give the dancer Pavlova’s reply to the man who asked her what she meant when she was dancing: ‘If I could tell you’ she said ‘I wouldn’t dance it.’ But instead they all too easily fall into ponderous clichés silly truisms or into the prurient jaws of the gossip machine. We should all pay heed to what Paul Scofield said in a letter to a friend of mine: ‘I have found that an actor’s work has life and interest only in its execution.’
