level1: As we enter the twenty-first century, there is an urgent need to rethink the nature of work and the way it affects us as people. The problem, says Theodore Zeldin, is that we have lost the ability to question how our jobs shape us and why they change us. We work out of fear, not of what is to come but because we fear the future. It is as if we are ignoring the fundamental questions of human nature by settling for short-term solutions - and then regretting that decision when a better solution emerges. "Success in a career no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued and understood and even among individuals who have won eminence there is often bitterness behind the fame," he writes. The writer is co-author of a book, "Warrior's Creed". As well as writing, he co-directs The Good Life Project and an education program at the National Association of Colleges and Employers in Seattle.
level2_fkg: Are you as respected and appreciated as you deserve? Success in a career is no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued and understood and even among individuals who have won eminence there is often bitterness behind the fame. Loving your work until recently was enough to make you a member of an envied minority. But now you have to ask yourself what your job is doing to you as a person, to your mind, character and relationships. This question is crucial.
level2_cefr: Will we be satisfied with our lives if we do not take a little time out of our day jobs to read books, read novels, watch TV, etc? We are no longer content in our comfortable homes. We need stimulation, freedom of choice and stimulation to keep ourselves active and young. Is the job you are in doing something that will bring you satisfaction and fulfilment? Have you achieved any of these things? If so, then you are not happy. Sadly, the world of work is not the same as it was when Theodore Zeldin was a young man. He is now 60 and looking back at the working life he had at the time. Theodore Zeldin believes that the working life of his generation could easily be radically different. He wonders whether the problem is our increasing reliance on machine technologies and the fact that the working life of most people has become more competitive. He questions whether our working life is really worthwhile and whether we can have more leisure time. Can we actually find time to read books and play sport? How much time do we have to spend with friends and family? Is it possible to have time to write? Does having time to read have a positive impact on our health, wellbeing and mental health? Is the feeling of achievement that comes with doing a good job enough to make us happy? The answer to these questions is not always easy to answer. Most people are satisfied with their

level1: There are about 400,000 words in our language, roughly one word for every letter in the alphabet. As you may or may not know, these words are not actually words. In fact, they are made up of a combination of phonological patterns. In the language that you and I use, when we speak, the sounds of the English language are like a musical symphony: they can make a brain in your brain vibrate like a violin or a violin string, or like a chimpanzee’s heart beat when it hears its name. In the other language we use, when we speak, the words we use can make sounds like a rat’s snarl when it hears its name. In the language that we use, when we hear, the words can make sounds like a dog’s bark or the sounds made by a kitten. A word that has several phonological patterns and many of the sounds of other languages has one single phonological pattern and one single phoneme, which is the same as the phonemes of the German language. The number of different phonemes in the language of language is called morphology. There are 20 major morphologies that make up the language that we use. I believe there are 20 major morphologies that make up language. In general, a morphology is the set of morphological
level2_fkg: Language You and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability. We can shape events in each others brains with exquisite precision. Language is so tightly woven into our human experience that it is scarcely possible to imagine life without it. Chances are that if you find two or more people together anywhere on earth they will soon be exchanging words. When there is no one to talk with, people talk to themselves, their dogs, even to their plants. I like to describe the skill of language as an ‘instinct.’ This conveys the idea that people know how to talk in more or less the sense that spiders know how to spin webs.

level1: Kinetic Art Rejoice is a brilliantly small and unassuming exhibition at London’s Hayward Gallery. It’s the most interesting, unusual and delightfully eccentric investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. Rather than the huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media spectacle that so many museums are turning their backs on, this one has a clear point, a point you won’t be able to ignore. It’s well-presented, thoughtfully organised and a joy to wander through. It has a strong sense of place and is easily accessible for all. It’s an event I recommend if you’re in the capital, or if you’ve ever wondered what ‘kinetic’ or ‘eclectic’ art is.
level2_fkg: "Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder." A new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery traces the history of kinetic art, that is art which is concerned with movement. In the process, it reveals that making artworks which either move by themselves or investigate the idea of movement in some way has been a consistent but largely unrecognised theme of some of the most fascinating creative activity of this century. Almost every exhibition I’ve been to, either as curator or collector, has been concerned with the kinetic arts, i.e. the movement of objects. And I’ve never been so excited to see a room full of interesting and exciting works of kinetic art. The exhibition starts with a long introductory lecture focusing on the history of the movement in art. It includes more than 40 artists including John Bellamy, Ray Bradbury, Willem de Kooning, and Charles Ray. The lecture includes information about their work, including the significance of movement, and how it changed art. One of the highlights of the lecture is a piece which uses a hammer to smash a vase against the wall. The art itself is rather striking, with a bold red abstract work by Paul Gauguin, as well as pieces by Alberto Giacometti, Ernst Ludwig
level2_cefr: A new exhibition has taken over a London gallery and turned it into a place full of wonder. Taking visitors on a journey through the history of kinetic art, the new show starts with the invention of the clock and goes on to show how kinetic art is a central theme in the work of many of the leading artists in the field. By tracing the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — the exhibition reveals that making artworks which either move by themselves or investigate the idea of movement in some way has been a consistent, if largely unrecognised, theme of some of the most fascinating creative activity of this century. One remark: “It is a little like tinkering with a broken clock - you don’t do it perfectly - but the kinetic movement is interesting.” I love it when I get to see my favourite work, especially one that had me baffled and smiling in front of it. I think the most astonishing of all is 'The Clock Movement', which is basically a giant clock that has been moved by its owner. But then there are a whole host of other pieces — some very clever and quite beautiful. I especially enjoyed 'The Moon Walk' which involves two'snakes' with magnets attached which move one at a time, so that they
level3_fkg: Kinetic Art traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century. It starts with the work of Alberto Giacometti in 1931, when he exhibited a sculpture known as the ‘Mother and Child’. Giacometti was an Italian-born artist who worked in oil, the same medium as the other kinetic artists, such as the Russian-born artist László Moholy-Nagy and the German-born artist Anselm Kiefer. They created sculptures such as the ‘Wave’, and the ‘Crystal’, both of which are presented in the exhibition. Other artists who work in kinetic art include the Austrian-born artist Josef Albers, whose ‘Cycles’ is an enormously complex work in which hundreds of wooden discs – mounted on a rotating plinth – generates a dance of sounds in the gallery’s vast room. Some of these kinetic works seem designed to be enjoyed by both the viewer and the viewer’s pet cat: a glass of wine slowly swings upwards, a cat leaps in response, and a tiger is chased by a tiger as it chases it in an open air room. But others are more subtle: works by the German-born artist Karl
level3_cefr: Kinetic Art, a new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London, has uncovered many wonderful and rare works of kinetic art that are now showing to great interest. Rather than focusing on how kinetic art has been made, as some exhibitions do, it instead focuses on why it has been so popular and why it has continued to be so popular, and why it will continue to be popular into the future. This is a great article for any language learner.
level4_fkg: After the success of the new exhibition that explores the history of kinetic art, the Hayward Gallery has now reopened after a significant renovation. The museum is now known for its wonderful collections, but one aspect of its new look was the restoration of a small but important kinetic art gallery. Located at 7 King’s Road, near Hyde Park, the gallery’s name was changed to Kinetic Art in a sign of the hope it had for the future of the space it had been housed in for several years. The new kinetic art exhibition is the first time the Hayward Gallery has had its very own kinetic art gallery for many years. It is a rare opportunity to see such an extensive collection of kinetic art all in one place. It also combines an in-depth analysis of the kinetic art movement in a fascinating way. The new space, a former garage and one formerly used for a church, contains many of the best pieces, like the large ‘Castle in the Air’ made in the 1960s. This is the perfect place to watch the moving, intricately designed and incredibly complex piece. It is an exhibition of kinetic art that is not only an exciting display, but one that tells the story of kinetic art itself in a way that is both beautiful and thoughtful.
level4_cefr: Kinetic Art Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not thankfully by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media spectacle but by a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century. In the process it reveals that making artworks which either move by themselves or investigate the idea of movement in some way has been a consistent if largely unrecognised theme of some of the most fascinating creative activity of this century.

level1: After the success of their breakout album “Stone Cold” in 1956, Paul Simon and Ringo Starr had their first recording session with producer Jack White, who was responsible for both the psychedelic rock of Pink Floyd’s “Under Pressure” and the lilting folky melodies of The Rolling Stones’ “Chain Reaction.” When Simon became more aware of White’s role in producing the album, he turned to Freed, who was promoting the album with a full-band session. After his first session, Simon began recording songs with White, and began playing them on Moondog with White, starting with a cover of Little Richard’s “Seasons of Love.” When Freed asked Simon to sing “Little Girls” to a recording of the Beatles’ “On the Road Again,” Simon agreed to do so. He added a line on the cover that read, “If the Beatles ate every word, then the Beatles ate me.” For White, the song represented a call-back to his earlier hits, a sentiment that resonated with Simon. “It feels like my parents took over the radio station after me,” Simon wrote. But White, who would go on to produce his next two albums, had just left Moondog. Simon was already planning his first recording session, which took place in June of 1956. While he was listening to
level2_fkg: Rock and roll in the 1950s was primarily a youth cult, but its lasting importance lay in the seismic impact it had on the middle class and the middle-aged. It also paved the way for the next generation of rock idols who listened to it awestruck and aware that this strange, unsettling sound would somehow irrevocably be linked with their destinies. For Paul Simon as for other youngsters in the US, the chief opportunity for hearing this new and invigorating type of music that was sweeping the country was courtesy of Alan Freed’s radio show Moondog Rock’n’Roll Party.

level1: POETRY RECITALS At any given time in history the literary scene will seem confused to those who are living through it and it is the selectivity of posterity that makes the pattern and orders of eminence appear clearly defined to the retrospective view. It is fairly safe to say that at the present time there is an especially bewildering complexity of poetic tendencies of kinds of poetry being written, of warring factions of ways of presenting, criticising and teaching poetry and of conflicting beliefs about the role of the poet in society. It is fairly safe to say that at the present time there is an especially bewildering complexity of poetic tendencies of kinds of poetry being written, of warring factions of ways of presenting, criticising and teaching poetry and of conflicting beliefs about the role of the poet in society. Very broadly speaking, the present debate in contemporary poetry concerns the reciprocal mistrust and disapproval shown by the seriously committed 'literary' writers whose poems are intended to be printed and read on the page and the ‘popular’ performing poets who while they will probably publish their verses in magazines and collections are happier declaiming them to an audience.

level1: An infant's tears may show more helplessness than a grown woman's, but a new study from the University of Missouri suggests a new era in crying is just beginning.
level2_fkg: CRYING Charles Darwin thought that the human tendency to cry had no obvious evolutionary purpose. He was almost certainly wrong. More recently scientists have pointed to its social significance, with psychiatrist John Bowlby highlighting the role of crying in developing the attachment between a mother and a child. Many believe that tears at least during childhood are mainly an expression of helplessness. However, the persistence of crying into adulthood is harder to explain. It seems that the sound of crying becomes considerably less important than the visual signal it conveys. It may have been advantageous to early human communities as a means of promoting trust and social connectedness.

level1: It’s been a fun last couple of weeks. I thought I would share a photo of a couple I’ve been seeing in the blogosphere, as well as a photo that I took at a recent party in Toronto, where I took a lot of photos of my fellow bloggers in the #bloggersphere. I also wanted to share a picture that I took of my friend (that I’m not really sure of the name) from a local restaurant. Not a photo of a restaurant where we’ve had lunch, it’s just a picture of her and me with food – we had a nice lunch together when we were at the same restaurant. That’s not all: my friend is also the co-owner of the restaurant next to where we ate, and we also worked with her to create a logo for the restaurant. You’d never know unless we showed you. On our social media platforms, some things are private, and there are a lot of things I can’t share. On Facebook, for example, my Facebook friend list has only a couple of friends, but I’m still posting there, so we might as well be friends. My colleague is using LinkedIn to build a professional network in Toronto, and we have a similar set of social media connections in Toronto. On Instagram, we don’t have as many people, but we can
level2_fkg: Blogging: Confessing to the world Some time ago a website highlighted the risks of public check-ins – online announcements of your whereabouts. The site’s point was blunt: you may think you are just telling the world ‘Hey I’m at this place’ – but you are also advertising your out-and-about-ness to all kinds of people everywhere – not all of them people you might like to bump into. This appeared to confirm the growing awareness that there might be a downside to all the frantic sharing the web has enabled. The vast new opportunities to publish any and every aspect of our lives to a potentially global audience hold out all sorts of tantalising possibilities: wealth!

level1: Food There is something very elemental and satisfying about our relationship with food. I know I may be preaching to the converted because presumably people keen on cooking buy cookery books like this one but so often we imagine that unless it is some special occasion or an especially elaborate dish it is hardly worth attempting. Not so. Just by throwing a few roughly chopped carrots, a leek, some celery and a few herbs into water you will get the most delicious soup. This is much more satisfying than buying a packet or opening a tin. Instead of buying an over-sweet chocolate mousse full of preservatives emulsifiers and additives, in five minutes you can turn out the most delicious confection that both grown-ups and children will love.

level1: We are presented with a series of hypothetical situations involving two types of chef. You have a kitchen at work. You have a kitchen at home. You have a kitchen at home and a kitchen at work. You also have a kitchen at home and a kitchen at work. You go to work on a busy day and you get your homework done. You have a kitchen at home and your dishes are delicious. However, if you look at each scenario, you would find that in each situation, the kitchen is either far more or far less efficient. We can use the following hypotheticals as a basis for our analysis: (1) If your job is fast-paced and you have a lot of responsibility, your work time is a lot longer. However, if your job is mundane, you are wasting time doing dull work. (2) If you are a busy chef working in a restaurant, you are not doing much cooking. (3) If you are a busy chef working in a restaurant and you can do more cooking than your colleagues, your work will be much faster. (4) As a busy chef, you work well under pressure. You must be efficient at whatever you do. (5) If you are on your way to work but are about to run over a customer, you have the option to call in your colleagues. But you can’t just walk in to work at any time. You have to
level2_fkg: The Lure of the Kitchen When I was at university I decided I wanted to be a chef. Among my contemporaries this was an unusual choice. Cooking was not one of the plum jobs that most of us wanted. It is on the face of it an unattractive profession. Chefs lead notoriously harsh lives: the work is long, pressured menial and poorly paid. But such considerations didn’t put me off. I was unhappy at university. The work was hard; the social scene was insular and self-important. Being a chef seemed the perfect antidote to intellectual and social posturing. It promised a seriousness and integrity lacking in my college life.

level4_fkg: The Lure of the Kitchen When I was at university I decided I wanted to be a chef. Among my contemporaries, this was an unusual choice. Cooking was not one of the plum jobs that most of us wanted. It is on the face of it an unattractive profession. Chefs lead notoriously harsh lives: the work is long, pressured and menial - and badly paid. But such considerations didn’t put me off. I was unhappy at university. The work was hard; the social scene was insular and self-important. Being a chef seemed the perfect antidote to intellectual and social posturing. It promised a seriousness and integrity lacking in my college life.

level1: I was ushered into the young man’s drawing room, an oasis of cultural sanity surrounded by what appeared to be a quite shambolic cluster of rooms in which the less enterprising members of the family operated. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour was an upgrade from economy to business class. Here was the largest collection of records I had ever seen the first stereo record player and tuner I had ever come across and the astonishing evidence that a teenager existed who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses pictures and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. The record player sounded a bit unrefined, although it was a good stereo unit, and his tuner was clearly in need of servicing. The wine glasses appeared too fragile for an 18-year-old’s discerning palate, though there were wine glasses with other designs on the stems. The only other evidence I saw of a teenager spending money on art and antiques was a series of pictures of classical music in oil paintings. And the wine glasses showed that his father was a collector of fine art. TIM RICE As he opened the fridge he began to pour himself a glass. He then poured himself another. Then another. The next glass he poured himself another. Then another. Then another. The next glass was very good but not excellent. Then another
level2_fkg: Andrew Lloyd Webber has spent a fortune on clothes, furniture and records. What is the first thing that pops into your head about him? It’s not a lot, unless you consider that the collection consists of albums, LPs, singles, compilations, and compilation albums that have been remastered by others. What I find really astonishing is that he was able to afford such purchases when he was at school. The only other thing is that there are more discs than records. The fact that it has been this way for so long is a sign of something. His parents, at home and in school, were indolent.
level2_cefr: TIM RICE The young man shook his head sadly. It was very obvious that he had no intention of getting serious. His room looked nothing like a man who was about to hit the big time. It was quite evident that he did not plan on going through with it. It seemed quite obvious he did not have the money to buy the things he had said that he did. This he had proved at every turn. He had got a job that he liked doing and the money he needed to do it. The only thing he did not do was work for the council. His house seemed to be a mess. He had been on the streets looking for work but had not got anywhere. But he had done an excellent job of saving money – and the credit card was working. He was very proud of this. I thought it was quite an achievement for a teenager to have saved that much money. He could barely afford to buy a drink but could afford to spend hundreds of pounds on Georgian wine glasses and furniture. I thought it would be a good idea to write him a letter and ask him what his plans were for the future. He told me that the children were too young to see much of what was going on and that the house was in terrible shape. But what he told me left me in no doubt. He was making money. He had decided it was time for
level3_fkg: Tim Rice went with the family into the kitchen. It seemed as if they were all on drugs. But before the family got there he looked out his kitchen window, and saw a cigarette end in the air. He guessed what it was, a cigarette dipped in cocaine. He put the cigarette end into the ashtray he had left out for Mr Webber before he left for work. He snorted, but Mr Webber thought he was drunk, so he poured him a glass of water instead.
level3_cefr: TIM RICE I was ushered into the young man’s drawing room, an oasis of cultured sanity surrounded by what appeared to be a quite shambolic cluster of rooms in which the less enterprising members of the family operated. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour was an upgrade from economy to business class. Here was the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had ever come across and the astonishing evidence that a teenager existed who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses pictures and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber.
level4_fkg: TIM RICE Andrew Lloyd Webber was born in London in 1923. He is a British actor singer and screenwriter and has been very successful over the years. Today he plays Lord Byron in the musical Les Miserables and is a successful writer and composer of stage musicals. He is the youngest of seven brothers. His father was well known at the theatre and, on that particular afternoon, was credited with giving a start to the musical revival in Britain. My father would certainly have been proud of his son. He told me that when he was younger he had often been influenced by his mother, whose talents he still admired. His uncle was very well known for being a famous astrologer and the family would often go to the observatory together to watch the astronomers. His mother’s first love was opera and she was also an acclaimed actress. Her husband, Sir Thomas, was very much a sportsman and was one of the most successful astrologers and cricketers of all times. However, he suffered from paranoia and this affected his performances. My father was also extremely proud of his son and although he told me the truth it had caused some concern among his friends. He would never have spoken of his son without his mother’s approval. Mrs. Webber thought it would be very embarrassing for me to see my father in such an elaborate

level1: Advertising on trial Advertisers argue that the UK government’s Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has misled consumers into believing that they were protected by copyright by censoring and scrutinising advertisements for the first time in the agency’s history. The ASA claimed that the government was being unfair when it refused to sanction agencies for misleading consumers about the safety of a product and if they did so were responsible for the poor performance of some of their own agencies. The court was told that all such claims were false because the ads did not comply with the code and the agency did not carry out any work which, as it put it, was “too controversial or inflammatory”. The court decided that the government’s claim was without foundation and dismissed it without costs. The case was heard at the High Court in London on 26 January 1992.
level2_fkg: If you work for an advertising agency the early years of the 1990s may well have been the toughest of your professional life. The recession in business was bad enough. It was longer deeper and more severe than anticipated by even the most pessimistic, hitting industrialised nations as hard as anything else for thirty years. In Britain it meant in 1991 alone that while gross domestic product (GDP) declined, interest rates remained punitive high, consumer spending on almost everything other than staples fell more than half a million people lost their jobs and some 75000 homes were repossessed. Now, a little over two years later, we finally see how the recession has affected advertising in Britain. For years, companies across all industries had suffered from the economic downturn. Nevertheless, the sector continued to work if you look at the way ads were distributed to the public. In the early years of the recession, however, many advertisers had chosen to stop trying to generate revenue through advertising, either by cutting staff or by spending money in other areas. For instance, even in the late 1980s, advertising had often been used to generate revenue for newspapers. In the 1970s, newspapers were not considered to be a viable source of advertising revenue, so, when newspapers began to cut advertising, fewer and fewer newspapers started using this business model as a new source of revenue. The result was that even when the economy was in recovery, newspaper advertising continued
level2_cefr: Advertising on trial If you work for an advertising agency the early years of the 1990s may well have been the toughest of your professional life. The recession in business was bad enough. It was longer, deeper and more severe than anticipated by even the most pessimistic. In Britain it meant in 1991 alone that while gross domestic product (GDP) declined interest rates remained punitive high, consumer spending on almost everything other than staples fell, more than half a million people lost their jobs and some 75000 homes were repossessed.
level3_fkg: As the economy recovered some advertising agencies began to advertise again and so began an upsurge in creativity. By the early 1990s all of the big names in advertising had gone through a major revamp. As the recession eased so too did the size and scope of advertising agencies. There were, though, some exceptions to the pattern. British advertisers still clung to some of their more traditional techniques such as billboards and telemarketing but they have also become more innovative and experiment with new approaches. These changes are often seen as part of a move towards new thinking or a return to the old ways of advertising. And there were, even among the advertising veterans in the late 1990s, some examples of the new thinking.
level3_cefr: Advertising on trial It was a bitter time for the advertising industry. At the time some of the industry leaders were making a big fuss about the fact that many companies were cutting costs to make a profit. That was understandable of course since no one could know how long it would last and how much more severe it would get. At the same time the economic situation did not make it any easier to attract the attention of potential clients. There was a tendency for many of them to become tetchy at the thought of advertising their products in such a tough economic climate. Yet even if clients weren't necessarily making the kind of decisions that would lead to a recession it meant that advertising would have to go on. As a consequence many large, established, well-funded agencies in Britain made a concerted effort to keep clients, and themselves, happy by finding ways to attract new clients. They took a number of unusual measures aimed at easing the pressure on clients to stick to rigid budgets, such as restricting spending on staff training and re-orienting their focus to new markets. Rather than trying to do their best to win clients and create a profit, they were putting themselves on the defensive to secure their existing work. They reduced staff levels, reduced overheads, decreased salaries and even cut the salaries of their employees who were already stretched. In effect they had made themselves into "agencies of survival
level4_fkg: A new strategy had been devised to make advertising more competitive in times of economic crisis. That strategy was the use of television commercials to drive footfall into brands such as the British Heart Foundation (BHF). At the time, the BHF had a budget of £150 million (about $150 million today), and their advertising expenditure over three years averaged about £1.25 million a week. This advertising cost, however, was not unusual compared to the cost of other forms of advertising in the early 1990s. In a country as engulfed in a worldwide recession it would have cost £300 million today to run the same television advertising campaign. Until then, BHF was the largest advertising agency in the UK, but it lost half of its business when the recession hit. At that time, BBC Radio 4 was relegated to only 5th place in the UK charts. For example, in 1990, British Airways, the world's largest airline, retreated to its lowest position on the chart at number 10 in 1992. Similarly, the number one spot in London Times Square ad spend dropped by 10% that year. This, combined with the fact that other agencies were launching ads and not only remained competitive with British Airways, but had been on the TV screen at night, and the advertising content in all the commercials, also had to be boosted. The problem was that a lot of the advertising
level4_cefr: Advertising on trial It was not easy to stay creative during this very dark period of the British economy. But there were ways to cope, and that was to show the world that we were not completely hopeless even as the economy continued to falter....

level1: It’s true, there are good and bad poetry writers out there. Good poets take some time to develop an eye for poetic meter and imagery, and many fail to keep this in mind. Ignoring this common error on the part of many writers, I present the following chart to show how to determine the size of an unruly poem: How to Write a Poem a Poem a Poem in One or Two Lines The first question to ask yourself is how much space to make, and how long you’ll make the poem. A poem has a meter of around 10 lines. Once you know what your line count is, then you can consider how many lines to make to best fit it in. A good line count is 3 lines: 1 line should be 5 lines; 4 lines should be 4 lines; and 5 lines should be 6 or 8 lines. A good rule of thumb is to write at least 2 lines longer than the minimum of 3 lines, and 2 lines shorter than that. For more guidance and specific suggestions, check out this post on how to figure out what to write. To keep the lines together, make sure the rhyme scheme is balanced with at least 3 consonant (I recommend 8 consonant sounds only). You’ll need to do this step twice to make your line count: once when you have the line count where it is 8 and 4 lines, and then again when the
level2_fkg: How to Write Poetry Telling people how to write poetry is a bit like frolicking through a minefield: spontaneity is the order of the day but one false step and a dozen certainties will blow up in your face. Setting oneself up as a know-all is dangerous so I have decided to side-step the whole issue by saying that for someone just beginning to write no advice can be a substitute for abundant reading, extensive writing and the freeing of the imagination and spirit in whatever way seems fruitful barring total anarchy. Some people need their life to be reasonably secure before a poem will come; others can write their way out of misery.

level3_cefr: 1. Poetry is an art in which the poet uses language and images to create meaning. Poetry should not be treated as a science, it is the product of a living process and must be treated with respect in order to become something valuable. It can be an avocation or it can be a job. Poetry should be developed in its entirety through the process of writing in whatever form seems the most suitable and appropriate to the poem. 2. The first stage in learning how to write poetry is to read a wide variety of poetry, especially English poetry. As soon as you have read a few poems, you should keep on reading them until you find something you enjoy. Keep reading to build up your vocabulary, to become familiar with all kinds of different styles of poetry. Try reading some poetry that you have never heard before. You might find yourself inspired to write a poem. 3. To write a poem, you need to imagine, to write something without thinking about anything. You might have an idea for a poem while you are walking in the woods, or while you are dreaming. You might have an idea for a poem when you feel lonely or when you are scared or in a strange situation. 4. Write a poem from the same point of view or from different points of view. The goal is not to try to make your poem better or more complicated. The focus must be on expressing your thoughts, feelings and opinions. When you have written

level1: Amazon.com offers up a lot more than books and the occasional recommendation or two. It also has a great selection of free and low cost literary criticism books, which in itself is a nice little bonus. For example, I did a Google search for "daily dose of literary criticism" and came up with my own personal favourite. On this site, I offer a list of recommended books, selected according to my taste and not by random. I have included links to reviews from The New Yorker, the Washington Post, Time, the Wall Street Journal, The Los Angeles Times, the Chicago Tribune, the Los Angeles Times, Salon.com, and many other respected magazines and publications. The titles on offer are all fairly diverse, and the book reviews on the site are far from exhaustive. However, I feel that the site offers an important contribution to the broader field of literary criticism. I hope that readers, and writers, will be encouraged by the variety of literary criticism offered. As well as the usual fare I try to include anecdotes and tidbits on various readings, movies, music, and food. There are many things on offer which are of interest to anyone interested in contemporary literature. There are also two other main categories of information, one of which is the Amazon Review. The reviews are usually only 300 words or less, but they can contain up to 70 words and sometimes over 100. If
level2_fkg: Online Literary Criticism For All Do-it-yourself literary criticism: more than just harmless fun? From the outset the idea of open access to the Internet was one of its guiding principles. In theory anyone could publish a manifesto or broadcast a music channel on the Internet. In practice, however, a certain amount of technical know-how was required, at least in the early years. However, there was at least one field previously restricted to the few that was genuinely opened up to the masses. By visiting the pages of Amazon.com, the first popular online bookshop, anyone was able to try their hand at literary criticism.

level1: It was already after 4 pm when he went upstairs to find that the lights had gone out. ‘It’s very funny. What a weird time to be trying to learn something new. How embarrassing for both of you!’ mui sighed. Chen said: ‘Mui, look at you, ringing the bell – ringing, ringing - you could hear the sirens outside the window but not the police. Mui, you are too busy for that!’ he exclaimed as he rang the bell. ‘Now I want to hear the question,’ Lily replied. ‘Well, your brother-in-law is the one who owns the car – he can drive!’ he replied as he rang the bell again. ‘He can’t drive’ Mui pointed out. ‘Why?’ Lily explained. The two sisters had been trying to avoid him. But now he had turned up, and that was the only way he could be identified. Mui then said: ‘So why did you call the police? Then you wouldn’t be the only one who knew I’d been driving?’ Chen thought for a moment and replied: ‘Well we both know you’re good at this,’ he said. ‘Are you telling Mui that I’ve been driving? I never asked you
level2_fkg: Mui looked back at Lily, whose new found skills were still a secret from her father-in-law. She was astonished that she had not noticed the small detail that Chen was so excited about.
level2_cefr: The two sisters kept Lily’s driving a secret from Chen for a time. She would drive around the allotments and the railway line and gasworks shooting the tiny hump-backed bridge with all four wheels in the air and a tremendous bump (Lily’s only misjudgment) before completing the journey by the gasworks in an odour of sulphur and brimstone. Chen however, was actually amused by what his wife had been doing behind his back. ‘So you can really drive it then Lily? Well done!’ Men were strange creatures, Mui thought. Brother-in-law should have been upset about this. Yet he was soon enthusiastically making plans with Lily for a jaunt, and obviously revelling in her mastery of this new skill.

level1: In a fit of true inspiration and self-analysis I asked myself: Do I really have the courage to accept God’s call on my life? A life of faithful and generous service? Or do I simply want to be famous for being one of the biggest talkers of the world and the most influential Christian speaker in history?
level2_fkg: I waited to be told that cowboys only have big boots. Cowboys also have big hearts. They are compassionate and love people. They are honest. That’s why cowboys have big hearts. I’d give anything to give cowboys my heart. In short, cowboys care for others. When I heard that, I cried.
level2_cefr: It was a strange morning. I could not believe the way the clouds broke. The sun was so hot. It felt like I was about to get burned, yet I had arrived at the desert. It felt like I had been thrown into the middle of a scene in the western movie "Cowboy Bebop". I couldn’t shake the feeling that I would die before getting to the desert. My heart began to race. It took me a moment to calm down. And then I could feel my pulse pick up. I was still standing on those rocks in those big boots. I could not believe that my feet were still in those big boots.
level3_fkg: We are Talking Big Boots here. Really BIGTIME Boots. I stood in my 800-dollar-each designer-label cowboy boots on the rocks of an old formation in the Arizona desert sand. Money no object. I wore the whole cowboy outfit and if you had the outfit you might be a cowboy. But I was not. It wasn’t working. I squinted info the morning sun looking out at the Arizona mountains and I had to admit I was not at home on the range. Flying in from Denver just after dawn I had the feeling that I just might pass far an ol' cowhand coming in from the sky.
level3_cefr: As I sat on the rocks and stared at the desert landscape and the stars I realized that my boots were not the answer. No, they just were not. I have had my fair share of adventures on the road, but it wasn’t until I sat down on the sand, looked out at the desert, and remembered that there was a cowboy who had a solution to what I was feeling. He told me he would do me a favor. He would make me laugh. He would make me understand what I was feeling. I told him that I was not being a cowboy. He said he had a cow.

level1: If a bird makes you sick, does it mean your bad luck has arrived? Could a bird be telling you that a bad car crash is coming? Could a bird be trying to let you know that you’re not worth spending time with? A recent study published in the journal Conservation Biology found that we’ve inherited a lot of skepticism about birds, and these beliefs are likely to lead us astray, writes the author of the study: Dr Susan M. Bender: Birds are not our personal saviors, but our saviors nonetheless. They make us think we should take care of our families and our homes, but they can also be a drain on the planet. “People are fascinated by birds in various ways but they also have a tendency to judge their actions as positive or negative by what they think other people will think, especially if they can think of positive or negative consequences, such as a house being overrun,” says Bender. Then there’s the myth of the wren, a bird with an enigmatic personality that people consider threatening, frightening or sacred. It’s an ancient belief that birds had a recurring pattern of dropping a piece of worm, the seedpod, onto their prey as a warning. To eschew this danger, wrens were left to die. Another
level2_fkg: My girlfriend and I are walking home from my mother's house in rural North Carolina when we hear a loud noise. We rush over and investigate, and see that a little brown shuttlecock has bounced against the glass. It turns out that it is a wren - a bird of portent, augury and divination. Is it spelling out some sort of message from a world at the very edges of my imagination? Or is it just a poor bird stuck in a greenhouse? Depending on your point of view, both could be true. You could say that your bird is a wren, and it is giving you a message about something eerily related to your own life. Or you could say that your bird is a wren, and it is an ominous bird, indicating that something may be about to happen to you. Or you could say that it's a poor bird, and you're just glad that it's not dead. To answer your questions: If your bird is an ominous bird, it's probably sending you a message or warning you about something in your life that you want to change. You'll need to look up some wren myths to find out why they believe in omens, augury and divination.
level2_cefr: A bird has been our symbol for the past couple of thousand years. It's a small bird, with a long tailed body and feathers. They were regarded as creatures of darkness and mystery, with an unwavering belief in their power to utter warnings and ill omens, and as messengers of bad things to come. Despite a few rudimentary attempts to understand their language, humans still haven't quite been able to answer the question: are we all just birdwatchers? One theory is that birds are actually much smarter than people give them credit for. A quick survey of a few popular websites suggests a number of people agree that there is a wren and a number of people disagree on which one is the most interesting. Some people believe the wren is a messenger from a strange parallel world that we ourselves created. Others say that birds are messengers from another dimension that is a part of the material world and not the spirit world.
level3_fkg: "The myths and rituals around birds are as old as the world itself. For humans, birds have eluded the boundaries of our imaginations, and we have created fantastical ideas about them in fanciful ways."
level3_cefr: Love them fear them worship them, the human race has always been drawn to birds. Birds have been the subject of countless songs and tales of bad luck, misfortune, or just plain old pity. But if they are more than just cute little creatures, they have also played important roles in human history. To the early Greeks, birds were considered harbingers of death. To the Egyptians, they were symbols of regeneration and immortality, and they tamed their ferocious predators by giving them wings. In the 18th century, some early bird watchers began to use "wrens" as symbols of fright and fear, with the famous 1931 painting "Wren frightened and starving" (Michael Jackson) starring a wren frightened and starving. More recent studies have sounded different, including a 2009 study on an international bird watchers' group in the US claiming wrens are a "fear of the supernatural" and that they help to break bad dreams. In one study, wrens were considered to warn of the upcoming of the end of the world in 1337. The findings were backed by further work, including a 2010 study that claims wrens are "a symbol of mortality and death." The birds are also part of our collective
level4_fkg: The birds in my greenhouse have always been my fascination. A little brown shuttlecock bounces against the glass as it hops around from plant to plant, and we're both happy he's hanging around. But what does it say about us? Paul Evans explains how his interest in bird behaviour began as a child when he saw a crow in a tree at school. This piqued his curiosity and he wanted to be like that bird. So he went to college to study psychology. But even as he got better at studying the behaviour of birds, he continued to observe them closely. He discovered that although birds are ominous, they're also just shy, playful creatures. These traits can make it difficult for people to be friends with them. "It's always going to be this way," he told Nature. "I think there's a lot of mistrust, but also a lot of empathy. I don't want them to be a troublesome bird. But to be a little bit kind to them would be a great beginning." Paul's fascination with birds continues to this day as he writes a weekly column for the Guardian about life in the countryside.
level4_cefr: Paul Evans says we owe a lot to birds: the animals we've worshipped for hundreds of years, the symbols we've tied to our own cultures, the mysteries we've astonished with. But is all this just about bird-watching? It's part of the British Museum's Natural History collections, the largest of its kind in Europe. Over the past 100 years, more than 2,000 different kinds of bird have been culled from museums there, including more than 5,000 different species of wrens, a bird of portent. Evans has visited the collections in London, Berlin, and Rome, and he reflects on the cultural significance of birds in human culture.

level1: BOOKS FOR KIDS, THE COVER:... and more! Joanna MacGregor has a hectic schedule as a concert pianist. So why has she added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano? Even a member of that mythical species the completely tone deaf could not fail to be stirred by a Joanna MacGregor performance. Simply to see her zipping around a keyboard grabbing fistfuls of notes at the behest of some unfeasible contemporary score is to watch a pianist pushing the human frame to its limits. But even her dazzling virtuosity was not enough to was one small boy at a recent concert she gave for kids.

level3_fkg: When Joanna MacGregor is not on stage as a concert pianist, she can be found writing for children. Her books are designed to help young children learn the piano in the same way she learnt when she was a young child. Now, she’s a parent. But she won’t have it all her way. After being invited to attend a concert by a very small child, Joanna knows her only way of keeping the child entertained is with a funny and memorable story. That is, until the child begins asking questions.

level1: I can't tell you how many chapters of the book I can dispense with. The only place that I haven't abridged is the entire ending of the book. Ultimately, even though the book was written before I was born, I know what I wanted to include. As the script sat on my desk I thought back to what I had already penned in my head and said, "What would you do if you had this?" I then decided to make it less confusing for the reader by making that part of the book go away. The ending of the book has a different message, a different point. We no longer need to know what the hell happened to the characters who died at the beginning of the book. It's only our job to imagine what they do next in the course of events. Here are some thoughts I had when drafting the movie: When the film starts we immediately understand the purpose of the film - they want us to be aware of what happened in the book. They understand why they did what they did. It also helps to imagine that the audience will not get a chance to catch the movie at the theatre before it opens. In movies, there is already a story being told. The actors are acting out their part. They already know a lot of the details, they've had to work for their part and they know what they're doing. When the
level2_fkg: Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction, condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer, but also illuminating. Working on a script, I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point. This does not necessarily mean that the dialogue and description of the original were superfluous. It is a matter of the type of attention demanded by the audience by narrative in each medium and a matter of the type of redundancy each employs.
level2_cefr: The story is about how the narrator has to adapt a novel for the screen. She was frustrated because of how much of the dialogue and narrative description she could dispense with.

level1: The Heat is On We’ve all heard about global warming but just how much warmer will the earth get and how will it affect our lives? Almost everyone has some idea of what global warming is all about but no one is quite sure about its consequences. A warmer climate is likely to mean changes to the weather in all parts of the world. And since the atmosphere is intimately linked to every aspect of the planet on which we live, any changes to climate will have significant knock-on effects for plants and animals as well as water and soils. We humans have learned to use such natural resources to our advantage, enabling us to produce food build great cities and support six billion members of the human race.

level1: c. 1680 Maps were first used in England and the Netherlands, with the first printed maps appearing in Britain between the 9th and 10th centuries A.D.
level2_fkg: Maps were important for determining how a distance was measured and the direction it was heading. They also helped keep track of the location of things when they had to be kept somewhere a long time in the past.
level2_cefr: Maps The purpose of a map is to express graphically the relations of points and features on the earth’s surface to each other. These are determined by distance and direction. In early times distance was often expressed in units of time, for example ‘so many hours’ march’ or ‘a day’s journey by river’ but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than they did about actual distance. The other element is direction, but for the ordinary traveller whose main concern was ‘Where do I go from here?’ and ‘How far away is it?’ the accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance.

level1: AMERICAN executives are adopting the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model of good management, writes Eluned Price for the BBC. As The Telegraph points out, 'the polar explorer was a 'people person'. He would ask the people to do what he needed them to do, and did not ask them to do things they shouldn't have done.' Shackleton is credited with leading the most dangerous expedition of his age – the expedition of the Endurance – to the South Pole, but was eventually forced to quit despite the fact that he feared the cold. After his death in 1914, the American public seemed to get the polar exploration bug. His life was celebrated as an example of good management. A documentary about his life and accomplishments is currently in production. The US icebreaker Pelican, which has never attempted a crossing of the Antarctic ice, will be shown at a public celebration in Washington, D.C., on January 31. 'We're going into the future – we're going to be trying to be successful in the future', says a Pelican spokeswoman. Sir Ernest died in 1922, but his name and voyage are still widely known.
level2_fkg: Ernest Shackleton had the reputation as a 'People Person': he didn't worry about himself or the company he ran. He knew when it was time to put the men first and, like any manager, gave the job to the people he wanted to manage. Now, American executives have adopted the polar explorer's model of good management as a model for success: Shackleton teamed with the explorer and Antarctic scientist Sir Ernest Shackleton to make a gruelling and disastrous voyage to the South Pole in 1908 as the last surviving member of his famous expedition.
level2_cefr: Sir Ernest Shackleton's gruelling 1905-1906 Antarctic adventure was billed by the US National Geographic magazine as one of the best expeditions ever undertaken in the Antarctic. He faced danger and sledging as well as cold and he did it without fuel or food and when he finally reached the South Pole he was greeted warmly by the American public.
level3_fkg: HE WAS A PEOPLE PEOPLE HE WAS A PIECE OF WARRIOR ERROR. US EVENING SCHOOL TEAMS UP FOR FUNERAL: "Our ancestor, Sir Ernest Shackleton, had a habit of saying, 'The things that will get you out of trouble can be done.'"
level3_cefr: American executives are adopting the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management, Eluned Price reports in the Washington Post.
level4_fkg: A polar explorer who made history by crossing the Antarctic and setting a new record for time at sea - 1882–1902 - is now being adopted as a model for management success in America.
level4_cefr: HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American executives are adopting the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model of good management.

level1: Technological advances continue to transform our lives at work at home and in our leisure activities. Susan Hallam discusses their impact on music in Britain. In the latter half of the 20th century we saw a rapid increase in the opportunities available for listening to music through radio TV records tapes CDs videos and a rapidly developing range of multi-media techniques. Along with this there has been a decline in the performance of live music and in the full-time employment opportunities for professional musicians. There seems little doubt that the widening access to music is likely to continue fulfilling, as it does so many human needs.

level1: The Holiday Reading The Summer promises us two of life’s great joys: escaping home and reading books. Joys that of course are intimately connected. Books may help us to feel more at home in the world at large. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands because there are fewer human types than there are people. In the books of others we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling or can express our very own thoughts but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.

level1: Photographs are a means of transferring experience and information. The way you experience something in a photograph can be very different from the way you experience a story or other text. For example, you can easily experience the feeling of being confronted with a threat or danger. You can experience these emotions by looking at photographs of violence. These are the kind of images that help you understand and accept human behaviour. However, when you try to experience a scene with someone you haven’t met you’re less likely to experience the same kinds of emotions. Photographing an object that you haven’t met has a very different effect on your perception of the subject. When you see the image of a woman with an artificially long braid at a carnival you’re probably more likely to interpret the image as a representation of female sexuality. You’re probably more likely to interpret it as a representation of being in love. It’s not clear to me whether people would have this reaction to photographs from a completely different culture than their own. It’s possible that they would feel more cynical when they saw one of these kinds of images in a foreign land. So, it’s up to you. This book is designed to help you explore the images you see in the real world. By studying your favorite photographs you’ll begin to develop an understanding of how the world is presented in pictures -
level2_fkg: I think photography has a place in society and is important to all of us. I think you have to consider what a photograph means, how a photographer takes a photograph and what influences the choice of images that you see.
level2_cefr: Photography When a photographer takes a photograph he or she makes a selection of visual information that is determined by his or her technical and aesthetic skills, personal views and experience, together with a set of social and cultural norms. And in the course of this book we shall see how these factors not only affect the style content and expression of a photograph, but also how those images are perceived and responded to by the viewer. For example, we might consider that the casual reader of a newspaper will have an implicit understanding of the photographic images reproduced on the page.
level3_fkg: Photography When a photographer takes a photograph he or she makes a selection of visual information that is determined by his or her technical and aesthetic skills personal views and experience together with a set of social and cultural norms. And in the course of this book we shall see how these factors not only affect the style, content and expression of a photograph but also how those images are perceived and responded to by the viewer. For example, we might consider that the casual reader of a newspaper will have an implicit understanding of the photographic images reproduced on the page.

And in the course of this book we shall see how these factors not only affect the style, content and expression of a photograph, but also how those images are perceived and responded to by the viewer. For example, we might consider that the casual reader of a newspaper will have an implicit understanding of the photographic images reproduced on the page.

level1: ‘Don’t worry, Maurice. I know he will enjoy it as much as I am.’ I replied. Maurice, not quite knowing where to begin, said: ‘But what if I change my mind?’ I explained. He said that the money he had given me for a trip to the United States was not the money that Maurice had really given him in the first place. Maurice had said that his father had sent him money from Paris but I did not think Maurice had actually ever made any money in Paris. I also doubted whether Maurice was willing to invest his money if he did not know how much he could get for it in a few months. ‘So why did you give your money to the man who had never even lived there?’ my father asked with a smile. I looked back at my father and asked ‘What do you mean?’ ‘Well, I’m afraid you’ll have to pay for it,’ Maurice replied. ‘I mean the tuition fees,’ I replied. ‘I think he’s going to charge you even more for doing something so stupid.’ Maurice laughed and my father said nothing. I said ‘I understand Maurice’s point of view, and so I’ll just leave you with that’.
level2_fkg: My Father told me a story that he had told me about the family business that he ran. When he told this story to his son I was so excited that I blurted it out to him. He said that when he was in his younger days, he was an entrepreneur and used to juggle business and family. Now he was retired and the family business was the usual business that he took care of. Then one day when I was about to tell the story he asked, ‘Well, now, can you tell me a bit about it?’ ‘Yes, Dad.’ I said. ‘It’s quite simple really. When a businessman takes over another family business, they start thinking how they can make money on that business. He has the whole family to manage so he has to have Maurice, the boy, take care of it. He takes Maurice in to bed in the morning, and Dad takes Maurice to a special restaurant and Maurice buys me a bottle of champagne and then he leaves. Then Maurice takes care of Maurice and takes Maurice to dinner and Maurice takes Maurice to my room and Maurice spends the night at my parents’ house. Then Maurice gives all the money from the wine in our cellar to Maurice and Maurice gets a book of travel guides. But if Maurice wants the
level2_cefr: The Family Business ‘Look here it’s no good!’ said my Dad. We were in the car on the way back to London. My father with my brother Maurice in tow had just collected me and my trunk from the posh girls’ school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent’s Day in the course of which I was presented with the Latin prize and the prize for the girl who had done best in her end-of-school exams. He had had a long conversation with my headteacher and now here we were bound for home and holidays. ‘What isn’t?’ I said though I had guessed the trend of his thoughts from his unusual silence.
level3_fkg: You see there are two reasons why I won the Latin prize. The first is that I studied at the school. I am used to doing well in exams and I am used to doing well at the school. It’s all in the preparation. I could not resign early so I had to finish my last exam on Wednesday before going into school. The second reason is that I didn’t win the prize for the girl who did best in her end-of-school exams. The last reason is that when my father collected me from the school, he handed me over to Maurice. Maurice knew what he was doing and I suspected he could not do it. I was wrong. I had made my best in my final exams, though the only grades I got on my last exam were ‘B’ and ‘C’. I should have scored higher than those. The first reason is that Maurice is my brother. When I told him of my triumph over Maurice he paused but said, ‘It’s all right, Maurice.’ I hoped he could understand. Maurice smiled but told my father he was sorry. Maurice did not say anything to him about his feelings. My father said he would rather have Maurice to himself. He did so until my father spoke. level3_cefr: ‘I’m sure it isn’t,’ I said. ‘How’d you know it wasn’t?’ ‘Dad figured it was because he was looking for another job when I had finished school. He then went into Maurice’s room to retrieve the key, when he realised I had left the door open. He screamed after me and threw Maurice’s keys down the stairs. But I ran across Maurice standing in front of the door. He had the key in the lock, and he had already gone in to get it. ‘Let me get it and get Maurice out of there,’ I said. ‘I didn’t want you doing that!’ ‘You didn’t do it for Maurice!’ Maurice screamed. ‘The house is locked!’ Maurice screamed. ‘It’s not open!’ ‘But I do’ Maurice screamed. ‘You must have knocked on the door and the key is not there!’ ‘Well, you’re going to have to get to the other side of the house anyway because there is a ladder outside!’ ‘You can get to it, Maurice’ my father said. level1: Vancouver In the last ten years or so hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world have taken up residence in Vancouver in western Canada. To relax in the evening residents stroll down the city streets and if you join them you are likely to overhear a different language at almost every other step. People come to Vancouver for its mild climate its wonderful setting between the ocean and the mountains, its clean and safe environment and its educational and job opportunities. And much as some may grumble about the speed at which new buildings have sprung up, there's no doubt that the new arrivals and flourishing tourism industry have helped fuel an urban renaissance.

level1: It is, in fact, the theatre that makes opera so valuable in that it is the one art form in which everyone has an equal opportunity for understanding and enjoyment. So, a good opera is music with drama.
level2_fkg: MUSIC AND THEATRE Up until quite recently I would have said that opera is first and foremost theatre. Not any more. After a brief spell working at a national opera house I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That’s as it should be of course. But I come from a different world, the world of the theatre, where the word and the actor speaking it have primacy, where there is nobody out front directing the action once the event is underway and where performer and audience (mostly) speak the same language. At any musical performance, whether in a concert hall or opera house, there will generally be a substantial minority of people who like me have little technical or academic understanding of music.
level2_cefr: A MAN READING A BIBLE BOOK UP UNTIL QUITE RECENTLY I WOULD HAVE SAID THAT OPERA IS FIRST AND FOREMOST THEATRE. NOT ANYMORE. After a brief spell working at the United Nations Opera House, I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That’s as it should be of course. But I come from a different world, the world of the theatre. Where the word and the actor speaking it have primacy, where there is nobody out front directing the action once the event gets under way and where performer and audience (mostly) speak the same language. At any musical performance, whether in a concert hall or opera house, there will generally be a substantial minority of people who, like me, have little technical or academic understanding of music.

level1: Broadcasting originally meant sowing seeds broadly by hand. It is in other words not only an agricultural metaphor, it is also one of optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth in the widest possible circles the production if the conditions are right of a rich harvest. The metaphor presupposes a bucket of seeds at the centre of the activity i.e. the existence of centralised resources intended and suited for spreading - and reproduction. The question to be looked into is why a new technology that transmitted words and pictures electronically was organised in a way that made this agricultural metaphor seem adequate.

level1: Those are my thoughts on writing a book review. Mostly I like what Frank Kermode writes but I have a few things he says which make me uncomfortable. The book review is more of a critique than a review. You have to be critical and objective and you can’t just give a broad overview. If a book is worth reading, then it must be read. When I write a book review I also go into some very interesting theoretical territory which is quite a lot more advanced than just book reviewing. For instance, I go into literary criticism and philosophy. In my personal view, philosophy, and religion are some of the most important fields in literature today so I am sure it’s interesting to read about how both areas have evolved over the last twenty or thirty years. As I read, I see how my thinking on a certain subject is shaped by my cultural background and how that has shaped my reading. The fact that I have such a large amount of knowledge about a particular field shows that if you have a good grasp of that field then you are in a much better position to give a more coherent and well-informed opinion. Obviously, I don’t think I always do a good job of explaining the reason why I agree with a given stance or argument. But I also realise that there is a lot to learn from other perspectives and that it’s very
level2_fkg: Most reviews are written and circulated under conditions which ensure that they have a very short active life. There are deadlines, there are restrictions normally quite severe on their length; and when published they claim houseroom only for as long as the newspaper they are printed in - a day or a week at most a month. Moreover, the literary status of reviews tends to be settled by their ephemerality.

level1: The film Citizen Kane was released in 1941. After the flamboyant opening scene, I was shocked, stunned, and even sickened at the scenes in the following two acts. The final scene that left me speechless was the final scene, where he was literally buried alive. Then I was awed once more by what welles had accomplished in such a short period. Kane was an enigma. A living, breathing man on the verge of death. He was not the only man to lose his life but his only son. And, of course, his grandson, William Randolph Hearst, was not only his source of the story but, apparently, it was the only man to have ever actually seen Kane. For one brief but terrifying moment in the final scene, an unidentified man, possibly a security guard, stepped out and jumped off a building. Kane stepped back and looked around. A shadowy figure in the distance made its way toward him, seemingly a person or thing standing before him. It seemed to me he was not the same man who had witnessed him on the day that he had lost his life but perhaps the same man who would see him in the future. But Kane did not merely take his life on that day but rather he took the life of a man that would – in the end – still
level2_fkg: Citizen Kane When the film Citizen Kane finally appeared in 1941, despite the brouhaha that attended its release - delayed because of the distributor’s fears of the harm William Randolph Hearst’s alleged subject might do to them - and largely ecstatic reviews, it was not a commercial success. It was television that brought it back to the public consciousness. It is perhaps the one film above all others that has inspired people to become film-makers. This is all the more astonishing since it was Orson Welles’s first film. Welles always maintained that its success arose from his having no idea of what he was or wasn’t allowed to do: he just went ahead and did it.

level1: Breakfast came to England about 1600. In the fifteenth century, England had been plagued by disease, particularly for women. People who were overweight or obese would eat a late night snack before supper. This also encouraged the consumption of salt and sugar in an attempt to counteract the effects of alcohol and tobacco.
level2_fkg: England’s breakfast revolution The importance of a good breakfast is beyond dispute according to health experts, but in historical terms breakfast is a relatively new arrival in England, with descriptions of breakfast seldom featuring in medieval literature. Admittedly, there are scattered references to travellers having a meal at dawn before embarking on arduous journeys and to the sick sitting down to breakfast for medicinal reasons, but most people went without unless they were monarchs or nobles. However, in the sixteenth century, it gradually became the norm not the exception. Some writers have attributed this to the greater availability of food.
